Test tsag8rack_cpu_usage_x3dbnode.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsag8rack_cpu_usage_x3dbnode.tsc - enables/disables half of the CPU resources
                                        on X3 db node using resourcecontrol script

This test runs on real hardware. It enables/disables half of the CPU resources on X3 db node
     using resourcecontrol script. An X3 compute node has 8 active CPU cores per socket and a total
     number of 16 active cores. Half of them can be disabled and then 4 cores per socket and total
     8 cores will be functioning.

This is a real hardware test and at the time this test has been written eighthRack attribute
     has not been implemented for compute nodes therefore CPU cores are enabled/disabled by using
     resourcecontrol script. resourcecontrol is tool found in /opt/oracele.SupportedTools/
     directory on a cell/compute node.

This test runs on real hardware. It enables/disables half of the CPU resources on X42 db node
     using resourcecontrol script. An X42 compute node has 12 active CPU cores per socket and a total
     number of 24 active cores, half of them can be disabled. After  having disabled half of the CPU
     cores 6 cores per socket and total 12 cores will be functioning.

This is a real hardware test and at the time this test has been written eighthRack attribute
     has not been implemented for compute nodes, therefore CPU cores are enabled/disabled by using
     resourcecontrol script. Script resourcecontrol is a tool found in /opt/oracele.SupportedTools/
     directory on a cell/compute node.

Test tsag8rack_tst_6.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsa8rack.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsag8rack_tst_6.tsc - executes test 6

Test 6: Simulate a failure on a disk. The cell disk (cd)/grid disks (gd)/flash
             cache (fc)/flash log (fl) on it (if any) will be automatically recreated
             on a spare disk. Make a note of the cd/gd/fc/fl info before the failure
             simulation, and compare it with the recreated ones after the simulation.
             Make sure cell disk deviceName, devicePartition, id, and physicalDisk
             attributes are all different. The status should all be normal. FC and FL
             remain normal with the same size.

Test tsagabortsnapdel.tsc. setup=xblockini. flags: iscsi=true, multiple_bst=true. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagabortsnapdel.tsc - Verify that  snap deletion job is aborted when VIP is moving to new worker

Abort snap deletion job if VIP is moving to new worker,
     so that it won't be blocked since snap file deletion can drag long.
     To be more specific, VIP will be released earlier and let it move
     instead of waiting there and hit the ORA since VIP cannot drain the running job.
     The job will keep running and end the job when file deletion is completed.

     Test Steps:
1.  Start with iscsi mode  and multiple BSWs
2.  create 3 VIPs, 3 5g volumes, 3 snapshots
3.  kill two BSWs
4.  Set snap file deletion delay simulation
5.  remove 3 snapshots - eventually the requests will be timed out or get Error code: 20018
6.  Bring up one BSW
7.  wait 5 mins. Should not see ORA "fail to drain running jobs "
8.  turn off simulation
      9.  check vips and snapshots
      10. wait 5 mins more. Should not see ORA "fail to drain running jobs "
11.  check VIPs - 3 VIPs should all be state CREATED instead of MOVING
12. check snapshots - 3 snapshots are removed

This test case was added in transaction kukuchen_abort.snap.del.job .

Test tsagabortwhenhitkeeplimit.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsacachplcupgrd.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagabortwhenhitkeeplimit.tsc - Check keep ioctl rejects

Test to verify that when flashcache is already over keep threshold,
     new coming population request should be rejected

   Notes
    Run srdbmsini to setup database and cell, this script created a 1.5GB
    cellcli -e list flashcache detail
    Set cellsrv flashcache layer trace to mid level.
    Create a 1.5GB table testtb1
    Sqlplus> alter table testtb1 storage (cell_flash_cache keep); //This should full fill the flashcache with populated data of testtb1
    Create a smaller table(maybe 500MB) testtb2
    Sqlplus> alter table testtb1 storage (cell_flash_cache keep);//Populate request should be rejected by flashcache since flashcache is over keep threshold
    Grep cell trace for âfcPopRanges over keep limitâ, you should see it print out flashcache is over keep limit.

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagactondskevnt.tsc - Exadata Act on disk Event Test

#   Test verifies MS is shutdown and restarted during disk failure, removal and replacement ##
1. set MS_TESTING env
2. add _cell_actupon_disk_event_reboot_ms=true in cellinit.ora and restart MS
3. simulate  disk failure, list PD should fail with CELL-01514
4. MS status should be running after a little wait
5. Remove _cell_actupon_disk_event_reboot_ms, Restart MS
6. List PD status (should be failed) and alert for failure should be generated

Repeat the steps 2-6 for simulating disk removal

Repeat the steps 2-6 for disk replacement

Test tsagaffinity.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagaffinity.tsc - Tests node->IP address affinity code in ossnet.c

On Numa machines, some IP address are closer to some nodes than
     others.  On such machines it is more efficient for a given node
     to use a particular IP address for message traffic in and out than
     other IP address.  This test, test the code which makes this
     selection in ossnet.c.

     In addition to that, having more than 4 IPs (e.g. 8) in the system
     requires the libcell to select a subset of 4 IPs that would be used
     to initialize the SKGXP context.

     See http://dbdev.us.oracle.com/twiki/bin/view/Sage/DBNodeSupportFivePlusHCAs

There are two ways to simulate NUMA-aware machine:

      - Using "SIM_NUMA" environment variable, which simulates the NUMA-aware
        machine at the skgsn level. We're using this method to test the
        oss_check_sage_config() which happens to have no diag context.

      - Using the 'libcell.cellclnt_ossnet_trc' diag event. We're using this
        method to simulate a particular node (not possible via the skgsn
        simulation).

     tsagaffinity.c - the C test case that drives the load

Description: tsagarbcov.tsc - Arbiter test for griddisk layer coverage

Griddisks can be physcially fragmented - but for the sage lrgs we run,
     the griddisks that get created have one contiguous fragment, due to
     which that portion of the code which deals with fragmented griddisk
     does not get exercised. We have added a parameter
     '_cell_force_split_gdisk' which creates a situation such that griddisk
     gets fragmented. NOTE this parameter is ONLY used for coverage and
     should never be tampered with in other tests.

Description: tsagarpe1.tsc - Sanity test for Auto Rebal Level Engine

       3) Cases for max vote value for rebalance

Test tsagarpejarhc.tsc. setup=(none). flags: oss_hw_testing=true, cellconnstr=root@^cell_name^.us.oracle.com. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagarpejarhc.tsc - Exploratory Unit Test for Auto Rebalance Power engine on HC

The tool - autoRebalTest.jar is used for simulating rebalance. It was developed by Yan Zhao.
     It requires 2 arguments : I/O workload configuration and ASM rebalance configuration.
     Following scenarios are run in the test using the tool:
     1) Small Read Only
     2) Large Read Only
     3) Small Write Only
     4) Large Write Only
     5) Small Log Write Only
     6) Large Log Write Only
     Each of the above scenarios are simulated by using appropriate IO workload configurations.

     After running each of these scenarios, the test validates whether the power vote values
     followed the trend, the pattern should be like increase -> decrease -> increase.

     This test case is run on both High Capacity and Extreme Flash hardwares.
     "ef_test" flag is used for picking right config files, to run the test on EF hardware.
     If this flag is not set, the config files appropriate for HC hardware will be picked.

Confluence page : https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/display/~yan.zhao@oracle.com/Exploratory+Unit+Test

Description: tsagattachlimit.tsc - Tests that maximum of 256 attachments could be made per initiator id.

Test case to check the maximum number of attachments
   that could be attached to a single initiator id. Its expected
   that 64 attachments to single initiator id will be successfull
   and 65th attachment to that initiator id will fail.

   Test cases covered:
    1) Attaches 260 volume attachments to 260 different initiator ids. All should succeed.
    2) Attaches 260 volume attachments, 5 attachment per initiator id. All should succeed.
    3) Attaches 64 volume attachments to single initiator id. They should succeed and 65th attachment to same initiator id will fail.

The same test cases is covered for volume snapshot attachments.

Description: tsagautonj.tsc - dismount DG in both ASM instances after pulling disk

Similar to tsagautong.tsc with RAC except DG is dismounted in both
     ASM instances.
     - have 2 ASM instances
     - have DG mounted in both ASM instances
     - drop datafile1~4 from diskgroup.
     - pull a disk and verify that the disk goes offline in ASM
     - dismount DG in both ASM instances
     - push the disk back
     - verify that the disk does not get onlined
     - mount DG in one ASM instance
     - verify that the disk now gets onlined
     - add disks back in diskgroup

Test tsagawrrpt.tsc. setup=(none). flags: report_name='tsagrpt_'^awrsuffix^, awr_constr='connect sys/knl_test7 as sysdba'. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsa11p3_excld.
Suites: EXAC_REGRESS, EXAC_RMAN.
Description: tsagawrrpt.tsc - Generate ADDM, AWR, ASH report

* snap_interval - setting affects how often(mins) snapshots are automatically captured.
   * snap_topnsql  - The number of SQL captured for each Top criteria.

   Usage: runtest tsagawrrpt  mode=<BEGIN|END|> \
                           [awr_beginsnap=<awr_beginsnap>] \
                           [awr_endsnap=<awr_endsnap>] \
                           [report_name=<report_name>]

      1. If you know the snapshot ids and want to genereate reports between begin snapshot
          and end snapshot, then you can do:
          runtest tsagawrrpt awr_beginsnap=bein_snap awr_endsnap=end_sanp
      Note: a) Ensure bein_snap is less than end_sanp
            b) There isn't db shutdown event between bein_snap and end_sanp

      2. If you don't know snapshot ids but want to monitor oratst blocks, please follow
           the following example:

              set snap_interval 10 - The default value is changed to 30 mins
              set snap_topnsql 1000 - The default value is 100
              runtest tsagawrrpt mode=BEGIN
              {runutl tkrmopti -con ^s1^ -DropTables -pctlimit 90 >>> ^ofile^^r^.lst
               ....}
              runtest tsagawrrpt mode=END

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagawsrunscript.tsc - The wrapper of invoking sqlplus/perl/sh/cellcli
         to run on AWS cell and compute nodes

The wrapper of invoking sqlplus/perl/sh/cellcli to run on AWS cell and compute nodes
   it requires cell or compute parameter
     cell=[1-3], mean run on cell[1-3] node
     compute=[1-3], mean run on compute[1-3] node

   usage: how to run sql/perl/shell/cellcli

     echo > cell.dat
          > set echo on
          > list cell detail
     endecho
     tcellcli cell.dat cell=1 > ^outbasename^
     log append

     echo > checkimage.sh
          > imageinfo
          > echo "test value $1"
     endecho
     tsh checkimage.sh test1 cell=2 > ^outbasename^
     log append

     echo > checkimage.pl
          > system("imageinfo");
     endecho
     tperl checkimage.pl cell=2 > ^outbasename^
     log append

     echo > tsagcrttb.sql
          > set verify off
          > connect sys/knl_test7 as sysdba
          > set echo on
          > set trimspool on
          > set linesize 160
          > drop table t1;
          > 'create table &1 (c0 number, c1 date, c2 varchar2(2000), c3 nvarchar2(2000), c4 timestamp,'
          >       c5 timestamp with time zone, c6 timestamp with local time zone, c7 float(20), c8 number,  c9 number);
          > declare
          >  i     NUMBER := 0;
          >  k     timestamp:= systimestamp;
          >  l     nvarchar2(30):= ''stage22299'';
          > begin
          >  for i in 1..80000 loop
          > '  insert into &1 values (i,sysdate,''storage'',l,k+i,k+i,systimestamp,9999.99999,2,i); '
          >  end loop;
          >  commit;
          > end ;
          > /
          > 'select count(*) from &1 ;'
     endecho
     sesql tsagcrttb t1 compute=1 > ^outbasename^
     log append

The wrapper of invoking sqlplus/perl/sh/cellcli

Description: tsagawssesqlfp.tsc - SESQLF with Parameter passing on AWS and real hw lrgs

Use sqlplus to execute a sql script and optionally compare results.
     See sesqlf for a general description.  This file is the same as
     sesqlf except that it adds parameter parsing similar to sesql, so that
     parameters can be passed to the sql script being executed.

Usage:
       fork sesqlf script [compute=1-x] [compare[=refname]] [mask] [log=logname.log] \
                   [sqlargs...]

     Example:
       fork sesqlf tkfoo 3.14 2.718 compute=1 compare log=tkfoo01.log
                         ^    ^
                         \----|--- Arguments for tkfoo.sql

Test tsagawssetup.tsc. setup=(none). flags: deploy_oeda=1, aws_terminate_instance=y, aws_exadata_group=FUN. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagawssetup.tsc - Setup Exadata on AWS

Setup Exadata on AWS

     You can just run tsagawssetup.tsc to setup Exadata on AWS, below is the parameters
     that you can set with your speical setting:

       1) deploy_oeda : true|false, run oeda to deploy GI and DB, default is false
       2) aws_account_id : your aws account id, default is 548323806279
       3) aws_access_key_id: your aws access key id
       4) aws_secret_access_key: your aws secret access key
       5) aws_region_name: the region of your aws EC2 instances, default is us-west-2
       6) aws_exadata_group: Exadata group, default is FUN
             DEV - Development
             FUN - Functional Testing
             MAA - MAA/XTeam
             PRF - Performance Testing
             SUS - Sustaining Eng Team
             STR - Stress Testing
       7) cluster_id: cluster id, should be 1-47, default is 47
       8) aws_terminate_instance: y|n whether terminate instances at the end of test
                                  default is y

     For local run, you can just run:
       oratst tsagawssetup.tsc key=value

Setup Exadata on AWS

Test tsagbkpobjabsent.tsc. setup=xblockini. flags: setup_blockstore=true. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbkpobjabsent.tsc - Test backup deletion and restore operations when object is absent.

Test for kukuchen_allow.delete.bkp.if.bkp.obj.absent .
     Now the code allows user to delete backup or complete restore with backup in the situation that the object is absent.
     This is because we have a routine mechanism to delete bucket every 7 days. When the bucket is gone, backup object will
     be gone as well. In this case, instead of letting the server down or making the restore operation hang, will allow the
     operation to go ahead and complete the job.

Tests:

        1.  Delete the bucket and try deleting all backups starting from some intermediate backup.
            (We will hit soft ORA such as "absentBkpObj" but it shouldn't block the operation)
        2.  Delete the bucket. Create a new backup (this will likely recreate the bucket with same name,
            but old objects would be gone). Then try and restore from some older backup whose objects are all gone.
            Then delete all the backups starting from some intermediate one first.
            (Delete might hit the soft ORA. Restore should complete without hang, might also hit the soft ORA.)
        3.  Delete the bucket while restore, backup is going on.

Test tsagbsmbswcrash.tsc. setup=(none). flags: setup_blockstore=true. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsaexacldbsfail5edv.
Suites: EXAC_EDV, EXAC_REGRESS, EXAC_VOL.
Description: tsagbsmbswcrash.tsc - Simulates bsm and bsw failure through cellcli events.

In this test, BSM and BSW are crashed during control operation through
     cellcli events. The cellcli events are:
     Event 1 : EBS_IOCTL_ERR_BEFORE_CBK - Service is crashed while control
               operation is in progress.
     Event 2 : EBS_SRV_ERR_BEFORE_IOCTL_REPLY - Service is crashed when control
               operation is finshed but escli has not been informed about it.

     There are a total of 4 scenarios that can be simulated:
     1. Crashing BSM with Event 1 and BSW with Event 1.
     2. Crashing BSM with Event 1 and BSW with Event 2.
     3. Crashing BSM with Event 2 and BSW with Event 1.
     4. Crashing BSM with Event 2 and BSW with Event 2.

Description: tsagbsmfail.tsc - Failure test case for BSM

Sets up environment with 2 BSM  + 3 BSW
     Create 2 users
     Each user creates block devics and login to them
     Kill BSM leader and wait for 2nd bsm to become leader
     Logout from blockdevices and remove them for both users
     Each user creates block devices and login to them
     Kill new BSM leader . Now all bsm got killed
     All blockstore operations will fail
     Startup 2 bsm s and one among them will become leader
     Logout from blockdevices and remove them for both users

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbswbkpdiscard.tsc - This test script fixes one issue seen in stress test environment
       where a volume backup restoration is not able to find its backing object in OCI
       objectstorage

This test script fixes one issue seen in stress test environment where a volume backup
     restoration is not able to find its backing object in OCI objectstorage.
        Here are the test steps:
          1. create a 100G volume.
          2. write 10MB to the volume from offset 0.
          3. Make volume snapshot then backup.
          4. Restore the volume, before the previous transaction the operation will not be able to complete.

Description: tsagbswnetworkmon.tsc - Test for adding Network Monitoring functionality to BSW

Test steps:
       1) create two interfaces bsw1 and bsw2.
       2) update $OSSCONF/bsw/excloudinit.ora to include these two interfaces (both for client as well as storage)
       3) create vips and verify that they gets distributed among interfaces
       4) Fail one interface and ensure that IP address moves to the remaining
       5) Bring back the failed interface to ensure IPs get distributed nicely again
       6) Fail both the interfaces and make sure that BSW detects this and goes down.

Description: tsagbug13114222.tsc - Check, if rowsrc and rowsrc SI stats are updated for table scan.

KCFIS layer (smart scan) should consider adding row source statistics such as
     storage index savings, number of flash cache hits, a bitmap of different type
     of errors encountered, etc. Such row source statistics will eventually be part of
     sqlmon and will help in isolating performance regressions by comparing row source
     statistics between the good case and the bad case.

Test tsagbug13534084.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: creatdev_file=tsagprdef. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug13534084.tsc - Negative test case for bug 13534084, which involves shrinking the griddisk size
	             into the data area. The test will be changed once the bug is fixed.

The test can be outlined as follows :
  * Bring up DB on two cells
  * Shrink the griddisks to 1/4 of its original size, without shrinking them at ASM first.
        * Try restarting ASM and mount all the diskgroup. This operation should fail.
  * Any DB workload intiated at the DB instance should fail as well, as some of the data may
    lie outside the valid offset of the griddisk
  * Now, revert all the changes made to the griddisk, restart ASM and mount all the griddisks. This operation should work.
  * Resizing the griddisk back to its original size might have corrupted some griddisk. So, restarting DB could lead to
          ambiguous behavior as its possible that griddisk related to controlfile might be corrupted. Hence, we dont restart DB in this test case.

Test tsagbug13587920.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug13587920.tsc - test-case for OpenDisk async fencing check

This test aims to exercise the asynchronous implicit fencing check
     introduced as the fix for bug 13587920.

     Testcase overview:

      1. Set the lag-simulation event to inject 15 seconds delay the first time
         the FenceMaster is writing the metadata to the disk.
      2. Bring the CELLSRV down.
      3. Remove FenceMaster's on-disk metadata ($OSSCONF/cell_bootstrap.ora).
      4. Bring the CELLSRV up.
      5. Do a simple query to ensure the RDBMS had reconnected. Upon re-connect,
         the CELLSRV will have to update the FenceMaster metadata, which will step
         on the injected 15 seconds lag, causing the reconnects from other
         processes to be deferred.
      6. Validate with the phase-stats that we have indeed covered the async
         fencing check path (i.e. the OpenDisk's Fenceleader_Wait_to_Process phase
         has a non-zero 'phase_traverse_count').

Test tsagbug14803349_1.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: creatdev_file=tsagccdef. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsaactd11.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug14803349_1.tsc - Test case for bug 14803349

The test can be outlined as follows :
 * Bring up DB with normal redundancy
 * Stop caching unmirrored disks in cell 1
 * Shutdown cell services on cell 2 and  set events to run confinement tests on c9flash0,
   this should flush data on this disk.
 * Set events to pause the flush trigger in the previous step.
 * The disk c9flash0 shouldnt go in confined offline state, as there is some data still to be flushed and
   its partner disk is still unavailable.
 * Now, bring up cell services on cell 2. The disk c9flash0 should now go in confinedOffLine state.
       * Sleep for some time and make sure that the MS onlines the disk c9flash0 after running the confinement tests.

Test tsagbug14803349_2.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: creatdev_file=tsagccdef. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsaactd11.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug14803349_2.tsc - Test case for bug 14803349

The test can be outlined as follows :
       * Bring up DB with normal redundancy
       * Stop caching unmirrored disks in cell 1
       * Set events to trigger confinement tests on c9flash0, this should trigger flushing of data on this disk.
       * After the disk goes to confinedOffline state, sleep for some time to let MS run confinement tests on the disk.
   The disk is brought online after the tests are done runing on it.

Test tsagbug17546682.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: datafilelist=^rtest^, tsnum=0, bugtesti=bugtest^tsnum^, log_file=tsagbug17546682.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsamsbug3.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug17546682.tsc - NEW TEST REQUESTS FOR BUG 17513555

Add a new test case for bug 17513555, after fix of bug 17513555,
       scrubbing job would not kickoff back to back within 10min margin.
     Main Steps:
       1. Setup fake env with ASM instance
       2. Kickoff scrubbing:
          cellcli -e alter harddiskscrubstarttime='now'
       3. Check for alert.log that scrubbing was kicked off:
           look for messages like:
           Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9standby0.
           Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile4.
       4. Wait for 5min, check scrubbing should not be kicked off again:
           Check alert.log, there should no duplicate "Begin scrubbing <celldisk>"
           message for one celldisk.
       5. issue "cellcli -e alter harddiskscrubstarttime='now'" again, and check
           alert.log, scrubbing should kick off again.

Test tsagbug17547471.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsascbug14.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug17547471.tsc - Testcase for bug 17547471

Bug 17547471 - X2-8: CELL 1550 CELLSRV NOT RESPONSIVE WHEN CLUSTERWARE SHUTDOWN ABNORMALLY

This test ensures the subscriber (XDMG process in this case) is tracked aggressively for
    it's inactivity. Once the threshold of being idle is reached by any subscriber, that will
    be marked to be fenced automatically. This will avoid hangs on cellsrv when cluster services
    are brought down abnormally and events published by cellsrv to subscriber(s) are not
    responded

    Workflow:
   a) Bring up exadata stack with auto_management of disks enabled
   b) Kill cssd process
   c) sleep for 5 seconds
   d) Publish an event to subscriber (XDMG) - e.g: make a griddisk inactive
   e) The above event should wait for 120 seconds (threshold is 120sec in LRG and 10 min in prod)
      and then on no response from XDMG it marks XDMG's RSP as FENCED
   f) Grep for corresponding fence message in trace file.

Test tsagbug17876146.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: diskmon_pipe=_^host^_dskm_pipe, diskmon_pid=^proc_pid^, log_file=tsagbug17876146.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug17876146.tsc - TEST CASE REQUIRED FOR BUG-17415315

We wanted to make sure diskmon process (pertaining to hang diskmon_pid)
     cleans up by DiskmonAgent with following cases:-

     Case 1: When diskmon hang (kill -STOP <diskmon_pid>) OR take only below case.

     Case 2: When Diskmon hang (kill -STOP <diskmon_pid>) and at the same time if
     orarootagent restarted due to some reason (kill -9 <diskmonAgent_pid>).

     After sometime (say 90 seconds), we should not see the diskmon_pid running in
     the machine.

     This test might be verified on the production env since lrg may have multiple
     diskmons running the same machine. Otherwise, we might need to check the
     diskmon id properly on the lrg env. i.e., below command should return
     nothing:-

     (on lrg env)
     ps -aef | grep $ORACLE_SID | grep -i "_dskm_pipe" |grep -i <diskmon_pid>

     where diskmon_pid refers to the hang diskmon.

Test tsagbug19190475.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsascbug18.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug19190475.tsc - test case cover 19190475

test case for  _cell_oflgrp_in_debug_mode param
     Test step:
     1. set _cell_oflgrp_in_debug_mode in <user offloadgroup>/celloffloadinit.ora, restart cell services
     2. kill user offloadgroup and sys offloadgroup
     3. sleep for serveral seconds
     4. see sys offloadgroup pid come back, but user offloadgroup didn't
     5. set _cell_oflgrp_in_debug_mode in cellcli with offloadgroupEvents to sys offloadgroup
     6. kill user offloadgroup and sys offloadgroup
     7. sleep for serveral seconds
     8. see neither user offloadgroup nor sys offloadgroup pid come back
     9. shutdown cell services, remove  _cell_oflgrp_in_debug_mode in <user offloadgroup>/celloffloadinit.ora
     10. restsart cell services, kill  user offloadgroup and sys offloadgroup
     11. sleep for serveral seconds
     12. see both user offloadgroup and sys offloadgroup pid come back

Test tsagbug2.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: sage_mirror_mode=high, creatdev_file=tsagrddef. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug2.tsc - Test for bug 9208843 and 9208779 (as described in
                  - bug 9225235). Make sure query doesn't fail after system
                  - runs out of 1mb buffers.

This tsc file tests the following scenarios:
           - When a cellsv has a shortage of memory (1MB buffers), cellsrv return
             an out-of-memory error.  kcfis will then issue block IO requests instead
             of smart scans. For block IOs, we have a reserved pool of buffers on cellsrv.
           - Kcfis will use block IOs only for those cells which return an out-of-mem
             error.  For other cells, we use smart scans.  Hence, this test uses
             multiple cells and with resource configured to a small value in some cells.
             (not all the cells).

Test tsagbug20598619.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsafault4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug20598619.tsc - Bug test 20598619 in oss_safault4.tsc

IORM HARD LIMIT WHEN REACHED, FLASHLOG TO BE BYPASSED

- Set low IORM hard limits at database level
     - Soon more IOs result in ending up in IORM queue as IORM throttles
       the IOs seeing them hitting low hard limits
     - This builds up IO queue which are pending to be written to disk
     - While disk IOs are pending, if they are log writes, all are
       rescued by FL and DB runs happily.
     - In cellsrv, since the disk IOs are not complete and the buffers are
       still not released, any new incoming IOs, cellsrv will not be able
       to pick up as buffers exhausted and runs into hang.

Test tsagbug21861668.tsc. setup=xrdbmsini. flags: sage_mirror_mode=normal, creatdev_file=tsagrh2def. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgdbconsahdcio2.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug21861668.tsc - Test for bug 21861668

BUG 21861668 - ORA-600 [SAFEFILE_OPEN1: CAN NOT OPEN MORE THAN ONE SAFEFILE IN A THREAD]

     1.) start IOV on a griddisk to populate flash cache with dirty data.
     2.) fail a flash that was caching for the griddisk.
     3.) Set the following simulation events to simulate celldisk metadata IO errors:
       cellcli -e alter cell events='"cellsrv_simevent[CDMETA_READ_ERR] err_type=internal, frequency=1, count=2, evarg1=2201"'
       cellcli -e alter cell events='"cellsrv_simevent[CDMETA_WRITE_ERR] err_type=internal, frequency=1, count=2, evarg1=2201"'

        The evarg1 parameter controls what errorcode to simulate. 2201 is
        OSS_ERRCODE_IO_CANCELLED, which should NOT lead to celldisk confinement.
        The only errorcodes which should lead to confinement are 201 (OSS_ERRCODE_IOERROR) and
         2203 (OSS_ERRCODE_IO_CANCELLED_DUE_TO_DISK_FAILURE).

      4.) wait for resilvering to complete
      5.) When resilvering completes, it will attempt to write some celldisk metadata.
         Due to the events set in step 3, this IO will fail, and depending on the evarg1 parameter,
         will either lead to confinement of the celldisk or not. This also tests bug-21861668,
        since we should not see an assert at this step with the fix.

     9. Test end.

LRGs: (none).

Description: tsagbug22220568.tsc - Diskmon bug#22220568 test

1. Setup Exadata with below settings:
         setenv RECON_CELL_FREQ_IN_SEC 2
         setenv RECON_CELL_ATTEMPT_COUNT 5
         setenv SAGE_MIRROR_MODE high
      2. Shutdown DB
      3. Set event to diskmon:
         $ADE_VIEW_ROOT/oracle/bin/diskmon -m "libcell.diskmon_sim_ops[sleep_diskmon_thrd]
           dskmsimloc='sleep_at_dskm_proc_get_ossid',dskmsimstime=15000"
      4. Stop RS to prevent restart cellsrv on cell 2
      5. Startup DB (at the same time)   kill -9 <cellsrv_ospid>
      6. Unset the event:
         $ADE_VIEW_ROOT/oracle/bin/diskmon -m
           "libcell.diskmon_sim_ops[sleep_diskmon_thrd] dskmsimloc='',dskmsimstime=20000"

Test tsagbug22236130.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: OSS_ENABLE_FC_PERSISTENCE=writeback, raw_path=^T_WORK^/raw. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug22236130.tsc - Test for BUG 222361630

1. Create WB FC with 2 CD (tsagnini)
      2. list gd details - CachedBy non-empty, cachingPolicy default
      3. drop PDs
      4. list gd Details - CachedBy non-empty, CachingPolicy default
      5. reenable PDs
      6. list gd details - CachedBy non-empty, cachingPolicy default
      Repeat for WBFC with 1 CD and alter it to use 2 CDs for 3rd case

Due to the code change in bug 31439012, ALTER PHYSICALDISK DROP FOR
   REPLACEMENT will not flush Flash Cache on HDD. Thus, the CachedBy attribute
   will not be empty after the DROP command and is expected to remain the same
   value.

Test tsagbug22605762.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: TZ=PST8, datafilelist=^rtest^, tsnum=0, bugtesti=bugtest^tsnum^, log_file=tsagbug22605762.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsamsbug3.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug22605762.tsc - NEW TEST REQUESTS FOR BUG 22605762

Test procedure:
      1. Test scrubbing kickoff for normal schedule:
         - alter cell harddiskscrubinterval=biweekly
         set IO error simulation on one CD
         - alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[BLOCKIO_READ_ERR] err_type=internal,frequency=1,count=1,
                              evarg1=c9datafile0"

         get current time and set start time as two weeks ago:
          - alter cell harddiskscrubstarttime="2016-01-19T21:32:43-08:00"
         wait for 20sec, we should see scrubbing kicked off on all CDs
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9logfile0.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile0.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile1.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile2.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9standby0.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile3.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile4.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9controlfile0.
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9logfile1.
      	> CELLSRV error simulation: location BLOCKIO_READ_ERR count 1 CD c9datafile0 offset 0 size xx

      2. Test scrubbing kickoff for follow-up schedule:
         turn off IO error simulation:
         - alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[BLOCKIO_READ_ERR] off"

         get current time again and set start time as one week ago:
         - alter cell harddiskscrubstarttime="2016-01-19T21:34:43-08:00"
         wait for 20sec, we should see scrubbing job kicked off on c9datafile0 only:
      	> Begin scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile0.
      	...
      	> Finished scrubbing CellDisk:c9datafile0, scrubbed blocks (1MB):1488, found bad blocks:0
         set start time as one week ago again:
         - alter cell harddiskscrubstarttime="2016-01-19T21:35:43-08:00"
         wait for 20sec, we should see no scrubbing job kicked off this time.

Description: tsagbug24745355.tsc - ASM DISK RESIZE APPEARS TO HANG WHEN OLTP
                           WORKLOAD IS RUNNING

Test flow:
     1. create testing tables for OLTP workload: created three tables with 1000rows
     2. fork 3 oltp workloads and running for 30 mins

Description: tsagbug27438679.tsc - Bug test for 27438679

1. Create an environment with griddisks and also add them to the ASM.
     2. cellcli -e list griddisk attributes name, asmmodestatus, asmdeactivationoutcome
     3. Drop the diskgroup with force option at ASM.
     4. Shutdown the ASM instance
     5. Manually drop the griddisks at cellsrv using "cellcli -e drop griddisk <gdname> force" for all griddisks
     6. Restart the ASM instance
     7. Recreate the griddisks using cellcli with the same name, size etc as in Step-1
     8. Create the diskgroups (with same name)
     9. Manually add the griddisk at ASM.
     10. Check if the griddisk are not auto dropped at ASM (ASM should not autodrop the griddisks)
          - Wait for few seconds and then check sql> select name, state from v$asm_disk;
          - cellcli -e list griddisk attributes name, asmmodestatus, asmdeactivationoutcome
            the attributes "asmmodestatus, asmdeactivationoutcome" of griddisks should be correct with ASM instance

Test tsagbug28716488.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsascbug5.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug28716488.tsc - PREDICATECACHEPUT WAS IDLED FOR OVER 5 MINS LEADING TO CLIENT VRPC TIMEOUT

This test checks for the presence of a race condition due to timezone
      caching. Two jobs are issued simultaneously. The first job caches the
      timezone file, but is forced by the sim event to sleep for one minute
      before completing. The second job should wait for the first job to
      return before completing, but should not reach an error state where it
      times out. If either job returns in < 1 minute, then the timezone
      caching conditions were set up improperly.
     The test steps are as follows:
     1.setup env srdbmsini
     2.set underscore parameter in cellinit.ora
     3.disable offloading for DB instance system
     4.In sql, create a large sample data table with date/time values
     5.Restart cellsrv
     6.Enable simulation event in cellcli: PREDCACHEPUT_TIMEOUT
     7.Open two SQL terminal sessions and invoke it together
     8.If either query takes less than 1 minute or longer than 5 minutes to execute, then the test should fail.

Test tsagbug3.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: oss_testing=1. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsascbug9.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug3.tsc - Test case for bug 9780796 and bug 9151718

Test case for bug 9780796

Cellsrv used to crash with an assert in skgxpStats_RegisterEPID:Failed
     when hostname of a compute node was changed. With fix for this
     bug this should no longer happen.

     Test case is as follows:
     1). Cell, ASM (and DB if needed) are running.
         At this point diskmon would have connected using the
         hostname of the machine where the test is running.

     2). Create $T_WORK/myhostname to have `hostname` appended
         with the domain name
            "reallylongdomainname.us.oracle.com"
         even if the hostname already has a domain name.
         The reason for setting a really long hostname is
         to make sure that cellsrv doesn't crash due to
         bug 9151718.

         Code has been modified to look for this file and if
         present will take precendece over procuring host name
         from the OS.

     3). Kill diskmon. Agent should automatically restart it
         and it should connect to cell with the new hostname
         set in $T_WORK/myhostname

     4). Verify that cellsrv doesn't crash.
         TODO: We could also compare metrics snapshot before
               and after.

     5). Remove $T_WORK/myhostname

     6). Kill diskmon. Agent should automatically restart it
         and it should connect to cell with the actual hostname.

     7). Verify that cellsrv doesn't crash.

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug30495040.tsc - bug test

This bug test validates a new ASM mirror hint parameter to Orion.
     This will allow testing the existing FC functionality which prevents
     caching of any IO not marked as "primary" or "activesecondary".

     It is a functional test fo writeThrough FC, where we try to populate
     FC using an Orion workload with "primary" (which should show FC getting
     populated. The current and default behavior), and compare it to trying
     to populating FC using an Orion workload with a "null" mirror hint, which
     should show FC not getting populated at all.

Test tsagbug30512925.tsc. setup=(none). flags: loop_num=3. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbcsafccachedby.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug30512925.tsc - Run base test with/without asm/db instance

Run base test with/without asm/db instance

1. Setup cell and DB and base table for CC workload.
    2. create writeback flashcache;
    3. Check "list griddisk attributes name, cachingPolicy, cachedBy" after
       sleeping 2 minutes. All griddisks should have cachedBy assigned.
    4. run scan query of the CC table; and check flashcacheContent. Table
       should have ColumnarCachedSize.
    5. alter flashcache all flush;
    6. Check "list griddisk attributes name, cachingPolicy, cachedBy" after
       sleeping 2 minutes. All griddisks should have cachedBy empty.
    7. drop flashcache.
    8. recreate writeback FC.
    9. repeat 3~4.

    Usage: mode - if it is CC2, then will run the bug test with CC workloads
                  and asm/db are up
    Usage:        if it is null, it will not setup asm/db instance
           runtest tsagbug30512925
           runtest tsagbug30512925 mode=CC2

Test Case for bug 30585062

Test Case for bug 30585062, the flows is as below:

     1. setup X6 HC simulation by tsagx6config.tsc
     2. Force predictive failure of m2 device
       $DEBUGCLI -alter -m2 0 -p status -v "PREDFAIL"

Test tsagbug30596196.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: creatdev_file=tsagcfcdef, oss_testing=1, log_file=tsagbug30596196_fake.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug30596196.tsc - TestCases for bug 30596196

TestCases for bug 30596196

This is a new feature in Exadata 20.1 release, which is about postponing
     creating sparse hash table until the first time we create sparse grid
     disk. Sparse hash table takes up about 12 GB on a real cell node. Thus
     itâs possible the creation fails when thereâs no enough memory. The code
     transaction - yichewan_bug_30596196 tries to drop the offload servers
     first to release memory, and then retries the creation. Offload groups
     would be brought back after that. You can have more information here:
           https://orareview.us.oracle.com/84529514
     To prove the correctness of this feature, we add 3 new cases to cover it:
       1. Thereâs enough memory, sparse grid disk creation succeeds at the
          first try, and does not do the recreation
       2. Thereâs little memory, sparse grid disk creation fails again even
          after dropping offload groups
       3. The creation fails at the firs time, but succeeds at the second try

Description: tsagbug31816888.tsc - OOM on MS startup test

Enforce OutOfMemory error by using large persisted metric file
     MS raises OutOfMemory error on startup if it reads the current very large metric file.
     To simulate this, prepare sample metric archive, rename it with current date to mimic the latest file.
     On startup, if MS has the ability to remove this file at OOM state, the file is removed. This may fail
     because JVM could be unstable state at OOM exception. So, I added recheck logic in this test.
     120 sec sleep X 5 , hope this will remove the file after several MS restart.
     Successfull behavior should be MS restart with no OOM by purging the large metric by MS.

Remove the large file on failure

     extents. If cellsrv restarts in the middle, it loses the SSTree info.
     EDS automatically reconnects and re-sends drop file extents requests,
     but it does not resends SSTree. This causes the  drop to fail

Test steps for below bug:
     Bug# 32843838 - PREDICATIVELY FAILED FLASH CAUSES LGWR HANG / APPLICATION BLACKOUTS / INSTANCE CRASH

     (1) create 2 grid disks and create WBFC with 2 flash stores;
         (disable pmemcache/ramcache)
     (2) list cachedBy of grid disks;
     (3) Run concurrent orion small OLTP workload in background, make sure the orion
         testing area is smaller than FC size, so that data would get 100% cached after some time;
     (4) Simulate failureType=predictivefailure on one flash cache store;
     (5) Check celldisk and flashcache status to ensure the flash store is in predicative failure.
     (6) Check cachedBy, there should be no change.
     (7) Check cellsrvstat IO stats delta, all read/write should continue going to FC.
          Number of read hits -- non-zero
          Number of cache writes -- non-zero
          Number of nocache writes -- expected to be 0.
     (8) Un-simulate the failure and re-enable the store.

Test tsagbug33038849.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug33038849.tsc - Test case for bug 33038849

Test case for bug 33038849, code fix - weizhang_ctrlfile_unaligned_write

Test steps for below bug:
     Bug# 33038849 - ENABLING FLASH CACHE CACHING FOR CONTROL FILE HEADERS

     (1) Run orion 100% small ControlFile read workload on 100MB disk region.
         The small read is 1KB, i.e. not 4KB aligned. The small read would
         trigger FC prefetch and populatiion. At the end of workload.
         The data would get 100% cached.
     $ADE_VIEW_ROOT/rdbms/bin/orion -run advanced -type rand -write 0 \
       -filetype Controlfile -testname orion -size_small 1 -size_large 1 \
       -matrix point -num_small 1 -num_large 0 -seed 90338  -duration 30 \
       -disk_end_offset 100M

     Please list the following fast metrics (via cellsrvstat) for reference.
     Number of ctrlfile read cache hit
     Total size of ctrlfile read cache hit (KB)
     Number of ctrlfile read cache miss
     Total size of ctrlfile read cache miss (KB)
     Number of ctrlfile read population           ==> should be non-zero
     Total size of ctrlfile read population (KB)  ==> should be non-zero


     (2) Run orion 100% small ControlFile write workload on 100MB disk region.
         The small write is 1KB, not 4KB aligned. Without fix, the write would
         all go to disk and invalidate cache. With fix, the write would go to cache.
     $ADE_VIEW_ROOT/rdbms/bin/orion -run advanced -type rand -write 100 \
        -filetype Controlfile -testname orion -size_small 1 -size_large 1 \
        -matrix point -num_small 1 -num_large 0 -seed 90338  -duration 30 \
        -disk_end_offset 100M

     Please check the following fast metrics (via cellsrvstat):
     Number of ctrlfile write to cache                ==> should be non-zero
     Total size of ctrlfile write to cache (KB)       ==> should be non-zero
     Number of ctrlfile write bypass cache            ==> should be zero
     Total size of ctrlfile write bypass cache (KB)   ==> should be zero
     Number of ctrlfile nocache write unaligned       ==> should be zero
     Total size of ctrlfile nocache write unaligned (KB) ==> should be zero

     (3) Repeat control file small read in (1). Without fix, there would be
         ctrlfile read cache misses. With fix, all read would get cache hit.
     $ADE_VIEW_ROOT/rdbms/bin/orion -run advanced -type rand -write 0 \
       -filetype Controlfile -testname orion -size_small 1 -size_large 1 \
       -matrix point -num_small 1 -num_large 0 -seed 90338  -duration 30 \
       -disk_end_offset 100M

     Please check the following fast metrics.
     Number of ctrlfile read cache hit           ==> should have non-zero delta
     Total size of ctrlfile read cache hit (KB)  ==> should have non-zero delta
     Number of ctrlfile read cache miss          ==> should have zero delta
     Total size of ctrlfile read cache miss (KB) ==> should have zero delta
     Number of ctrlfile read population          ==> should have zero delta
     Total size of ctrlfile read population (KB) ==> should have zero delta

Test tsagbug33355297.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: oss_testing=1, flash_size=576, num_flash_per_cell=1, OSS_ENABLE_FC_PERSISTENCE=writeback, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cache_flint_only=1, creatdev_file=tsagcfcdef, sysdba='sys/knl_test7@cdb1_pdb1 as sysdba'. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug33355297.tsc - Test case for bug 33355297

bug 33355297 - UNINTENTIONALLY USED PMEMCACHE AFTER ESS UPGRADE

Customer reported that pmemcache got unintentionally used even when
    database has IORM plan pmemcache=off configured.

    If cell got reboot after setting plan pmemcache=off, pmemcache got used
    unintentionally, although PMemCache group dump shows that the group indeed
    has pmemcache=off (i.e. hardMax=0).

    It turns out that the env doesn't have any group with non-zero limit.
    From space management's viewpoint, there is only one default group really used.
    Hence system mistakenly took a fast path (i.e. fccGroupEnabled=false),
    which bypassed IORM limit check during runtime space allocation and
    caused new pmemcache space allocation to sneak in.

    The problem would get resolved automatically if there is IORM plan set/change
    or if there is any workload on any database with non-zero pmemCacheMin
    or pmemCacheLimit or pmemCacheSize within the same cellsrv lifecycle.
    In those code paths, system would auto-fix the in-memory state of whether
    group is enabled.


  The steps to reproduce the issue are:
    1. Create one DB with similar to the other replacement test, create
       for tablespace that contains test table. And disable caching for all other
       system grid disks. Populate the test table with some initial data.
    2. Drop and recreate writethrough pmemcache.
    3. Set DB IORM plan to have "pmemcache=off". List iormplan; list database detail;
       list pluggabledatabase detail ( if it is CDB test).
    4. Perform OLTP query of the test table for 10 mins.
    5. Check DB_PC_BY_ALLOCATED for the database, it is supposed to be 0.
    6. Restart cellsrv ignore redundancy.
    7. Wait for 2 mins.
    8. List iormplan; list database detail; list pluggabledatabase detail
       The pmemCacheSize for the database should be 0.
    9. Repeat 4 - Perform OLTP query of the test table for 10 mins.
    10. Check DB_PC_BY_ALLOCATED for the database.
        Without fix, it is non-zero. With fix, it would be 0.

Description: tsagbug33372595.tsc - Test for bug 33372595

EXASCALE: CELL ROLLING UPGRADE - PERMISSIONS FOR
     /OPT/ORACLE/CELL/CELLSRV/DEPLOY/LOG IS INCORRECT,
     EXPECTED:0770 FOUND:2775

Test steps:
      1. Cleanup the cell - restart services, drop and create cell,
   drop all alerts
      2. Change asm/cell permissions, restart ms
      3. Grep for "Unexpected file ownership or permissions" in alerthistory
      4. Change deploy/log permissions, restart ms
      5. Grep for "Unexpected file ownership or permissions" in alerthistory
      6. Reset to normal permissions, restart ms
      7. Grep for "Unexpected file ownership or permissions" in alerthistory

   With bug 35187540, we are using rpm commands in permissions_check.py to
   help verify files in cell package. The verification is done in two steps:
   (1). Perform a generic check on several import locations. (i.e., OSSCONF)
        and capture any violations.
   (2). Use RPM commands to verify all package files.

   Note that some files or directories might be checked in both steps. In
   these cases, we only count errors reported by step 2 as RPM commands are
   more accuate.

   Additional Testcases:
   (1). Altering permission/ownership of a file which is checked by generic
        rules (step 1), but not owned by RPM (step 2). This is to ensure
        step 1 is working as intended.

        Method:
          create a new file under OSSCONF which violates OSSCONF's generic
          file rules: "root, root, 0600".
          $ touch $OSSCONF/permissions_check_tempfile
          $ chown celladmin:cellusers $OSSCONF/permissions_check_tempfile

   (2). Altering permission/ownership of a file owned by RPM but is not
        checked by generic rules. This is to ensure step 2 is working as
        intended.

        Method:
          Modifying $OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/permissions_check.py (itself)

Description: tsagbug33481285.tsc - test case for bug 33481285:
                           ENABLE OBJECTS TO BE KEPT IN FLASH CACHE WITHOUT A SCAN

This test case has below steps:
     Case 1: for partitioned table
       Step 1: create partitioned table
       Step 2: check that cell_flash_cache is default for all partitions
       Step 3: check size and get object id of each partition
       Step 4: flush flashcache
       Step 5: alter table to keep
       Step 6: check that cachedSize and cachedKeepSize are
               90% - 110% of partition size
     Case 2: for non-partitioned table
       Step 1: create non-partitioned table
       Step 2: check that cell_flash_cache is default
       Step 3: check size and get object id of table
       Step 4: flush flashcache
       Step 5: alter table to keep
       Step 6: check that cachedSize and cachedKeepSize are
               90% - 110% of table size
     Case 3: for IOT overflow mapping table
       Step 1: create IOT overflow mapping table
       Step 2: check that cell_flash_cache is default
       Step 3: check size and object id for each partition
       Step 4: flush flashcache
       Step 5: alter table to keep
       Step 6: check that cachedSize and cachedKeepSize are
               90% - 110% of each partition size
     For Exascale, this test has one test case which is similar to case 2
       Step 1: create non-partitioned table
       Step 2: check that cell_flash_cache is default
       Step 3: check size and get object id of table
       Step 4: flush flashcache and check FlashCache pop keep in cellsrvstat
       Step 5: alter table to keep and check FlashCache pop keep again
       Step 6: check that the change in FlashCache pop keep is
               90% - 110% of table size

Test tsagbug33481452.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: OSS_ENABLE_FC_PERSISTENCE=writeback, OSS_ENABLE_NC_PERSISTENCE=off, creatdev_file=tsagr2def, uniq_dsknames=all. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsafcbug2.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug33481452.tsc - Test for Bug 33481452

1. Have a workload to seed dirty data, orion (random, 100% small write) used.
     2. The test then picks a candidate cacheline through event ? immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_flashcache(dumpdirtylru..)? , using the floc location through dumptranslatedgdaddress.
     3. Simulate the read IO error on the disk selected using cellsrv_simevent[BLOCKIO_READ_ERR] ..
     4. Run another workload to get datasync write jobs to kick in and drain dirty lru list. As the cacheline set for simevent was from dirty lry list, the dkwr will hit IO error when it tries to sync this line.
     5. Verify that this line is hit only once with ? immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_flashcache(dumpcorestats..), where the output looks like
     # numDkwrScrubbedCLs 1
     # numDkwrWriteActivatedCLs 0
     6. The test then turns off the IO error event, and runs the first workload again to write to the cacheline and mark it as active again.
     7. Verify again with dumpcorestats for the following
     # numDkwrScrubbedCLs 1
     # numDkwrWriteActivatedCLs 1

This test verifies that even if enough clients try to connect to
     cellsrv after it has been restarted (with all EGS servers down),
     it will not result in a deadlock in RemoteListener in cellsrv.

     1. Get an ExaScale cluster with no ASM grid disk.

     3. Restart CELLSRV.

     5. Restart MS.
     6. Execute command "cellcli -e list griddisk". It should succeed.

Test tsagbug33734670.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: cc_mode=cc2, enable_columnar_cache=65. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsacfcbug3.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug33734670.tsc - functional test for bug 33734670

When CC2 is populated and next scan hit CC2 I/O error in CC layer, the existing
   logic will return the I/O error back to DB (kcfis), and kcfis will retry a different
   mirror for the read and also notify ASM to check the block on primary mirror. But
   ASMâs check I/O is block I/O, it will read from disk (so it can succeed) and
   also it will not trigger the population for CC2 on the cell. As a result,
   the CC2 on first cell is lost and not rebuilt automatically, the next scan will
   hit a performance degradation since some CC was removed.

   With the fix, upon a CC read I/O error, the cell will retry the I/O again
   through disk and then it will automatically populate the CC2 back to FC so that
   next scan will still benefit from CC2.

   We also support this bug test with cc1 table if cc_mode=cc1

The test steps are:
       1). Setup normal redundancy with writeBack flashcache
       2). Populate CC2 and wait for no IMC pop req.
       3). Scan the table once:  select count(*) from temp;
       4). Query the CC hit count = CC_hits_1
       5). Simulate read I/O error on one of the flash celldisk on first cell by CellCLI:
           alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[BLOCKIO_READ_ERR] err_type=internal,frequency=1,
              count=10, evarg1=FD_01_raw60422"
       6). Scan the table once and stop the simulation event:
       7). alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[BLOCKIO_READ_ERR] off"
       8). Wait for no IMC pop req, and then query the CC hit count again, CC_hits_2,
           this hit count should be less than CC_hits_1 as some CC read hits I/O error,
           no need to check the hit value in this step as it is depending on how many
           I/O error on FC, it is hard to control.
       9). Scan the table once again and query the CC hit count again, CC_hits_3,
           this time CC_hits_3 should be very close to CC_hits_1 (as CC2 should be repopulated
           along with previous scan, without the fix, this CC2 hit count would be similar to CC_hits_2),
           we can tolerate delta +-2 for the CC hit count check.

Test tsagbug33998880.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: (none). platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug33998880.tsc - Test for bug 33998880

Test for bug 33998880 - in this bug, when EGS followers are restarted
     for many times, the threads in the EGS leader get stuck in RemoteCellMgr
     driver loop, and we see a Raft eviction.

Test Steps:
     1) Set up an exascale stack
     2) Get EGS servers configuration (Leader and followers)
     3) In a loop of 100, restart both EGS followers
     4) Get EGS servers configuration (Leader and followers)
     5) Compare initial and final configuration - leader must remain the same

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug34376468.tsc - Test for Bug 34376468

Bug 34376468 - INCREASED LIBCELL TRACING IN RFS TRACE FILES AFTER 19.14 RDBMS UPGRADE
    Steps:
     (1) Setup DG
     (2) enable write IO latency event
        CellCLI> alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[BLOCKIO_WRITE_LAT] \
              err_type=internal, frequency=1"
     (3) check RFS process whether it is generating outlier summary for redo IO
          It should not generate outlier summary.
     (4) check regular log write is generating outlier summary.
          It should generate the outlier summary.
     (5) Now enable log_write outlier in  RFS process. Once it is enabled,
          we should see outlier summary in RFS trace file.
     (6)  disable write IO latency.
         alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[BLOCKIO_WRITE_LAT] off";

Test Steps -
     1. Perform stackup - We have 3 EGS servers.
     2. Let us say EGS A is the leader.
     3. We shutdown all EGS servers.
     4. We startup EGS C and B. On startup, we should make sure that none of
        the alert logs of EGS B and EGS C print out that EGS A is the leader
        since it is dead.
     5. There will be a new election, either B or C will win. Again, we
        should confirm this from the alert logs that either of EGS B or
        EGS C became the leader.

Test tsagbug34952866.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: nflint=1. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug34952866.tsc - test to do I/Os on QLC disks

This test attempts to catch block corruptions when I/O is done to
     QLC disks. The test creates a fake DB, sets low iorm limit to queue I/Os,
     and then run an Orion workload with large writes. In case of I/O going
     to wrong celldisk, there would be an assert in cellsrv that was
     added by  aksshah_bug-34952866

With X10M EF, 2 QLC celldisks share the same DiskIOSched object as they
    belong to a single physical device. We had a bug in the DiskIOSched code
     where we returned an IO back to celldisk layer but the IO belonged to
     the peer celldisk. This IO is then issued to the wrong block IO
     context resulting in the wrong data and data corruption issues.

Description: tsagbug34978498.tsc - Test to cover bug- 34978498

This test is to make sure the metrics collection thread is able to
     function well when there is a space problem on ROOT folder inside a
     compute node. Steps are:
    1) create some dummy metrics files under $OSSCONF/metrics folder
    2) create /scratch folder then create a huge file using "fallocate**"
       on /scratch folder
    3) make sure / folder space exceeds 85%, but not too full, like around 90%
    4) create some dummy metrics files under $OSSCONF/metrics folder
    5) make sure all the metrics files are deleted
    6) make sure "list metriccurrent" can work
    7) manually remove the problematic file from 2)
    8) Check space full alert and space full resolved alert in alerthistory

Test tsagbug35002515.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsacc2qm.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug35002515.tsc - test case for bug 35002515
     This crash happned at decreasing myAutoQuarantinedPDBs counter
     in cdbObj link at dropping "DB IMC POP" quarantine. This counter
     was not incremented for "DB IMC POP" quarantine event.
     But cdb link was created by other quarantine incident.

     This test case recreates the steps that causes the crash. Namely,
     we create 2 "SQL PLAN" quarantines and 2 "DISK REGION IMC POP"
     quarantines and lead to" DB IMC POP" quarantine. We want to test
     that we do not get the ORA-600, QMDBObject: dropMyAutoQuarantinedPDBs
     when we drop the "DB IMC POP" quarantine.

This test has the following steps:
     Step 1: update cellinit.ora with _cell_qm_db_imc_threshold=2
     Step 2: create test table
     Step 3: run CC2 query with CCPOP_CELLOFLSRV_DEATH simulation
     Step 4: drop "DISK REGION" quarantines
     Step 5: create Escalated quarantine by runing workload
     Step 6: drop the escalated quarantine

Test tsagbug35008165.tsc. setup=(none). flags: num_cells=4. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexaclddropadd3_db.
Suites: EXAC_REGRESS, EXAC_VES.
Description: tsagbug35008165.tsc - Check cell offline time in 4 cell env

This script tests for cell offline time in 4 cell env
     for bug-35008165

Test steps:
       1 : Setup 4 cell env with db workload and randomly select
           3 cells
       2 : Drop the first cell
       3 : Wait for rebalance to start then make second cell
           unreachable
       4 : Sleep for 5 minutes
       5 : Make second cell reachable again
       6 : Wait for disks of second cell to come online
       7 : Add the dropped cell back to storagepool
       8 : Wait for rebalance to start and then make third cell
           unreachable
       9 : sleep for 5 minutes
      10 : Make third cell reachable again
      11 : Calculate time taken to make cell offline
      12 : Wait for disks of third cell to come online

LRGs: (none).

Description: tsagbug35043649.tsc - Test case for bug 35043649

bug 35043649 - WITH FC MAXSIZE, CC UNABLE TO GROW

1) setup 2G FC and a cdb with two pdbs, then setting IORM plan
        with flashcachesize=900MB for CDB, each PDB limit is 437MB.
     2) create lineitem table in each pdb and another OLTP table in pdb2.
        LINEITEM is 600+MB.
        OLTP table is 400M (larger than 50% of PDB FC limit).
     3) Perform CC scan workload in PDB1, so that PDB1 is populated with DW
        data. DW usage should be close to the PDB1 FC limit since there is
        no OLTP usage.
     4) Perform OLTP read workload in PDB2, so that PDB2 is populated
        with OLTP data. OLTP usage should be close to the PDB2 FC limit.
     5) Perform CC scan workload in PDB2. DW should be able to replace OLTP.
        OLTP usage below 50% OLTP reservation should not be replaced.
        DW should be able to use the remaining 50% quota.
        We should see CC hits.

Description: tsagbug35140650_x11.tsc - Functional Test for Bug 35140650 - x11 version

Functional Test for Bug 35140650 - x11 version
     Developer Txn : jiayawan_bug-35140650

Test needs to verify that we are not able to simulate disk failure
    on all system drives at the same time. Doing so (simulating failure
    on all system disks) will cause the system to go down and hard to
    recover from it.

    For X8 and older platforms, instead of flash, we use harddisks. We
    pick any two disks to fail, and the second failure should not be allowed.

    In case of only two physicaldisk in compute node, when we fail one
    pd then we need to wait for sapre rebuilding after cancelling failed pd.

       Bug 37914527 - NOT ABLE TO FAIL PHYSICALDISK B AFTER SIMULATING
              AND UN-SIMULATING FAILURE ON PHYSICALDISK A

Test tsagbug35315393.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: sage_mirror_mode=high. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexacldegs12.
Suites: EXAC_CORE, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagbug35315393.tsc - Test for fix for BUG 35315393

The following test covers two scenarios where Simulation event is set on EGS leader and
     validating that the Rebalance completes successfully while the Cellsrv behaves as expected

     In Scenario 1 - New Disk Case
     1. Move a disk to dead state.
     2. Once EGS drop forces the disk, we simulate the assert event:
        'before_format_persist' on EGS leader.
     3. Bring the dead disk back and wait for EGS leader to go crash due to the event.
     4. As the new EGS leader is elected and REBALANCE starts, validate that cellsrv doesnot
        hang/crash with ORA-00600[EgsConcurCtrl:: UpdateOngoingMap:request not found for DRAIN]

     In Scenario 2 - returning Disk Case
     1. Move the disk to dead state and wait for it to be FORCE DROPPED.
     2. Simulate a delay event 'before_format_ioctl' on EGS leader.
     3. Add the dead disk back and move it to Missing state.
     4. Bring back the disk to Online state and then simulate disk failure.
     5. Bring back the disk to Online state.
     6. This will kick in REBALANCE and we validate that cellsrv doesnot crash due to
        ORA-00600[EgsConcurCtrl:: UpdateOngoingMap: request not found for DRAIN]

Test to be added in lrgdbcsaexacldegs12

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug35318878.tsc - Functional test for BUG 35318878

1. Manually trigger a kernel panic by running: echo c > /proc/sysrq-trigger .
      2. The node will reboot. And once it's back, there should be a new directory under the crashfile directory. Wait until MS compresses it, which might take about 5 mins after MS starts up.
      3. Decompress the final tar file and leave the , and delete the core file in the extracted directory (the one with hundred of MBs and ending in vmcore). Leave the original tar file at the same time.
      4. Restart MS, wait until MS compresses the crashfile directory again.
      5. The original tar file should remain untouched, while the extracted directory gets compressed to a new tar, whose name is identical to the original tar file except that it has a suffix starting from 1 to differentiate.
      6. List the content of the 2 tars. The original one should contain the core file while the new one doesn't.

Test tsagbug35572071.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: nflint=1, sysdba='sys/knl_test7@cdb1_pdb1 as sysdba'. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsafcbug2.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug35572071.tsc - Bug test for 35572071

Bug 35572071 - EXADATA: LIBCELL DOES NOT ALLOW RDMA READ VIA IPCDAT AFTER A CELL IS BACK ONLINE
     1). Set up a test with 2 cellsrvs
     2). Set up a DB workload that uses RDMA. The table should be large enough to span
         multiple AUs (>>4MB ), but should be small enough to fit in the XRMemCache of
         both cellsrvs (default is 200MB of XRMemCache each, so table should be less than 400M)
     3). Verify that all IOs (or large proportion 99%) are going through RDMA. This can be done
          with the existing RDBMS stats.
     4). offline and online the cell
      inactive griddisks on the cell
      restart cell
      activate griddisks on the cell
     5). Wait for XRMemCache to get populated again. This may take a few minutes
     6). Verify that after the warmup step above, all IOs are again going through RDMA

  Comparing the ratio between "cell single block physical read: xrmem cache" and "cell single block physical read: RDMA"
  is enough. (In Qian's case, that ratio was ~99% RDMA/1% non-RDMA before the cell offline/online,
  and afterward she was seeing ~83% RDMA/17% non-RDMA in her 6 cell setup).
  EVENT                                                            TOTAL_WAITS
  ---------------------------------------------------------------- -----------
  cell single block physical read                                            1
  cell single block physical read: RDMA                                     11
  cell single block physical read: xrmem cache                               6
  cell single block physical read: flash cache                              35

Test tsagbug35769438.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: OSS_ENABLE_FC_PERSISTENCE=writeback, OSS_ENABLE_NC_PERSISTENCE=off, creatdev_file=tsagr2def, uniq_dsknames=all. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsafcbug2.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug35769438.tsc - Test for Bug 35769438

1. Perform disk writes to fill up most of FC ~80%
     2. Wait for data sync to kick in until amount dirty is below threshold, and stabilize
     3. Perform disk writes to disjoint set ~45% size of FC
     4. 2nd workload should be able to quickly reuse the data synced cache lines from workload 1
     5. Wait for data sync to kick in and stabilize
     6. Check how much synced/unsynced dirty cachelines we have

     With the bug throttling disk writer from being able to repurpose data synced cache lines
     the overall effect is that we are constantly in a state where OLTP AUX is under pressure
     forcing almost all cache lines to disk writer for aging writes
     Only after worklod is fully complete, we are able to perform most of the aging writes
     for replenishing the AUX, but now we end up over replenishing the AUX
     which leaves tFC with very little dirty cachelines left in FC

     With the patch, the repurposing is able to provide cache lines to the 2nd workload
     Ultimately, there's no exessive replenishment of OLTP AUX, and thus after the second
     workload we should still see handful of dirty cache lines. (Test specifically checks for > 30%)

Test tsagbug35871582.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug35871582.tsc - Test for BUG 35871582

Bug 35871582 fixes a race condition that may happen when dropping a griddisk
     and altering a griddisk on the same celldisk. Without the fix, the alter
     operation may return a "corrupt metadata" error even though the metadata is fine.
     1. Create 1 non-pooldisk and 1 pooldisk on the same celldisk.
        Create 2 other pooldisks on different celldisks.
     2. Set drop griddisk delay simulation ("DROPGD_DELETE_ENTRY_DELAY") to reliably
        trigger race condition.
     3. Drop non-pooldisk.
     4. Create storagepool with pooldisks, which will alter the griddisk metadatas.
        - Without fix: Get corrupt metadata error in traces, storagepool force drops
                       the pooldisk on same celldisk as non-pooldisk.
        - With fix: No error messages, all pooldisks in storagepool are online

Description: tsagbug35960426.tsc - Bug test for BUG 35960426

When celltest is run on an incident file that contains XrMEM CC2 (with a buffer >1MB),
     Celltest fails with the following error: POFC_processIMCPopMsg_invalidCCPopMode.
     This is because celltest did not have the capability to handle CC buffers > 1MB.
     This has now been fixed. Thus, we want to create a functional test that crashes the
     XrCC population and generates an incident file with a buffer that is >1MB. We then
     want to run celltest on this incident file and ensure that it completes without throwing
     an error, thus confirming the fact that celltest is now able to handle Population buffers > 1MB.

Test tsagbug36006239.tsc. setup=(none). flags: creatdev_file=tsagccdef. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsascbug18.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug36006239.tsc - Bug test for Bug 36006239 and Bug 35548952

Functional Test for Bug 36006239 and Bug 35548952
     Detailed steps:
       1. Check cellsrvstat for all 3 cells. We want to record the values for âFlashCache pop requestsâ and âXRmemCache incr touch count reqsâ.
       2. Create several large tables (several hundred MB at least).
       3. Simulate a failure for all the regular datafiles on cell 1.
       4. Run a workload to generate many ramcache/FC pop ioctls. In my experience, populating 3 tables with ~50MB should be enough.
       5. Check the cellsrvstat for all 3 cells.
            a. Cell 1 should not have any change in âFlashCache pop requestsâ or âXRmemCache incr touch count reqsâ
            b. Cell 2 and cell 3 should see these stats increase.
            c. The sum of âFlashCache pop requestsâ on cell 2 + cell 3 should be 20 â 40% of the sum of âXRmemCache incr touch count reqsâ on cell 2 + cell 3 in case of exadata and 15 - 55% in case of Exascale.
       6. End the failure simulation on cell 1.
       7. Run another workload to generate ramcache/FC pop ioctls.
       8. Check the cellsrvstat for cell 1.
            a. Cell 1 should see an increase in âFlashCache pop ioctlsâ but not âXRmemCache incr touch count ioctlsâ.

      Orareview: https://orareview.us.oracle.com/135308152
      Owner email: chad.hayen@oracle.com

Test script accepts 2 boolean parameters:
         1. skip_big_table (TRUE|FALSE): If True skip populating big tables for test (Default: FALSE).

Test tsagbug36015718.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: OSS_ENABLE_FC_PERSISTENCE=writeback, OSS_ENABLE_NC_PERSISTENCE=off, creatdev_file=tsagr2def, uniq_dsknames=all. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsafcbug2.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug36015718.tsc - Test for Bug 36015718

1. Perform OLTP small writes to fill up FC ~50%
     2. Wait for Data Sync to kick in and have ~50% synced cache lines
     3. Disable Data Sync
     4. Perform additional disjoint OLTP small writes
        to fill up additional ~20%. These are unsynced. We do 20% so that
        we don't prematuraly deplete the AUX and trigger replenishment
     5. Perform OLTP reads on disjoint set for >100% of FC space
        to cause AUX depletion
     6. Check that majority of replenished cache lines came from
        synced cache lines rather than unsynced

     We want to ensure that synced cache lines get priority for disk writer processing

     With the bug, we will see roughly similar amounts of both synced and unsynced
     cache lines that got replenished

     With the patch, we should see replenishment targets mostly synced cache lines

Test tsagbug36101321.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: sage_mirror_mode=normal, oss_failgroup=failalldbdg, oss_auto_manage_disks=true, debugcli=1. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsamsbug40.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug36101321.tsc - Test case for bug 36101321

Bug 36101321 - EF CLUSTER - NO AUTOMATIC DROP/REBALANCE ON ASM AFTER FLASH DISK FAILED

This test covers 2 cases:

   1. Removing/Adding Flash disk
     i.   Connect to cell2
     ii.  Record the grid disks that are cached by c9FLASH0
     iii. Shut down services
     iv.  Remove a flash disk
     v.   Start up services in the order of "rs-ms-cellsrv"
     vi.  Clean-up: Recreate the flash disk

   2. Moving disk file (failing physical disk)
     i.   Connect to cell2
     ii.  Pick a test hard disk, and record its serial number and
          device name  (which is also its fake disk file path).
     iii. Shut down services
     iv.  Move the disk file datafile0 outside $OSS_DEVDIR
     v.   Set parameters "_disk_last_powercycle_time_limit=1" and
          "_cell_disk_fail_list=<physicalDiskID>" in cellinit.ora
     vi.  Start up services in the order of "rs-ms-cellsrv"
     vii. Clean-up: move back disk file datafile0 back
          to $OSS_DEVDIR and cancel the failure simulation

Bug 36149249 - ESCS-PP1: DATA HARD DISKS ENTERED CONFINEMENT STATUS

     Test Steps:

      2. Save the copy of the below original files in directory
         $OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/hwadapter/diskadp/harddisk/

         with original which is saved in step-2)
      9. Again check the disk status, it should move to failed state.
         If not check periodically every 1 minute for 10 times.
     10. After getting disk status as "failed". unsimulate the failed disk

Test tsagbug36409525.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: OSS_ENABLE_FC_PERSISTENCE=writeback, OSS_ENABLE_NC_PERSISTENCE=off, creatdev_file=tsagr2def, uniq_dsknames=all. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsafcbug2.
Suites: (none).
Description: bug36409525.tsc - Test for Bug 36409525

1. Drop FC
     2. Populate test region with data version 1
     3. Enable write hang simulation
     4. Issue write with data version 2
     5. Create FC while write is hung
     6. After write is done, ensure that the next read is version 2

     Test ensures that FC correctly handles writes that are issued
     prior to bootstrap.

     In the bug we saw that a population read can land right after
     FC creation before the outstanding write lands. The write then only
     lands on disk and not cache as the write is not fully tracked.
     This led to stale data in FC.

Test tsagbug36457966.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: file_dest1='+'datafile. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug36457966.tsc - Test for bug 36457966

During smart scan, when we are using large metadata feature, we have a âgold-copyâ
shared metadata and all threads performing smart scan take a sparse clone metadata.
This shared+cloned metadata usually help save memory usage during smart scan.
But there are some queries whose metadata does not benefit from this shared+cloned
metadata approach.  When we detect that a given shared+clone metadata is inefficient
for a query, we disable the shared+cloned metadata feature for that specific query.

While cleaning up the shared metadata for an inefficient query, we have a race that is
leading to the assert.

ORA-00600: internal error code, arguments: [PMShared::deallocateMemoryForMetadata_clones],
[0x14A4482C0], [7], [], [], [], [], [], [], [], [], []

Test case for lower level flash cache touch count increment when
     blocks are cached in XRMemCache and accessed via SKGXP.

Test steps:

        on 10MB disk region. 10MB region should be cached by both
        FlashCache and XRMemCache.
     3. Reset stats.
     4. Repeat the small read workload on 10MN disk region.
        All the reads get served from XRMemCache.
     5. Verify XRMemCache issues touch count increment requests to
        FlashCache. And all the FlashCache touch count increment requests
        succeed, which indicate all the disk regions are cached in
        FlashCache as well.
