Test tsagbug36616063.tsc. setup=xblockini. flags: iscsi=true. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug36616063.tsc - Test cases for bug 36622685 and 36616063

For testing fix against bug 36622685 what we want to verify
     is that when there is a long running backup job and there
     is a reconfiguration event and sending signals to suspend
     ongoing operation, we do not mistakenly take an active long running job
     as a dead one and assert. So, the steps to verify this would be:
       1. create a volume vol1 of size 10G on v1
       2. create snapshot snap1 of vol1
       3. set event BSW_BKP_CREATE_DELAY_SIM and create backup bkp1 of snap1.
          This will delay the backup creation for 10 minutes
       4. after 9 minutes, turn off the event simulation and restart the BSM
          to trigger a reconfiguration event.
       5. Expect the workload to continue and no assert should happen.

    For bug 36616063, event simulation to simulate a scenario where in bsw
    a vip install job is not added to vip run queue and is directly replying to bsm,
    to test this we will:
       1. set the new event simulation to simulate a vip incarnation mismatch on bsw (once only)
       2. restart bsm to trigger a reconfiguration event
       3. Expect no assert happening.

Description: tsagbug36760261.tsc - Test for Bug-36760261

The test includes the following testcases
Test Case-1:
1. Create storagepool with 3 cells
2. Set the state of the disk pd00_simcell00 to INACCESSIBLE_UNKNOWN
3. 20 seconds later, set the state of the disk pd00_simcell1 to INACCESSIBLE_UNKNOWN
4. 20 seconds later, set the state of those two disks to DEAD
   This should trigger a rebalance.
5. Recreate those two disks with ACCESSIBLE_GOOD
   This should trigger a rebalance. Wait for rebalance to complete.
Test Case-2:
1. Create storagepool with 3 cells
2. Set the state of the disk pd00_simcell00 to INACCESSIBLE_UNKNOWN
3. 20 seconds later, set the state of disk pd00_simcell00 to DEAD
   This should trigger a rebalance
4. At about the same time, set the state of the disk pd00_simcell1 to INACCESSIBLE_UNKNOWN
5. 20 seconds later, set the state of pd00_simcell1 to DEAD
   Rebalance should continue to run.
6. Recreate those two disks with ACCESSIBLE_GOOD
   This should trigger a rebalance. Wait for rebalance to complete

Bug 36766407 - [ESCS-SCL1/SJC1] STUCK EDV THREAD ON KVM
     COMPUTE RESULTING IN OSSTLS_HANDSHAKE FAILURE

     The goal of this unit test is to simulate a TLS handshake hang in EDV's
     EGSLIB shared thread, and make sure the thread can sync with the primary
     thread for the latest TLS certificate, and move forward to do the next
     round of handshake after the hang.

     Test steps:
       1. oratst -d xblockini ledvsetup=true
       2. Use escli to set certDurationInMins to 20 minutes
       3. Shutdown EDV
       4. Shutdown DBRS, so RS won't kill EDV due to our hang simulation
       5. Append "libcell.tls_handshake_hang_sim hang_in_min=25"
          to _cell_client_event of the EDV's cellinit.ora
       6. Start up EDV directly(Don't use RS, since RS will kill the EDV
          if it hangs for more than 5 minutes)
       7. Check and make sure the hang simulation is enabled in one of the
          EDV's EGSLIB shared thread.
       8. Wait for 25 minutes, so the hang simulation completes. Check and
          make sure the share thread got the latest TLS cert from EGSLIB
          primary.

Description: tsagbug36830064.tsc - 36830064 - ADDING CELLCLI EVENT TO PURGE ALL CC FROM FLASHCACHE

This test has below steps:
     Step 1: set up table and populate CC2
     Step 2: check that columnar_cache_size is non-zero
     Step 3: Purge FlashCache CC
     Step 4: check that columnar_cache_size is 0

PurgeCC will purge columnar_cache_size for both Flashcache and XRMEMcache
     purgeXrCC will only purge columnar_cache_size in XRMEMcache
     The command is of the below sytax:
  alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_columnarcache \
  ('purgeCC/purgeXrCC', 'single', 'clusterName.vaultId.cdbid.dbid', \
   'table_space_number', 'objid')"
   Test case 1.1: Purge all for FCCC and XRCC
   Test case 1.2: Purge all for XRCC only
   Test case 2.1: Purge single object for FCCC and XRCC
   Test case 2.2: Purge single object for XRCC only
   Test case 3.1: Wildcard test, purge all objects in a PDB for FCCC and XRCC
   Test case 3.2: Wildcaed test, purge all objects in a CDB for FCCC and XRCC
     For wild card function, the wildcard must follow a top-down hierarchy:
     if the higher hierarchy has a wildcard the lower hierarchy parameter
     must have it too. The hierarchy is: cdb->dbid->vaultID->tsn->objid.

Description: tsagbug36855672_1.tsc - Non deterministic test for BUG-36855672

1. srdbmsini.tsc oss_columnar_cache=true
      2. create table with 17 columns
          - create table t1710k(col1 number, col2 number, col3 number, col4 number, col5 number,col6 number,col7 number,col8 number,col9 number,
            col10 number,col11 number,col12 number, col13 number,col14 number,col15 number,col16 number,col17 number);
      3. Insert 2000 rows of data
         Follow further steps from Notes.

From MinJi Kim :

    4. Set the following in RDBMS in sqlplus (put all smart scan into passthru mode from timezone upgrade,
    and disable certain passthru optimization to exercise the code change as much as possible)

    alter session set events='27605 trace name context forever, level  0x00000002';
    alter session set "_kcfis_cell_passthru_dataonly" = FALSE;
    alter session set "_kcfis_dump_corrupt_block" = FALSE;

    5. Set the following for cellsrv (With 10% chance, we will declare a block corrupt.
    And with 50% chance, we will fail to allocate output buffer.)

    alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[PRED_BLOCK_CORRUPT] frequency=10";
    alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[PRED_DESTBUF_ALLOC_FAIL] frequency=2";

    6. Then, run several smart scan queries in a loop.  Let's make sure that some queries are less selective than others
    (i.e. permissive predicate with a sum(column)).

    There is a very small chance that the query will fail with ORA-1578, but I am hoping that it will be extremely rare.

Bug 36908108 - EDSMGR TAKING TOO MUCH MEMORY
     A new parameter is added in EDS server _cell_edsmgr_keep_seconds
       that sets how long each item pushed to EdsMgr should be kept for after
       it's last access.

      7. Check that size= value is three digits long
      8. Check that EdsMgr fixed size allocator is not used
      9. Repeat step 1 - 7 except in 1. make parameter now 10
          seconds _cell_edsmgr_keep_seconds=10 and in 7,
          check that size= is 0 instead of triple digit

Test tsagbug36952541.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: cdb=true, cdb_dd=pdbs_across_cdbs, num_dbs=2, oss_asm_sec=true, clusterid=ASMClusterName, sysdba='sys/knl_test7@cdb1_pdb1 as sysdba'. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsascbug4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug36952541.tsc - Testcase for bug 36952541

Testcase for bug 36952541

   1. Set up 2 CDB/ASM+OSS env with ASM-scoped security enabled.
   2. shutdow all dbs/asm and restart cellsrv to get a fresh state in cellsrv for testing
   3. Startup asm and cdb1, run some oltp workload in cluster1.CDB1.
      By this time, cell would have created DBClient with clientName='cluster1' and PD1.
      cell would have created ClientDescriptor with clientName=CLUSTER1:CDB1, and got PD1
      from DBClient-cluster1.
      XRMemCache would have created cache group for cluster1 and registering MR using PD1.
   4. Stop DB and ASM for cluster1.
   5. Update griddisk availableTo to empty.
   6. Reset key of cluster1 to empty.
      Without fix, cell would remove the DBClient with clientName='cluster1' from DBClientDirectory.
      With fix, cell keeps the DBClient with clientName='cluster1' in DBClientDirectory wiht key update.
   7. Assign key1 to asmcluster cluster1.
      Without fix, cell would create  DBClient with clientName='cluster1'.
      With fix, cell would update existing DBClient with clientName='cluster1 with new key.
   8. Update griddisk availableTo cluster1
   9. Start up ASM. Create cluster1.CDB2, and run some oltp workload.
     Without fix, DBClient with clientName='cluster1' would use PD2.
     cell would have created ClientDescriptor with clientName=CLUSTER1:CDB2,
     and got PD2 from DBClient-cluster1. Since cache group for cluster1 uses PD1,
     and client descriptor CLUSTER1:CDB2 uses PD2, WC_REM_ACCESS_ERR is reported.
     With fix, DBCleint with  clientName='cluster1' would continue using PD1.
     CDB2 can have RDMA access without problem.

Testcase for bug 36952541

Description: tsagbug37140353.tsc - Testcase for the test bug fix 37140353 change.

Testcase for the test bug fix 37140353 change.
    Here are the test steps:
    - create a volume, a snapshot and a backup
    - set BSM crash sim event on final state of BsmCreateVolJob
    - cellcli -e "alter cell bsmEvents='ebs_simevent[BST_SRV_CRASH_SIM] evarg1=58,evarg2=20'"
    - send the following commands in parallel
    - restore bkp to new volume
    - restore bkp to new volume
    - sleep for 0.5 sec and delete bkp so that backup is not deleted before
    restoring volume
    - the restored volume will be created and backup can not be deleted till the
    restored volume creation is completed.
    - Keep deleting backup and bkp will be deleted after few trials(within 120
     seconds)
    - do lsvolumebackup, bkp is not present (this is an error since other volume is
                                        waiting to use the bkp for restore)
    - delete the snap
    - delete the parent volume
    - restart BSM (ORA)

Description: tsagbug37146355.tsc - Test for bug 37146355

37146355 - EXADATA 24AI AND RDBMS_23AI: CELLOFLSRV CORE DUMP WITH ORA-700
     [UPDATECRYPTOINFO: FILE CRYPTO KEY CHANGE]
     Problem
     When we create a tablespace again using same datafile after dropping, writes attempt to use
     this stale key(of previous tablespace) to decrypt the IO buffer and update the SI summary. Since the
     buffer becomes junk after decrypted with the wrong key, this could lead to
     a set of undeterministic behaviours

     Test
     1- Create table space with encryption
     2- Drop and create same tablespace again

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug37206941.tsc - Test case for bug 37206941

Test 1:
     0: Select a random disk (say disk in Slot-7) which starts with the normal state.
     1: Backup the below files in 2 different directries (say /root/orig. and /root/mod):
         $OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/hwadapter/diskadp/harddisk/sn1/get_cfgdsply_output.sh
   $OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/hwadapter/diskadp/harddisk/sn1/get_lsscsi_output.sh
   $OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/hwadapter/diskadp/harddisk/sn1/get_pdlist_output.sh
     2: Go to /mod directory and run the above scripts and save them in separate files in the same directory:
         ./root/mod/get_cfgdsply_output.sh > cfgdsply_output
   ./root/mod/get_lsscsi_output.sh  > lsscsi_output
         ./mod/get_pdlist_output.sh > pdlist_output
         ./mod/get_pdlist_output.sh > pdlist_output_foreign
     3: Open the above output files and modify as below:
        cfgdsply_output: Search for the block which contains Slot Number: 7 and
                         delete the entire block for this slotNumber
        lsscsi_output: remove the 2 lines of Key: 7    devicename:/dev/xyz
        pdlist_output_foreign:
           Search for the block which contains Slot Number: 7 and update the below 2 lines as below:
           1. Firmware state: Unconfigured(good), Spun Up   (FROM:   Firmware state: Online, Spun Up)
           2. Foreign State: Foreign   (FROM: Foreign State: None)
        pdlist_output: Search for the block which contains Slot Number: 7 and
                       delete the entire block for this slotNumber
     4: Open the below script files and add the line at the beginning of it as below:
         get_cfgdsply_output.sh:
            echo "$(cat /root/mod/cfgdsply_output)"
            exit 0
   get_lsscsi_output.sh:
      echo "$(cat /root /mod/lsscsi_output)"
	      exit 0
         get_pdlist_output.sh:
      if [ -e /root /mod/tempfile ]
      then
        echo "$(cat /root /mod/pdlist_output)"
      else
        touch /root /mod/tempfile
	echo "$(cat /root /mod/pdlist_output_foreign)"
            fi
            exit 0
     5: replace the original script files with the above modified script files :
   cd /root/mod/
         yes | cp -f get_* $OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/hwadapter/diskadp/harddisk/sn1/
     6: wait for 2 mins and then check the physicaldisk status and it should be either
         in power cycle state or failed. (The disk should eventually end in failed state)
     7: Replace back the orginal script files backedup in /root/orig and then reenable the
         physicaldisk in slot-7 back to normal(Not necessary but just to cleanup)
         cd /root/orig/
         yes | cp -f get_* $OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/hwadapter/diskadp/harddisk/sn1/
         cellcli -e alter physicaldisk <pdid in slot-7> reenable force

Test tsagbug37234462.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0, cell_with_xrmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug37234462.tsc - orion test case for bug 37234462

Test case for scan caching

Test steps:
     1. Create FC of 500MB
     2. Run OLTP write workload to populate FC with 300MB of OLTP data
     3. Run the following workloads in parallel to simulate mixed
        SCAN/OLTP workload
     (1) Run scan on the same 300MB region that was previously cached via
         OLTP with orion delay 20ms. This is to simulate cold scan to
         existing cached data.
     (2) Run another hot scan on a different 300MB region in parallel
         with orion delay 10ms. This is to simulate hot scan that brings
         in new cached data.
     (3) Run oltp read on different 200MB region in parallel to introduce
         new hot oltp data.
     4. Check cold and hot scan cached size. The expectation is that
        hot scan should be able to replace colder oltp data and cache
        more data than cold scan.

Test tsagbug37234542.tsc. setup=(none). flags: sysdba='sys/knl_test7@cdb1_pdb1 as sysdba'. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug37234542.tsc - testcase for bug 37234542

The bug seems to be a latent problem but somehow was discovered only
     recently.  The root cause of the problem is, when smart scan is
     submitting IO, the disk is still online but once the IO submitted the
     disk is dropped.  In some cases of IO submission failure, Cache (IO)
     layer doesn't clean up some state (i.e. JobIOContext) and leaves it,
     which leads to an assert.

     The simulation event, PRED_INVALID_GDNUM, sets the disk address to an
     invalid value, causing the above problem where Cache layer cannot find
     a valid disk during smart IO operation.

testcase for bug 37234542

This bug addresses the case where a cell runs into some unrecoverable
     problem and can never come back. In such a case, we want to permanently
     drop the cell along with its disks
     To address this, we now have a mechanism inside EGS to permanently drop
     a cell, if the cell has been unreachable to EGS for more than some
     amount of time - 3 days, by default. Admin still has to run "alter
     storagepool reconfig" to effect the permanent drop.

Test tsagbug37352143.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0, cell_with_xrmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: Test case for bug 37352143: unset nocache bit for cachelines replenished
     by iorm violation

Test steps:
     1. setup cell, create flash cache in writeback mode with size = 288M
     2. create fake databases
     3. run workload1: oltp read/write workload to dbid = 0(default flash
        cache group) with disk region1 = 300M. It should occupy whole flash
        cache with clean/dirty cachelines
     4. create softmax flash cache group with min set to 270M
     4. run workload 1 and
        workload2: oltp read/write workload to dbid = 6(new softmax flash
        cache group) with disk region2 = 300M. It should trigger the new
        softmax group replenishment since it cannot get enough avaliable
        cachelines to satisfy is flashcachemin.
     5. after both workload finished, check:
        5.1 numNoCacheEvict = 0
            with the new fix, during cacheline replenishment, the evicted
            cache headers should not have nocache bit set when replenishing
            from iorm violated group(default flash cache group)
        5.2 size of new fcg(dbid = 6) > flashcachemin(270M)
            without nocache bit set, the new force flush bit should still
            help those dkwr cachelines be picked as target of aging write
        5.3 numCLForceFlushIssued  > 0
            numCLForceFlushSkipped > 0
            numCLForceFlushDone > 0
            with the new fix, cachelines be evicted due to iorm policy
            violation should have force flush bit set(numCLForceFlushIssued  > 0)
            Since workload1 was concurrently running when fc replenished
            cachelines, we expect to see some cachelines in dkwr with force
            flush bit set have its bit cleared due to cache hit
            (numCLForceFlushSkipped > 0). However, eventually, due to background
            replenishment, we will see cachelines be invalidated(and synced, if needed)
            so flashcachemin can be satisfied(numCLForceFlushDone > 0).

Description: tsagbug37486615.tsc - Test file for BUG 37486615

Function Test Spec:
  https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/display/EXD/Functional+Test+For+Bug+37486615
  https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/display/EXD/Prioritize+Rebuild+Phase+In+ASM+Automatic+Rebalance+Power+Adjustment

    Test Steps:
   1.  Create folder in workspace : /root/rebal
   2.  Get "autoRebalTest.jar" from oss/src/tools/autoRebalPolicyEngineTest

       This configuration file specifies the properties of the I/O workloads.
   8.  Run the test : java -jar autoRebalTest.jar -ios cell1_io_2dg.conf -asm asm_2dg.conf -dir /root/rebal -verbose
   9.  Validate the top Diskgroup transition from votehis.log file
   10. Validate the transition of top Diskgroup from the policy engine trace file
   11. Validate vote for priority and non-priority Diskgroup

Description: tsagbug37525412.tsc - Functional test for bug 37525412
                           IMPROVE THE CELLDISK CREATION LOGIC WHILE ALLOCATING VIRTUAL SLOT NUMBER

Test Steps:
        1. Capture any celldisk name from the existing celldisk on any cell. Let's name it "celldiskTest"
        2. Add an underscore parameter in cellinit.ora.
              _celldisk_simulation_failure=celldiskTest
        3. Restart the MS services
        4. Drop all the celldisk
              cellcli -e drop celldisk all force
        5. Create all celldisk
              cellcli -e create celldisk all
        6. Check the virtual slot number now
              cellcli -e list celldisk attributes virtualslot where diskType=harddisk
            This should return all unique numbers. There should not be any repeat.
        7. Check for the log from ms-odl.trc "Injecting error while creating celldiskTest"
            (This is to make sure the simulation has taken place.)

Test tsagbug37560525.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: setup5egs=true. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgsaexacldegstruststore.
Suites: EXAC_CORE, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagbug37560525.tsc - Functional Test for Bug 37560525

37560525 - [ESCS - INTLSN] AFTER SCALE-OUT WITH 3 CELLS, TRUSTSTORE IS
                  SHOWING ONE ADDITIONAL ENTRY
     Test Steps:
          1. Setup using tsagexastackup with setup5egs=true
          2. Find out root certificate of current egs leader:
              cellcli -e list esnode attributes localRootCert
          3. Find out the current egs leader process:
              cd log ; grep -nr ./ -e "This server is LEADER".
          4. Restart the egs leader server:
              pkill egssrv3; $T_WORK/startegs3.sh
          5. Find out the listen port of new egs server :
              cellcli -e list escluster detail
          6. Change the listening port of ms and then restart ms
          7. Find current rootUrl and trust store by using cellcli -e list esnode detail.
             Remove url in step 3) from the current rootUrl and set the new rootUrl by using
              cellcli -> alter esnode rootUrl="<new root urls>";
             remove the root cert in step 2) from the current truststore and set the new t
             rust store by using cellcli -> alter esnode trustStore="<new root certs>"
          8. Restart syseds cellcli -e alter cell restart services syseds
          9. ls vault by escli --wallet $T_WORK/esadmin_wallet -> ls.
             The expected behavior is "ls" command should return the vault names.

Test tsagbug37578771.tsc. setup=xblockini. flags: (none). platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug37578771.tsc - This transaction fixes 37578771.

Volume clone creation from parent volume was timed out, this is because parent volume is still being restored from a backup.
    To fix it, return error directly if someone tries to create a clone from a volume that is being restored and restore is not complete yet.

    We can verify the fix by following steps:
      1. Create a backup
      2. Set restore delay simulation
          CellCLI> alter cell bswEvents="ebs_simevent[BSW_BKP_RESTORE_DELAY_SIM]"
          Cell EDSCELL1 successfully altered
      3. Create a volume from a backup, which would hit the simulation
      4. Create a clone from the volume which is created at step 3, which is also
         being restored. It should get error instead of timing out.

Description: tsagbug37757735.tsc - Test for Bug 3775773
                              THROTTLE MS EMAIL NOTIFICATIONS

Test Steps:
          1. Verify that statelessAlertIntervalInMins and statelessAlertSimilarityThrInPct are not set.
          2. Generate a cellsrv absent alert by killing cellsrv and verify that the
             alert is successfully generated.
          3. Kill cellsrv again and verify that there are no new cellsrv absent alerts.
          4. Set cell traceLevel to finest and kill cellsrv. Check for patterns in ms-odl.trc.
          5. Kill MS and verify that an alert is generated.
          6. Change the value of statelessAlertIntervalInMins and wait for 60 seconds.
          7. Kill cellsrv again and verify that a new cellsrv absent alert is generated.
          8. Verify statelessAlertSimilarityThrInPct.
          9. Verify removal of statelessAlertIntervalInMins and statelessAlertSimilarityThrInPct.
          10. Both statelessAlertIntervalInMins and statelessAlertSimilarityThrInPct should be
              removed from $OSSCONF/cell_disk_config.xml now.

Test tsagbug37768255.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: (none). platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgsaexacldesnpalert.
Suites: EXAC_CORE, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagbug37768255.tsc - Functional test for bug 37768255

There are 4 scenarios to cover this bug -
  1. a. Shutdown EGS
     b. wait for a short time (less than threshold 30 minutes)
     c. startup EGS: nothing should happen
     d. make sure no alert should produce in the alert log.

  2. a. Shutdown EGS
     b. wait for a long time (longer than threshold 30 minutes)
     c. startup EGS
     d. make sure WARNING ALERT and CLEAR ALERT are produced in alert log.

  3. a. Shutdown EGS
     b. immediately restart ESNP
     c. wait for a long time (longer than threshold 30 minutes)
     d. startup EGS
     e. make sure WARNING ALERT and CLEAR ALERT are produced in alert log.

  4. a. Shutdown EGS
     b. wait for a long time (longer than threshold 30 minutes)
     c. restart ESNP
     d. startup EGS
     e. make sure WARNING ALERT and CLEAR ALERT are produced in alert log.

Description: tsagbug37787501.tsc - IORM Batch Processing Test on Hybrid Environment

This test is to check Bug 37787501 for IORM exascale IOCTL batch
     processing in the hybird environment.
     The test proceeds with the following steps:
     1) Set PLAN_DELAY_MSEC and issue multiple vault create IOCTLs.
        These vault IOCTLs will be batched and wait for 3 minutes in
        SetPlan().
     2) Set BATCH_TEST to 3 mins. After 3-wait from Step 1) is expired, the
        batch processing will proceed and wait on the last IOCTL. At this
        point, the batch processing is not completed.
     3) Issue the intra-db plan from RDBMS node and check if the incident
        due to incorrect mapping of Bug 37787501 happens.

Description: Steps to Reproduce:
      - Create user1 with the category "compute_server" using the command: mkuser user1 --attributes id=user1,category=compute_server
      - Create user2 with the category "compute_server" using the command: mkuser user2 --attributes id=user2,category=compute_server
      - Create a wallet for user1.
      - Add user1 to the wallet (same steps as for any exascale user).
      - Create a file in the vault: mkvault user1vault
      - Modify the access control list (chacl) to allow both user1 and user2 access to the vault: chacl @USER1VAULT user1:M;user2:M
      - Use moss to write to the file using user1's wallet: moss -W $T_WORK/user1.wallet -d '@USER1VAULT/testfile1' -s 8192 -w 1000 -f 8M
      - Use moss to read from the file using user1's wallet: moss -W $T_WORK/user1.wallet -d '@USER1VAULT/testfile1' -s 8192 -r 1000 -f 8M
      - Use moss to read from the file using user2's wallet: moss -W $T_WORK/user2.wallet -d '@USER1VAULT/testfile1' -s 8192 -r 1000 -f 8M
      - Check cellsrvstat to verify there are no RDMA conflicts: XRmemCache number of RDMA conflicts 0 0

               EGSFEATUREMGR::REMOVEEGSNODE

Setup
    1. Setup 3 cell Exascale environment
    2. Add _egs_server_event="ebs_simevent[EGS_ALLOW_TRUSTSTORE_UPDATE_SIM]"
    3. Find 1 EGS follower and shut it down
    4. Remove the follower from all EGS rootURL
    5. Remove the follower root certificate from other EGSes trustStore
    6. Wait for 10min for the trustStore job to run
    7. Restart all EGSes

    3. Remove this EGS follower from the rootURL

Test tsagbug37927974.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsacfcbug3.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug37927974.tsc - functional test for bug 37927974 [KEEP BUFFERS FOR BACKGROUND CC2 POPULATION WHEN THE QUEUE IS NOT FULL]

There are two queues for pending CC2 population requests.
   Queue A: Each population request is associated with a data buffer. The capacity is computed by number of total 1MB
   buffer (_cell_num_1mb_buffers) multiplied by a percentage (_cell_imcpop_max_req_with_io_buf_percent)
   Queue B: Each population request is not associated with a data buffer. The capacity of this queue is much larger than the capacity of queue A.
   Whenever we create a new background CC2 population request, we always queue the request to A first if it hasnât reached its capacity.
   If A is full, then we free the data buffer from the request, and queue the request to B, and bump up the stat ('imc_io_requests_requeued').
   This mechanism prevents background CC2 populations from hogging too many data buffers.

The test steps are:
      1. use srdbmsini to setup exadata asm and enable columnar cache by setting oss_columnar_cache
2. get tsagcrtpch.sql and run it to create a large EHCC table
3. Setting the cell init parameter "_cell_imc_pop_job_limit" to 1 and restart cellsrv.
      4. Do the following in a loop with 30 times:
          4.1 Populate CC2 by using table full scan query after setting session parameter "_kdzf_columnar_cache"="enabled, pop_cc2_for_capacity".
	    4.2 use "exec sys.columnar_cache.check_columnar" to wait until CC2 background population is completed (may be slower due to the cell parameter)
    	    4.3 Purge all CC from the cell: alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_columnarcache('purgeCC', 'all', '0', '0', '0')"
    4.4 use "exec sys.tsagmdbchk.checkCellStat" to check if "imc_io_requests_requeued" has increased

Important note:
	i) _cell_num_1mb_buffers=1000 & _cell_imcpop_max_req_with_io_buf_percent=100
	These two parameters would increase the capacity of queue A from 120 to 1000. Without these, a single scan of
	lineitem would overflow queue A and force new requests to go to queue B, which was the reason why 'imc_io_requests_requeued' was bumped up.
      ii) _cell_enable_tier1_columnar_cache=false
	This parameter disables XrCC as its unrelated to this test. XrCC requests always queue to B, although they do not
 bump up 'imc_io_requests_requeued', they can create other noise so itâs better to just disable it for this test.

Description: tsagbug38014105.tsc - Test for Bug 38014105
          EXASCALE: WHEN A FEATURE IS ENABLED/DISABLED,
          THE CHANGE SHOULD TAKE EFFECT ACROSS THE STACK IMMEDIATELY

Test to verify ability for servers to perform feature registration
      immediately with the newly elected EGS leader after a leader switch.
      (Previously, this process could take up to 8 hours.)

  The test steps are:
    1. Setup xblockini
    2. Search for patten "EgsFeatureMgr::serverRegister" in the
       current EGS leader trace files, and make sure we see AT LEAST 1
       record for each types of the servers(Multiple records are fine),
       for example:
      a. egs_1748040_71.trc:2025-07-14 23:58:11.072814 :8109E0B2: EgsFeatureMgr::serverRegister type:cellsrv, name:phoenix96010_8.3_58358_8, nfeat:3
      b. egs_1748040_66.trc:2025-07-14 23:58:11.867070 :810B393E: EgsFeatureMgr::serverRegister type:ers, name:phoenix96010_8.3_55838_2, nfeat:10
    3. Restart the EGS leader to trigger a leader election.
    4. Again, search patten "EgsFeatureMgr::serverRegister" in the current
    EGS leader trace files, and make sure we see AT LEAST 1 record for each types of the servers.
    5. Repeat 2 - 3 for 5 times.

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug38034345.tsc - Test for Bug 38034345 - VOLUME BACKUP TO VAULTS: SET BACKING FILE AS READ ONLY

Test checks that the eds file of datcopy backup is set as readOnly.
     And when the backup is restored to a volume, the readOnly flag is removed
     Steps :
     1) create a volume
     2) Loop 3 times :
     3)   Add data to volume
     4)   Create volume snapshot.
     5)   Create datacopy backup and verify if the eds file is readOnly.
     6)   Compare data in volume snapshot and backup. Data should be same.
     7)   Try writing to backup. Since its readOnly, write is expected to fail.
     8)   Compare data in volume snapshot and backup. Data should be same.
     9)   Remove the backup with --keep-data option. And eds file should still be readOnly.
     10)  Restore the backup using eds file. ReadOnly flag will be removed automatically.

      3. In alert log and traces we can see event simulation will be triggered and i
      it will inject edslib error 1006 for 10 times to simulate failed metadata
      writes, with the fix, as the transient error clears, the volume creation will
succeed.

Description: tsagbug38168185.tsc - This test script tests the fix for the bug 38168185 where bsw accidentally removed
                           ip addresses that does not belong to it.

This test script tests the fix for the bug 38168185 where bsw accidentally removed ip addresses that
     does not belong to it. To verify this fix, we have this test case in this test script.
     Here are the test steps:
       1. Bring up xblockini.tsc with sage_mirror_mode=high and iscsi=true
       2. For each of the bsw network interface, add some extra ips with named interface aliases, e.g. run as root:
              ifconfig bsw1:hello 192.168.71.120 netmask 255.255.255.0 up
              ifconfig bsw2:hello 192.168.71.121 netmask 255.255.255.0 up
              ifconfig bsw3:hello 192.168.71.122 netmask 255.255.255.0 up
       3. Shutdown all bsws
       4. Bring up bsws one by one.
       5. Verify all those extra ips are not removed. and blockstore ip address is properly configured
       6. Remove the added ip address.

Test tsagbug38330972.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsamsbug28.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug38330972.tsc - Test for bug 38330972

ora-00600:
    internal error code, arguments: [scheduler::one_or_more_cellsrv_threads_stuck]
    Bug
    In a two-node cluster with heavy OLTP workload and many databases,
    restarting a node triggers cellsrv to process mass removal and addition of
    over 20,000 ports due to diskmon events. The add operation is blocked by a
    mutex needed for disk operations, causing threads to hang and thread
    shortages for parallel fencing. This results in all fencing being handled
    by a single thread, leading to delays (>10 seconds) and a cellsrv thread hang assertion.
    --------------------------------------------------------------
    The fix is to process all fencing operations in a dedicated thread.

Description: tsagcelflof.tsc - Cell Failure offline

        -- Workload spawned against 2 Cells against two diskgroups (Datafile
           and Fred DG).
        -- Stop I/O's to one particular Fred diskgroup,  keeping
           the foreground alive (sleep).
           Continue workload that does I/O's to  the Datafile DG.
        -- cellsrv for the fred dg is killed.
        -- Validate that grid disks to which I/O was done (Datafile)
           gets offlined.
           But the grid disk belonging to fredDG should still be seen
           online by ASM, since there was no I/O generated to it.
        -- Start cell1
        -- Wake up the sleeping sql session and make more inserts to Fred DG.
        -- Online the grid disks of Datafile dg the one that went offline due
           the cell coming down while io's were in progress.
        -- Make more inserts to Datafile and make sure everything is ok.

Runs with two cellsrv process (normal redundancy)

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagcellofcp1a.tsc - Tests Cell to cell offload feature

Outline of the test :
 * Bring two RDBMS instances with help of RAC.
       * set event to HOLD IO on first RDBMS instance, insert some records and then RELEASE IO
       * Run workload on both the RDBMS instances.
       * shutdown abort first ASM
       * workload on first RDBMS instance should fail, but workload on RDBMS instance shuld succeed

Cell-to-Cell offload feature comes into play when :
        o ASM synchronizes data from an ONLINE disk to one or more partner disks, which are being brought ONLINE.
        o ASM Diskgroup is undergoing a reconfiguration due to disks being dropped or added.
      Typially ASM is the one which gets data from the source disk and then copies to the destination disk for disk rebalance. But with cell to cell offload feature
      ASM instructs destination cell to get the data from the source disk and when this is done the destination disk sends an update to ASM, there by
      involving ASM as little as possible and hence saving significant amount of bandwidth.

Description: tsagcellofcp2a.tsc - Tests cell to cell offload feature by bouncing cellsrvs while runing a DB workload

This test basically does the following :
       * Run the following in a loop with high redundancy DG with some write intensive workload on the DB.
          a) Stop cell-a (here 'a' can be 1, 2 or 3)
          b) Sleep till cell is evicted
          c) Stop cell-b (here 'a' can be 1, 2 or 3 but not same value as 'a')
          d) Sleep till cell is evicted
          e) Start cell-a
          f) After a few seconds, Start cell-b
          g) Wait for all disks to be ONLINE.

Test tsagcellofflineforce.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: SAGE_MIRROR_MODE=high, confdir=^T_WORK^/raw^oss_port1^_conf. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgsaexacldcellupgrade2.
Suites: EXAC_REGRESS, EXAC_UPGRADE.
Description: tsagcellofflineforce.tsc - test for cell offline maintenance force event

A cell offline maintenance force event occurs when EGS finds that
     a cell has already moved to offline maintenance without first
     consulting with EGS. Test steps:

     1. Bring up exascale stack with high redundancy
     2. Shutdown all EGS servers
     3. Shutdown MS on cell 1
     4. Set status to "offline" in $OSSCONF/cell_disk_config.xml for cell 1
     5. Startup MS on cell 1
     6. Ensure status is set to offline by running "cellcli -e list cell"
     7. Startup all EGS servers
     8. Grep for "getExacEvents: set flag ECS_RESULT_FLAGS_IN_MAINTENANCE"
        in svtrc*trc to ensure that cellsrv has set the in maintenance flag
     9. Grep for the following in EGS leader alert log:
        a. USR-ExaVault .* is in OFFLINE_MAINTENANCE state
        b. SYS-ExaVault .* is in OFFLINE_MAINTENANCE state
  c. ExaScale cell server .* is in OFFLINE_MAINTENANCE (FORCE)
    10. Restart all services
    11. Online cell 1 by running cellcli -e "alter cell fromversion='21.4.0.0.0.220103',patchmode='is_rolling'"

Test tsagcellproxy.tsc. setup=(none). flags: cell_conn1=o^s^^cellip^:^oss_port1^, cellproxy_opt='-p "'^cell_conn1^'"  -p "'^cell_conn2^'"', cell_conn2=o^s^^cellip^:^oss_port2^, log_file=tsagnetworkproxy_cell^cell_mode^.log. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsadskpxy.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagcellproxy.tsc - use cellconnstress to test cellsrv proxy

This feature includes below basic tests:
       1. Clients can connect to a cell via diskmon, need Clusterware and
          cell services but not ASM/RDBMS instance
          do like: runtest tsagcellproxy cell_mode=1
       2. Clients can connect to a cell via diskmon, multi-cell
          do like: runtest tsagcellproxy cell_mode=2
       3. Clients can connect to a cell via diskmon, need ASM/RDBMS instance
          do like: runtest tsagcellproxy cell_mode=3

We are going to test below tests 1-10, which need to run cellconnstress
     with various different cellinit.ora parameter settings. Some of these
     parameter settings affect cellsrv, and some affect diskmon. For the
     tests which have new parameter settings for cellsrv, we need to restart
     cellsrv.

     For the tests which have new parameter settings for diskmon, we need to
     restart diskmon, which requires killing the current diskmon, and
     waiting for cssd to restart it.  WARNING: we can only kill diskmon 5
     times in a span of 10 minutes.  Tests for cell_mode 1 and 2 currently
     kill diskmon 5 times, so we are at this limit; if we ever add more
     tests which need to kill diskmon, we will need to add a sleep of 600
     seconds after each set of 5 kills. The parameter _enable_proxy is used
     to enable/disable cellsrv proxy feature.

       - Test 1: Default settings: proxy feature disabled
       - Test 2: _enable_proxy=TRUE [cellsrv]
       - Test 3: _enable_proxy=FALSE [cellsrv] and _enable_proxy=TRUE
                [diskmon]
       - Test 4: _enable_proxy=TRUE for cellsrv and diskmon

  For tests 5-10, keep _enable_proxy=TRUE.

       - Test 5: _cell_proxy_socket_buffer_size=1 [cellsrv]
       - Test 6: (also, remove setting for _cell_proxy_socket_buffer_size):
                _dskm_proxy_socket_buffer_size=1 [diskmon]
       - Test 7:_cell_proxy_socket_buffer_size=1 [cellsrv]
                _dskm_proxy_socket_buffer_size=1 [diskmon]

  For tests 8-10, restore the default settings for
    _cell_proxy_socket_buffer_size and _dskm_proxy_socket_buffer_size.
       - Test 8: _send_partial_proxy_data=TRUE [cellsrv]
       - Test 9: _send_partial_proxy_data=TRUE [diskmon]
       - Test 10: _send_partial_proxy_data=TRUE [cellsrv and diskmon]

  * cellconnstress will need to be run with the following command-line:
    cellconnstress -C oss_conn -p "o/<connect_string>" -d 0 -t 10 -c 10 1 60

     The connect_string argument should be the same as the value of the cell
     parameter from cellip.ora; for example:
        cell="10.240.3.31;10.240.3.31;10.240.3.31;10.240.3.31:34854"

     So, the cellconnstress command-line would look like this:
        cellconnstress -C oss_conn -p "o/xx:34854" -d 0 -t 10 -c 10 1 60

     The output from cellconnstress looks like this:
      #con    #coner    ms/con    con/s    #dis    #diserr    ms/dis    dis/s
      100    0    2.45    3798.24    0    0    0.00    0.00
      0    0    0.00    0.00    100    0    1.11    7970.67
      #con    #coner    ms/con    con/s    #dis    #diserr    ms/dis    dis/s
      100    0    2.57    3626.08    0    0    0.00    0.00
      0    0    0.00    0.00    100    0    1.14    6269.20
      ...
     There are 3 lines of output for every iteration (the last command-line
     argument specifies the # of iterations. The key thing is that on the 2nd
     line (of each iteration), the 2nd column ("#coner") value should be zero,
     and on the 3rd line, the 6th column ("#diserr") should also be zero. If
     they are not both zero, that should be a dif.

Description: tsagcrashbkp2.tsc - Randomised bsw failure test for volume backup

Create a volume and its attachment. Add data to it
     incrementally and root snapshot, intermediate snapshot and
     leaf snapshot is created.

     Service: BSM / BSW

     Service is crashed and restarted while following operations happen:
      1) While creating root bkp, intermediate bkp and leaf bkp
      2) While restoring root bkp, intermediate bkp and leaf bkp
      3) While deleting root bkp, intermediate bkp and leaf bkp


     These tests are run in a loop for 5 times.
     Test is looped for the crashes to hit as many random points
     in volume bkp operation path.

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagcrtexttab.tsc - Covert a internal table to external table on Exadoop

Below is how to use:
       runtest tsagcrtexttab tab=tsagstrindx1 [cur_user=test,] [cur_pwd=test,] \
               [external_type=hive|hdfs] [order_col=col_name]
         1. cur_user: if do not set, the default value is SYS, don't require cur_pwd
         2. tab     : required, the existing normal table, after converting process, the
                      normal table name is: $tab_normal, external table is $tab
         3. cur_pwd : if do not set, the default value is the same as cur_user
         4. external_type: the default value is hdfs, it means oracle_hdfs
         5. order_col: the column name that you want to use it as a order name

Test tsagdbidfccontent.tsc. setup=(none). flags: SAGE_MIRROR_MODE=normal, scompatible.asm=19.0.0.0, scompatible.rdbms=19.0.0.0, flash_size=1024, uniq_dsknames=FLASH, creatdev_file=tsagrddef. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsafcdbid.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdbidfccontent.tsc - Test for bug 33947516

Test steps:
     1. Bring up tsagobjcachini
     2. Create a new griddisk Flint and a new diskgroup fred using these GD
     3. Disable caching for all the sysfiles and enable only for flint GD
     4. Create tablespace on fred DG and a table in it.
     5. Record the cachedSize for (dbID!=0 && objectNumber=<table's objectID>)
        and (dbID=0 && objectId=0)
     6. Perform inserts on the table
     7. Record the cachedSize again
     8. Expected behaviour: CachedSize delta for table's objectID should
        be a positive value. with bug 33947516 fix, delta cachedSize for dbid=0
        should be 0. Prior to that bug fix, DB incorrectly passed dbid=0
        for FlashCache population ioctls

Test tsagdbnodereimage.tsc. setup=(none). flags: SKIP_REIMAGE=true, FORCE_REIMAGE=false, dbnode_imagv="", view_imagv="", image_needed=true. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdbnodereimage.tsc - File with code for re-imaging the dbnode

This script reimages based on some pre-checks.
     Checks are as follows:

     The script first determines (1) Image version on dbnode
                                 (2) Image version in view
     Additionally, skip_reimage & force_reimage flags are imported.
     If force_reimage is issued, re-imaging is done in all cases.
     Else, if skip_reimage is issued, re-image is skipped.
     If both skip_reimage and force_reimage are not issued,
     re-imaging occurs if (1)!=(2). Else, it is skipped.

     If re-imaging fails mid-way, the node is commented out
     and added back to the pool.

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdisk_scrub_log.tsc - functional test of disk scrub log

Steps:
        1) Setup test env
        2) Run cellcli and simulate IO errors - this would simulate 48 bad blocks
        3) Start disk scrub by running cmd
        4) Wait disk scrub to finish
        5) Check alert log for 48 read error traces
        6) Check alert log for 48 error clear traces showing these blocks are repaired
        7) Verify device name and sector numbers in both abive traces match
        8) Check alert log for 2 extents skipped

Test tsagdiskfencing.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdiskfencing.tsc - Test disk fencing through Arbiter.

In Oracle Exadata RAC clusters it is important that I/O's to disk prior
     to offlining and onlining back are fenced or blocked before doing any
     read or write I/O's after disk online. Due to the nature of the
     network it is possible that I/O's to a disk prior to offlining can
     reach the cell after the disk is onlined again. We need to guarantee
     that any in-flight I/O's are completed in order or dropped/fenced
     before processing the new I/O's to the disk after that disk is onlined.

Test tsagdltvltload.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: eswallet=^t_work^/esadmin_wallet, egstrcdir=^ADR_BASE^^s^diag^s^EXC^s^exc^s^^HOSTNAME^^s^trace^s^. platform: EXASCALE.

Description: tsagdltvltload.tsc - test for race condition between delete and load vault

1. Create a vault and a file in the vault
   2. set a simulation event in syseds to wait for 10 seconds after usreds completed deletion of all files
      in the vault and before deleting the vault metadata
   3. delete vault with options 'force' and 'nowait'
   4. wait for alert.log msg: 'EBS error simulation: location EDS_CNTR_MD_DELETE_DELAY_SIM'
   5. try creating a new file in the vault (or some other way to get to the vault content) - the request MUST fail
   6. clear the simulation event

LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdnsled1.tsc - Includes TEST CASES 1 and 2

TEST CASE 1
       When an ASM disk is offlined, a cell hosting a partner disk
       of the offlined ASM disk should have its Do-Not-Service LED turned on,
       and the LED should be turned off when the offlined ASM disk is back online.

     TEST CASE 2
       This test case is to clear the good-health bit of an
       ASM disk to simulate an unhealthy ASM disk and then set the
       good-health bit back. To clear the good-health bit of an ASM disk,
       we simulate a disk predictive failure. To set the good-health bit back,
       we cancel the failure simulation.

For local testing:
       oratst -d tsagdnsled1.tsc

Test tsagdropfirst_rebal2nd.tsc. setup=(none). flags: num_cells=4. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexcfailc42.
Suites: EXAC_FAILURE_LITE, EXAC_REGRESS, EXAC_VES.
Description: tsagdropfirst_rebal2nd.tsc - permanently drop griddisks of leader cell,
 then add back them and perform fail/reenable operation on non-leader cell

Test steps:

 i.) - Exascale setup with 4 cells and DB workload running

 In a loop (count 3); do

     ii.) - pick leader cell and drop its griddisks permanently, reconfig and
            wait for rebalance to complete

     iii.)  - add the disks back, reconfig, DO NOT wait for rebalance or
              reconfig to complete

      iv.) - switch to non leader cell and start an fail/reenable hard disk
             operations for 5 mins while rebalance is still happening.

      v.)  - wait for background running fail/reenable operation to finish
             and rebalance on leader cell to complete

 endloop

 vi.) make sure DB workload ran fine

Description: tsagdropfirst_scrub2nd.tsc - permanently drop griddisks of leader cell,
     then add back them and perform scrub on non-leader cell

Test steps:

 i.) - Exascale setup with 4 cells and DB workload running

 In a loop (count 3); do

     ii.) - pick leader cell and drop its griddisks permanently, reconfig and
            wait for rebalance to complete

     iii.)  - add the disks back, reconfig, DO NOT wait for rebalance or
              reconfig to complete

      iv.) - switching to non leader cell and start disk scrub operation
      (BLOCK IO READ Errors) for 5 mins while rebalance is still happening.

      v.)  - wait for background running scrub operation to finish and
             rebalance on leader cell to complete

 endloop

 vi.) make sure DB workload ran fine

Test tsagdskde01.tsc. setup=(none). flags: nowarn=^TST_NOWARN^, MAX_INSTANCE=2, orcl_sid_temp=^ORACLE_SID^, md=0, otemp=asm_instance^m^, oinst=^^otemp^. platform: (none).

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 1

Wrapper test which setsup ASM/DB and starts running indvidual
     diskmon death tests

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Test tsagdskde01a.tsc. setup=(none). flags: scr1=tsagwrkload1, scr2=tsagwrkload2, num=a. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsadskcl1.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01a.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 1

Test # 1:
     (i) Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii) Kill diskmon in one node
          - cssd restarts diskmon automatically (new incarnation of diskmon)
          - cellsrv should connect to new diskmon incaratnation
          - The surviving diskmon should know about the death of the other
            diskmon through the cssd communication channel
     (iii) Workload should finish in both instances without any errors

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Test tsagdskde01b.tsc. setup=(none). flags: scr1=tsagwrkload1, scr2=tsagwrkload2, num=^case^. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsadskcl1.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01b.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 1

Test # 2:
     (i) Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii) Kill diskmon in one node
          - cssd restarts diskmon (new incarnation of diskmon)
     (iii) Sleep 10 sec
     (iv) Kill cellsrv (abnormal shutdown)
          - RS should restart cellsrv
          - there is a new incarnation of cellsrv which should connect to the
            new diskmon
     (v) Workload should finish in both instances without any errors

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Test tsagdskde01c.tsc. setup=(none). flags: scr1=tsagwrkload1, scr2=tsagwrkload2, num=c. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01c.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 1

Test # 3:
    (i)   Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
    (ii)  Kill diskmon in one node
           - cssd restarts diskmon (new incarnation of diskmon)
    (iii) Sleep 10 sec
    (iv)  Shutdown cellsrv through cellcli (normal shutdown)
           - RS will not restart cellsrv
    (v)   Sleep for a minute or so before starting cellsrv.
           - this so that the cell gets evicted. Later when the cell gets
             started, it will get added automatically.
    (vi)  Startup cellsrv through cellcli - there is a new incarnation of
             cellsrv which should connect to the new diskmon
    (vii) Workload should finish in both instances without any errors.
           - Workload should be running for atleast a minute after the cell
             comes up

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Test tsagdskde01d.tsc. setup=(none). flags: orcl_sid_temp=^ORACLE_SID^, scr1=tsagwrkload1, scr2=tsagwrkload2, num=d1, tmp_db_name=^db_name^, r=2, otemp=asm_instance^m^, oinst=^^otemp^, l=2, nd=0. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01d.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 4

Test # 4:
     (i)   Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii)  Kill diskmon in one node
           - cssd restarts diskmon (new incarnation of diskmon)
     (iii) Shutdown abort ASM inst 2 in the same node where diskmon came down
           - This will bring down rdbms instance 2 where workload will be
             aborted
     (iv)  Sleep 5 sec
     (v)   Restart ASM 2 and RDBMS 2 and start a new workload
     (vi) - Should not get any error messages like instance busy etc.
          - Workload from instance 2 should complete
          - New workload from instance 1 should complete

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Test tsagdskde01e.tsc. setup=(none). flags: scr1=tsagwrkload1, scr2=tsagwrkload2, num=e. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01e.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 2

(i) Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii) Shutdown abort ASM inst 2
          - cssd will start doing the fencing through diskmon
     (iii) Kill diskmon in the same node where ASM went down.
          - Vijay will give make some code changes which will kill diskmon
           as soon as it starts receiving fence messeages. The test will
           instrument this using an underscore parameter.
          - cssd will start a new incarnation of diskmon
     (v) Restart ASM 2 and RDBMS 2 and start a new workload
     (vi) - Should not get any error messages like instance busy etc.
          - Workload from instance 1 should complete
          - New workload from instance 2 should complete

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Test tsagdskde01g.tsc. setup=(none). flags: orcl_sid_temp=^ORACLE_SID^, tmp_db_name=^db_name^, scr1=tsagwrkload1, scr2=tsagwrkload2, num=g. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsadskcl10.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01g.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 2

(i) Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii) kill -9  of one cssd
     (iii) workload in node 2 should complete
     (iv) should see node fence requests from survivng node

      If we invoke the test script with option=2, then we kill cssd in
step (ii) with -11 and at the end of the test we look for a
      fencing message in diskmon.log of node 1.

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Test tsagdskde01h.tsc. setup=(none). flags: orcl_sid_temp=^ORACLE_SID^, tmp_db_name=^db_name^, scr1=tsagwrkload1, scr2=tsagwrkload2, num=h1, nd=0, otemp=asm_instance^m^, oinst=^^otemp^. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsadskcl4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01h.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 2

(i)  Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii) HOLD cellsrv process for > 5min. This is done by
          - SIGSTOP (kill SIGSTOP <pid>)
          When this happens:
          - diskmon stops communication with cellsrv
          - cellsrv also figures out that it cannot communicate with diskmon
          - this will start implicit fencing of the I/O's
          - ASM dg goes down
          - RDBMS instance goes down
     (iii) Remove HOLD on cellsrv:

     (i) Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii) HOLD cellsrv process for 25 secs. This is done by either of
          these two methods:

          When this happens:

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskde01j.tsc - Exadata emulated multi-node diskmon death # 2

Almost same as tsagdskde01h.tsc except that time to wait after the HOLD is < 5 min.
     (i) Start workload in two nodes (2 RDBMS/ASM instances)
     (ii) HOLD one cssd using SIGSTOP process for 120 secs.
          When this happens:
          - the surviving cssd recognizes that the other node is
            not responding and will start fencing the I/O's
          - Diskmon has been updated so that when it recieves the fece msg
            from the node not responding it does *not* crash ASM/RDBMS
            and the test case hits ORA-15311
          - RDBMS instance from the cssd which is not responding will go down
            with ORA-15311
          - the ASM disks are *not* offlined (after the bug fix from 8821490)
          - The workload from the surviving node is completed
      (iii) The test case verification is done using the foll:
          - Make sure alert*log has ORA-15311
          - ASM disks are not offline
          - workload from surviving node completes succsessfully

Uses the emulated multi-node framework

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagdskpfail.tsc - Simulates predictive disk failure

The test can be outlined as follows :
 * Scenario 1
          1. create CD on disk A and create GDs on that CD but do not add any of the GDs to ASM diskgroup
          2. verify that GDs are seen in v$asm_disk and kfod
          3. simulate predictive failure on disk A
          4. verify that GDs are not seen in v$asm_disk or kfod
          5. restart cellsrv and MS
          6. verify that GDs are not seen in v$asm_disk or kfod
 * Scenario 2
    1. create CD on disk A and create GDs on that CD and add some of the disks to an ASM diskgroup
    2. repeat steps 2-6 from scenario 1
       * Scenario 3
          1. create CD on disk A and create GDs on that CD and add all of the disks to an ASM diskgroup
          2. repeat steps 2-6 from scenario 1
       * Scenario 4
          1. Keep one of the cells down and verify that kfod runs in
             parallel without having to wait for unavailable cell to come
             backup.

Description: tsagdskstatedump.tsc - Diskmon State Dump Test

The objective of this test is to test if orarootagent initiates Diskmon state dump
   before killing an unresponsive diskmon. This test is in response to Bug 12925823 fix.

   Test flow is outlined below:
     (1) Setup a single node Environment
     (2) Force ORAROOT agent to send sigusr2 to diskmon. (It will do this only when diskmon is hung)
     (3) Check oraroot agent log to see if state dump initiation message is recorded
     (4) Check diskmon logs to see if state dump has begun
     (5) Ensure that diskmon is killed after the state dump

Test tsagdssfg.tsc. setup=(none). flags: sage_mirror_mode=high, creatdev_file=tsagrddef, dangerousfg=1, differentszfg=1, diskstring=^diskstring^,''^nonsage_path^'*''', nonsage=nonsage^i^, tmp_port=oss_port^i^, nonsage_path=^T_WORK^^s^^nonsage^^s^, logad=tsagadfgb^j^, tmp_path=raw_path^i^. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).

Description: tsagdssfg.tsc - run tsagdss with oss failgroups and mixed disks

1 . run tsagdss with 2 oss servers, 1 failgroup per server and
       multiple datafile disks per failgroup
   2 . test rebalance between SAGE and non-SAGE and predicate pushing
       to mixed disks by adding non-SAGE disks to each of the 2 failgroups
       and run query
   3 . drop the non-SAGE disks to get the diskgroups to be SAGE-only
   4 . repeat 2 and 3 but do the add/drop in parallel with query
       (with j == 2 in for j loop)
   5 . repeat 2 and 3 but add the non-SAGE disks to a separate failgroup
       and drop the SAGE failgroup (done as step 2) then re-add the SAGE
       failgroups and drop the non-SAGE failgroups to restore SAGE-only
       (done as step 3)
       This is to test failover between SAGE and non-SAGE
       (with j == 3 in for j loop)

You can specify a larger number of oss's to run with and although
     the commands will succeed, there will be log difs because I haven't
     made the comparison general enough.

      1.Client#1 opens an EXC file and starts doing IOs

Test tsagedslibglobalfile.tsc. setup=xrdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexcedslibglobal.
Suites: EXAC_CORE, EXAC_EDS, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagedslibglobalfile.tsc - Functional test for chayen_edslib_global_file_close

We can open an Exascale file in two ways: a "regular" open and a "shared" open:
     - We can create a regular open anytime, and we can perform IO to a regular open anytime.
     - We can only create a shared open when we already have a regular open.
       (The shared open is "sharing" the regular open.)
     - We can perform IO to a shared open as long as there's at least one regular open.
     - When we close the last regular open, we can NO LONGER perform IO to the shared open.
       Even if we create a new regular open, we still cannot use the old shared open for IO.

     The tests spawn two or three sqlplus sessions, then use them to test regular and shared opens.
     We open files, close files, and perform IO using ksfdx debug functions.

     We should not close a sqlplus session mid-test unless we no longer need it for the rest of
     that test. File opens are tracked per-session. Closing a session also closes all its open files
     which will mess up the test.

     We MUST serialize execution between the sessions. File opens, closes, and IO must occur
     in the correct sequence. To synchronize, all sessions set up pipes via DBMS_PIPE. After
     executing, a session will wait to receive a message from another session before continuing.

     TEST 1 -
       Loop 10x:
         session 1 creates a tablespace + table each iteration.
         session 2 drops that tablespace each iteration.
       Before the txn, the tablespace drop would take ~40s. After, the tablespace drop takes ~10s.

     TEST 2 -
       Alternate opening, closing, and performing IO in two sqlplus sessions using ksfdx debug
       commands. Each command has a comment which specifies whether it should succeed or fail.
       The command should output "success=1" for a success and "success=0" for a failure.

     TEST 3 (RTI 29702835) -
       Use simulation events to trigger segfaults during file open and file close operations.
       Make sure latch cleanup works correctly and doesn't lead to any asserts.

     TEST 4 (Bug 37264948) -
       These steps caused the database's primary edslib process to enter an infinite loop:
         1. Open a file normally in session A, do shared opens of the file in sessions B and C.
         2. Exit session A without closing the file (triggering edslib cleanup).
         3. Close the file in session B.
         4. Database is now stuck in an infinite loop and cannot open/close new files until
            session C closes the file.
       Make sure after step 3 that we can open/close files as expected.

Description: tsagedsrman.tsc - EDS RMAN test

Testing of basic use of log_archive_dest and log_archive_format
     init.ora parameters.  Plus testing of a simple RMAN backup/restore.

Overall test plan is
        1) get a database up and running
        2) Get database into archive log mode, archiving to EDS destination
        3) Create a tablespace in the database to serve as recovery target
        4) Create table in the tablespace with some reference rows
        5) Offline the tablespace
        6) Use RMAN to perform a full backup of the tablespace.
        7) "erm"/remove the tablespace files from the file system
        8) bounce the datbase (needed to avoid a bug regarding db not closing
           files).
        9) use rman to restore and recover the tablespace
       10) Online the tablespace and confirm the data is as expected.

Test tsagegscancelcopy1.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsaexcsandboxcancel3.
Suites: EXAC_EGS_SANDBOX, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagegacancelcopy1.tsc - EGS Cancel Copy Test in Sandbox Setup

1. SP created with 3 cells.
   2. Run "alter storagepool reconfig" to add 3 more cells.
       Once EGS reports that the command is completed, rebalance will start.
   3. Sleep for a random interval from 1 to 30 seconds.
   4. Run alter "alter storagepool reconfig" to drop 3 cells.
       This command will interrupt the previous rebalance, resulting in EGS issuing CANCEL.
       Once EGS reports that the command is completed, rebalance will start.
   5. Sleep for a random interval from 1 to 30 seconds.
   6. Run "alter storagepool reconfig" to add 3 more cells.
       This command will interrupt the previous rebalance, resulting in EGS issuing CANCEL.
   7. Wait for everything to complete.

Test tsagegscancelcopy2.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsaexcsandboxcancel4.
Suites: EXAC_EGS_SANDBOX, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagegscancelcopy2.tsc - EGS Cancel Copy Test in Sandbox Setup

1. SP created with 3 cells.
   2. Make disks in Slot 0 on cells - 0, 1 and 2 go into ACCESSIBLE_BAD
       This will cause EGS to rebalance in order to restore redundancy
   3. Sleep for a random interval from 1 to 30 seconds
   4. Make disks in Slot 1 on cell - 0, 1 and 2 go into ACCESSIBLE_BAD
       This will cause EGS to interrupt the existing COPY operations
       (and therefore issue CANCEL) and instead start new COPY operations.
   5. Wait for Rebalance to complete and disks in Slots-0 and 1 to be DROPPED Gracefully.
   6. Create new disks in Slot 0 on cells - 0, 1 and 2 in ACCESSIBLE_GOOD state.
       This will cause EGS to rebalance
   7. Sleep for a random interval from 1 to 30 seconds
   8. Create new disks in Slot 1 on cells - 0 ,1 and 2 in ACCESSIBLE_GOOD state.
       This will cause EGS to interrupt the existing COPY operations
       (and therefore issue CANCEL) and instead start new COPY operations.
   9. Wait for Rebalance to complete and disks in Slots-0 and 1 to be ADDED back.

Test tsagegscancelsync2.tsc. setup=(none). flags: test_name=^tst_tscname^. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsaexcsandboxcancel2.
Suites: EXAC_EGS_SANDBOX, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagegacancelsync2.tsc - EGS Cancel Sync Test in Sandbox Setup

1. SP created with 3 cells.
   2. In a loop (say 30 iterations):
      a. Make disks in slots 0-3 of cell-1 go INACCESSIBLE_UNKNOWN.
          These disks will be taken OFFLINE by EGS
      b. Sleep for 5 seconds.
   3. Make disks in slots 0-3 of cell-1 go ACCESSIBLE_GOOD.
       EGS will start SYNC for slots 0-3 disks on cell-1
   4. Make disks in slots 4-7 of cell-2 go INACCESSIBLE_UNKNOWN.
       These slots 4-7 disks will be taken OFFLINE by EGS
       But some of these disks will be Source of the SYNC to the disks
         in slots 0-3 on cell-1.
       So, EGS will have to issue CANCEL and then move to Partner Disks
         to complete the SYNC for slots 0-3 disks on cell-1.
   5. Sleep for 5 seconds.
   6. Make disks in slots 4-7 of cell-2 go ACCESSIBLE_GOOD.
       EGS will start SYNC for slots 4-7 disks on cell-2
   7. Make disks in slots 8-11 of cell-3 go INACCESSIBLE_UNKNOWN.
       These slots 8-11 disks will be taken OFFLINE by EGS
       But some of these disks will be Source of the SYNC to the disks
         in slots 0-3 on cell-1 as well as slots 4-7 on cell-2.
       So, EGS will have to issue CANCEL and then move to Partner Disks
         to complete the SYNC for slots 0-3 disks on cell-1 as well as
          slots 4-7 disks on cell-2.
   8. Wait till all the disks go ONLINE.
   9. Goto Step 2a.

Description: tsagemptyvaulttest.tsc - A bug fix test with 3 test scenarios to check snap files gets deleted in vault
                            and vault delete is successful.

A bug fix test with 3 test scenarios to check snap files gets deleted in vault
                            and vault delete is successful.

Test steps:

  Test scenario 1
    1. Create a volume
    2. Create 2 snapshots from that volume
    3. Create a backup from second snapshot
    4. do ls to the vault and confirm EDS files existence:
        1 volume file
        2 snapshot files
    5. delete second snapshot
    6. do ls to the vault, the snap EDS file will remain there
    7. delete first snapshot
    8. do ls to the vault and confirm the first snap EDS file is gone
    9. delete the volume
    10. do ls to the vault and confirm that snap and volume EDS files are gone (vault will be empty)
    11. Delete vault
  Test scenario 2
    1. Create a volume
    2. Create 2 snapshots from that volume
    3. Create a backup from second snapshot
    4. do ls to the vault and confirm EDS files existence:
        1 volume file
        2 snapshot files
    5. delete the volume created
    6. confirm volume EDS file was deleted from the vault
    7. delete second snapshot
    8. do ls to the vault, the snap EDS file should be deleted
    9. delete first snapshot
    10. Do ls to the vault and confirm the first snap EDS file is gone (vault will be empty)
    11. Delete vault
  Test scenario 3
    1. Create a volume
    2. Create a snapshot from that volume
    3. Create a backup from snapshot
    4. confirm volume EDS file was deleted from the vault
    5. delete snapshot
    8. do ls to the vault, the snap EDS file should be deleted
    9. do ls to the vault and confirm the first snap EDS file is gone (vault will be empty)
    10 Delete vault

Create Table As Select and Alter Table Move
     Verify that "create table as select"  will successfully relocate an
     encrypted table to a tablespace created with a different encryption_spec.
     Also verify that the table can be effectively decrypted by doing "create
     table as select" to a non-encrypted tablespace.
     Verify that "alter table move" will successfully relocate an encrypted
     table to a tablespace created with a different encryption_spec.  Also
     verify that the table can be effectively decrypted by doing "alter table
     move" to a non-encrypted tablespace.

Test tsagenc15.tsc. setup=(none). flags: auto_undo_management=true, test_block_encrypt=true, compatible=^def_compatibility^. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsacfcentbs2unc_excld.
Suites: EXAC_COLUMNAR_CACHE, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagenc15.tsc - Test Kernel Buffer Cache ENCryption test 15, Clone tkbcenc15.tsc

Interactions with Wallet.
   Do multiple 'alter system set encryption key identified by "welcome1";'
   commands.  They should not give an error, not rekey datafile keys.
   Create an encrypted table within a tablespace.  Shut down and start up
   (without accessing that tablespace).  Open the Wallet, then close it.
   Access to the table within this tablespace should fail.  Note: this is
   the same as how TDE functions; it would fail with:
      "ORA-28365: wallet is not open".
   Do a shutdown abort so that recovery is necessary upon startup.  Close the
   wallet.  Verify that recovery cannot proceed when database is started
   (fail with "ORA-28365").  Open the wallet and verify that
   recovery can proceed.

Test tsagenc17.tsc. setup=(none). flags: test_block_encrypt=true, auto_undo_management=true. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsacfcentbs2unc_excld.
Suites: EXAC_COLUMNAR_CACHE, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagenc17.tsc - Test Kernel Buffer Cache ENCryption test 17,Clone tkbcenc17.tsc

1a. Underscore parameter _db_writer_coalesce_write_limit adjustment test
       -- encryption should work even if _db_writer_coalesce_write_limit is
       set to 0
    1b. Underscore parameter _db_writer_coalesce_area_size boundry
       verification test.  The new hard minimum is min(1% buffercache size,
       1MB).  If not specified, it should be set to min(1% buffercache size,
       4MB).
    1c. Underscore parameter _db_writer_nomemcopy_coalesce test.  No-memcopy
       coalescing is now a separate underscore parameter, and should work
       for both encryption and no-encryption cases.

    2. (Coverage) Test of DBV on datafile with encrypted blocks

    3. (Coverage) Test of BBED on datafile with encrypted blocks

Test tsagenc4.tsc. setup=(none). flags: test_block_encrypt=true, recovery_seeddb=true, auto_undo_management=true, compatible=^max_compatibility^, x=3  # Number of processes using same rollback seg, y=3  # Number of rollback segs used in test. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagenc4.tsc - Test Kernel Buffer Cache ENCryption
                    save undo test 4, Clone tkbcenc4.tsc

While an encrypted tablespace is being updated, take the tablespace
   offline so that SAVE UNDO will be stored in the SYSTEM tablespace.  Bring
   the tablespace back online and verify in the encrypted table that all
   changes are correctly reflected (see tkbcmbs0.tsc for a guideline on this).
   Also verify that cleartext for 'encryptedstring' does not appear within
   SYSTEM tablespace (file tbs_01.f in recovery database).

   Fork 9 test scripts which generate DML without committing
   then they perform a rendezvous with a process that takes the tablespace
   containing the table offline.  Then all active transactions call rollback.
   When the tablespace is onlined again, verify that the changes are
   indeed rolled back and verify through statistics that the multiblock
   save undo is applied.

Based upon test tkbcmbs1

flags.x: 3  # Number of processes using same rollback seg
flags.y: 3  # Number of rollback segs used in test

Test tsagerror_tracker.tsc. setup=(none). flags: SLEEP_TIME=600, TRACE_FILE=^t_work^/tsagerror_tracker_tracefile.dat. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagerror_tracker.tsc - driver script for error tracking
                             and sending mail or aborting lrg

This is the driver script for tracking specific errors in
     lrgs using tsagexastackup and either send mail and abort the
     lrg or just send the notification mail incase the error is
     encountered. The script runs in the background and
     automatically ends when lrg execution is finished.

Usage : farm submit <lrg> -config "TRACK_ERROR=true;
              ERROR_MSG=error1|error2|error3;MODE=ABORT/MAIL;
              TO_MAIL=<email_address>"
     TRACK_ERROR=true : to enable this function
     ERROR_MSG=error1|error2|error3 : error messages to track
               different messages need to be seperated by |
     MODE=MAIL for email alert only, abort for email alert and
               ending of lrg.
     TO_MAIL=<email_address> :address where the notif will be sent

     All of these parameters are necessary for the tracking to work

     Currently the files being tracked are mentioned in
     tsagerror_tracker_tracefile.dat. Please add full location of
     any other file which you want to track.

Description: tsagersreconfnc.tsc â Test for ERS fencing only upon reconnection.

This test covers the case when EGS leader only fences the services and bumps up the EXC node
     incarnation if the RECONNECT error was due to the below reasons.
     	1. The peer service restarted, which means it has a newer OSS incarnation number.
     	2. The peer service is truly in a bad state -- Some IOCTL doesn't complete in 30 minutes.
     Otherwise, EGS leader will just re-ONLINE the service with the same EXC node incarnation.

Description: tsagexadsmartall.tsc - Test for smart ALL adverb

Currently, when "ALL" is specified without other diskType qualifiers,
      the command would target at all types of cell disks for grid disk
      operations.
      In the transaction - yifanch_bug-35034249, "ALL" is made
      smarter and deterministic. It will filter out cell disks of the
      primary media type on a real hardware or when
      "_cell_griddisk_cmd_smart_all_sim_sys" is explicitly configured
      (0:HC, 1:EF w/ TLC only-EF sys before X10, 2:EF w/ TLC and QLC-EF X10).
