Description: tsagfcioruntc.tsc - Exadata CDB Flash Cache/DiskIO Run Test Case

This file runs a Flash Cache/Disk IO test case using the specified
     parameters.

Parameters:
        wl_type: Type of workload, can be 'fc' or 'io'

        wl_time: Workload running time in seconds.

        cdbn_pdbm: The name of the container where each workload will run,
                   where n is the CDB number and m is the PDB number, and
                   both numbers can be up to 10.

        cdbn_pdbmwlcount: The workload count for the specified cdbn_pdbm
                          container. I.e. a wlcount of 3 will be three times
                          as intensive as a wlcount of 1.

        cdbn_pdbmshares: The expected resource shares consumed by the
                         container. Used for verification.

        cdbn_pdbmaction: The action to be performed on the container before
                         and after the test case is run. Only supported value
                         is 'close', which closes the PDB before starting the
                         test case, and reopens the container after the test
                         case is done.

Test tsagfcmdsync.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgsafciovgroup4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagfcmdsync.tsc - functional test for FC MD sync during clean shutdown

functional test for FC MD sync during clean shutdown

functional test for FC MD sync during clean shutdown

     (1) Create 1GB WriteBack FlashCache with 2 flash stores.
     (2) Set cell parameter _cell_fc_toresilver_limit_mb to 1.
         This parameter limits the size of dirty cached data to resilver
         in flashcache to 1MB, and forces datasync to happen in background.
         The parameter can be dynamically set via:
         alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_setparam(' _cell_fc_toresilver_limit_mb', 1)";
     (3) Create 2 GridDisk with total size 800MB or greater.
         Wait till grid disks are cached by FlashCache.
     (4) Run orion 100% write workload on the entire grid disks for 2 mins
         to generate all the dirty cachelines.
         orion -run advanced -type rand -write 100 -testname orion \
           -size_small 1024 -num_small 16 -size_large 64 -num_large 0 \
           -matrix point -is_advm -duration 120
     (5) Get a FC stat dump for reference.
         alter cell events="immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_flashcache(dumpstats, 0, 0, 1)";
     (6) Get FC_BY_DIRTY metric . It should be non-zero.
         list metriccurrent attributes name, metricObjectName, metricValue where name like "FC_BY_DIRTY"
     (7) Sleep 120 seconds to allow background to do more datasync.
         For determinstic test result, check cellsrvstat periodically
         until timeout or "FlashCache synced dirty data (KB)" no longer
         changes.
     (8) Redirect the cellsrvstat output to a file for reference and check.
         The expected behavior is that there should be non-zero synced
         dirty data in FlashCache. We are interested in the following stats.
         Number of disk writer datasync writes
         Total size for disk writer datasync writes (KB)
         Cachesize(KB)
         FlashCache synced dirty data (KB)
         FlashCache unsynced dirty data (KB)
     (9) Restart cellsrv.
         alter cell restart services cellsrv;
     (10) Get a FC stat dump for reference.
     (11) Get FC_BY_DIRTY for reference. The expected behavior is that
          MD sync during clean shutdown should have converted the synced
          dirty cachelines to clean cachelines, so the real dirty data
          is <= 1MB after cellsrv restart.
     (12) Save cellsrvstat result for reference. Check cellsrvstat.
          The expected behavior is that there is no synced
          dirty data and the unsycned dirty data is <= 1MB.
          Cachesize(KB)                         --> non-zero, close to 800MB.
          FlashCache synced dirty data (KB)     --> should be 0
          FlashCache unsynced dirty data (KB)   --> should be <= 1MB

Test tsagfcreplace.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: oss_testing=1, flash_size=576, num_flash_per_cell=1, OSS_ENABLE_FC_PERSISTENCE=writeback, asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsafcbug1.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagfcreplace.tsc - Test case for cachelines replacement of flashcache

Test case for cachelines replacement of flashcache

PayPal ran into a problem where they were not able to pre-warm their IOT
     tables into flash cache via KEEP (due to some bug possibly in the PQ layer).

     Also cover the IORM bug:
  Bug 33403239 - ENABLE PDB LEVEL SETTINGS WITHOUT THE CDB PLAN FOR CDBS WITH SINGLE PDB

     Below is the PayPal problem:

       1). They have 5 DBs sharing the Exadata cells.  None of them have any flash
           cache min/limit/size set initially.The first 4 DBs have occupied the flash
           cache completely.  The 5th DB is a newly migrated DB, i.e. a new comer
           trying to get its blocks cached into flash cache.
       2). They can set the FlashCacheMin for the 5th DB (the newly migrated DB) to
            some reasonable value (say 3TB per cell), so that we can set aside
            at least 3TB per cell for caching this new DB.
       3). They can then do the pre-warm full table scans of key objects in the
           5th table.  Even though KEEP is not set, because the FC size for
           the 5th DB is not yet at the FlashCacheMin, all of the scans should
           get into flash cache as long as we can free up enough cachelines in
           flash cache to keep up. We may require repeated scans to get a table
           fully scanned, as flash cache may need some time to  find all the
           replacement cachelines for the new DB as it's already full.

     Test steps for fake dbs:

     (1) Let's create 2 data grid disks. Datafile0 is 512MB, which will be used
         for Database TEST5. Dadatafile1 is 512MB, which will be used for Database
          TEST6. Create FC 512 MB.
     (2) Similar to the current test, we first use orion to populate FC using TEST5.
         Let use the entire 512MB grid disk region for orion. We expect that FC is
          fully filled with TEST5 data. This is to simulate the scenario in
          customer's env where FC got full with existing databases data.
     (3) Set flashCacheMin limit for TEST6, say 200MB.
     (4) We need to introduce concurrent orion workloads on both TEST5 and TEST6
         to simulate the workload in customer env, i.e. both databases are
         active and performance critical.
         * This time, TEST5 need to have a smaller working set, say 200MB griddisk
            area. So that we can simulate  the scenario where some cache data from
            TEST5 can become cold, while some cached data are still hot.
         * TEST6 needs to have a working set larger than its flashCacheMin,
           say 500MB griddisk area.
     (5) After some time, we're expecting that cachedSize for TEST6 should be
         more than its flashCacheMin 200MB.

LRGs: lrgsafciovgroup3.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagfcstair.tsc - Flashcache/PMEMCache stair down/up tests

Flashcache/PMEMCache stair down/up tests

Flashcache/PMEMCache stair down/up tests
     below is test steps:

       1. create 2 grid disks datafile0 and datafile1 (512MB each).
       2. create flashcache 600MB
       3. create iorm fake_db test5 by using the following cellcli command.
          Cellcli> alter cell events = "cellsrv.cellsrv_iorm_ctl[FAKE_DBS] opval=6"
       4. set iorm plan for fake DB test5 to flashcache=off
          Cellcli> alter iormplan dbplan=((name=test5, flashcache=off, share=1))
       5. create a orion.lun for orion test.
          o/xxx/datafile0
          o/xxx/datafile1
       6. start orion all-read workload (duration 15 minutes) on DB test5.
          $ADE_VIEW_ROOT/rdbms/bin/orion -run advanced -type rand -matrix point
                 -testname orion -size_small 8 -num_large 0 -num_small 8 -write 0
       		  -duration 900 -dbid 5

       7. run the following stair up test in a loop.
         fclimit=0
         for i in 1..5 loop
           fcLimit += 100M
           alter iormplan dbplan=((name=test5, flashcache=on, flashcachesize=<fcLimit>))
           sleep 2 minutes
           # get DB_FC_BY_ALLOCATED for DB test5
           list metriccurrent attributes metricValue where name='DB_FC_BY_ALLOCATED'
       	     and metricObjectName='TEST5';
            # perform check -- the metricValue should match fcLimit
           <check>
         end loop
       8. run stair down test in a loop. Similar to step 7, but with fcLimit
          decremented back to 0 gradually.

Description: tsagfeatureupgrade.tsc - Exascale software feature upgrade test

Test for ExaScale software features with versioning infrastructure

This test covers the below metioned cases where all services
     are restarted after making any change in feature.conf

      0a. POSITIVE CASE - Verification of default feature AEP
      0b. POSITIVE CASE - Verifying feature SP_OP_TRACK
      1. POSITIVE CASE - Adding a feature
      CASE - DISABLING USREDS IN 1 CELL AND THEN ADDING FEATURE
      1a.POSITIVE CASE - Adding a feature having EGS as a participant
      1b.POSITIVE CASE - Adding a feature having multiple participants having EGS as mandatory one (bug-36339781)
      2. POSITIVE CASE - Adding faeture in disabled state and then enabling it
      3. NEGATIVE CASE - Downgrade feature version to immediate lower minor bit
      4. NEGATIVE CASE - Downgrade feature version to immediate lower major bit
      5. NEGATIVE CASE - Downgrade feature version to any lower major bit
      6. POSITIVE CASE - Rolling Upgrade feature version to next sequential minor bit
      7. POSITIVE CASE - Upgrade feature version to next sequential major bit
      8. NEGATIVE CASE - Upgrade feature version to non-sequential minor bit
      9. POSITIVE CASE - Upgrade feature version to non-sequential minor bit
      10. POSITIVE CASE - Upgrade feature version to non-sequential major bit
      11. POSITIVE CASE - Upgrade feature version to non-sequential [current_majorbit+1].0
      12. NEGATIVE CASE - Upgrade feature version to non-sequential [majorbit].[any_minorbit]
      13. POSITIVE CASE - Upgrade feature version to non-sequential [majorbit].[any_minorbit]
      14. POSITIVE CASE - Upgrading feature version to current version
      15. POSITIVE CASE - Disabling a feature manually and then upgrading its version
      2a. POSITIVE CASE - Adding a new feature in blackout mode which is in disabled state
      2b. POSITIVE CASE - Adding a new feature in blackout mode which is in enabled state
      2c. POSITIVE CASE - Adding a new participant in already existing feature via feature.conf
      16. NEGATIVE CASE - Removing feature.conf completely - Commented out
      17. POSITIVE CASE - Using empty feature.conf - Commented out

Test tsagfencauth.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: (none). platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexcfence1.
Suites: EXAC_CORE, EXAC_MEDIUM, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagfencauth.tsc - Test for ExaScale fencing authorization mechanism

When a server receives a fence request, it will proceed only if the peer
     is authorized. This lrg contains the unit tests for fence request
     authorization.
     Test cases:
       1. Set up the ExaScale cluster.
       2. Restart ERS to trigger a node level fencing. The fence should
          complete successfully since it is sent from EGS leader.
       3. Run edstool list command to trigger a member level fencing. The
          fence should complete successfully since it is sent from the ESNP
          who has the same node ID as edstool.
       4. Use Arbiter to simulate a node level fencing. The fence should
          fail, because Arbiter's cert doesn't have EGS bit.
       5. Use Arbiter to simulate a member level fencing for a different node.
          The fences should fail, because Arbiter's TLS cert has the same
          node ID as the ESNP, that it is not allowed to fence a different
          node's member.
       6. Use Arbiter to simulate a member level fencing for the same node.
          The fence should complete successfully since it is sent from the
          Arbiter who has the same node ID as ESNP.

Description: tsagfirmupdate.tsc - test for system disk firm failure

The test checks when a disk is replaced, MS triggers the firmware
   update and if the firmware update fails then MS will drop the lun
   and reject the disk with firmware update failed. And MS will
   do the same for the system disk. But if this is the only system
   disk then MS should not delete the lun (as a final resort to rescue
    the system).

Test tsagflashio.tsc. setup=(none). flags: db_cache_size=16, processes=200                          # need this if using parallel query, asm_ausize=1048576, enabledegraded=# tell tsagerrsimoff to reenable any degraded flash disk, errbasename=^tst_tscname^tmp.log. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsaflashw1_nvc.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagflashio.tsc -- concurrent I/O's

1. Create 5 tables of 1000 rows each - one on FLASH griddisk,
     the others on FLINT griddisks. Two FLINT tables are created with
     cell_flash_cache "DEFAULT", one with cell_flash_cache "KEEP", one
     with cell_flash_cache "NONE".
     Make one of the "DEFAULT" tables partitioned, with 10 partitions.
     1a. Change the "KEEP" table to "NONE" and the "NONE" table to "KEEP"
     then continue with next step to test partial write.
     2. If err_simulation1 is specfied, enable it. Then kick off sqlplus
     sessions to add ^addrows^ rows to each FLINT table and to update
     them concurrently. Also repeatedly drop and recreate the partitioned
     table and corresponding tablespace.
     3. Query the tables to make sure they are updated correctly.
     4. If working with a small flashcache (<=32M, or <=64M in case of
     writeback), add rows to "KEEP" table until it takes up more than 70%
     of flashcache. Then select from other tables to verify that they do
     not displace "KEEP" cache to the point that cachedKeepSize is less
     than 70% of flashcache.
     5. Disable err_simulation1 and if err_simulation2 is specfied,
     enable it. Then kick off sqlplus sessions to delete rows from each
     FLINT table, leaving only 500 rows, and to query them concurrently.
     6. Query the tables to make sure they are updated correctly.

     If testing read or write persistence, bounce the cell between steps
     2 and 3. Also bounce the cell in steps 2 and 5 if disks are mirrored.

flags.processes: 200                          # need this if using parallel query
flags.enabledegraded: # tell tsagerrsimoff to reenable any degraded flash disk

Test tsagflashrestart.tsc. setup=(none). flags: filesize=^TST_EXE_RESULT^, cacheKeepSizePreShutdown=^TST_EXE_RESULT^, cacheSizePreShutdown=^TST_EXE_RESULT^, errFrequency=1, errCount=1, evstr='['^bootstrap_err^'] count='^errCount^', frequency='^errFrequency^, nextPersistMode=off, oldsuffix=^logsuffix^, kill_cellsrv=^tst_exe_result^, cacheKeepSizePostShutdown=^TST_EXE_RESULT^, cacheSizePostShutdown=^TST_EXE_RESULT^, persistoff=1, nobootstrap=1, restartcell=^tst_exe_status^, errmsg='cacheSizePostShutdown < 70% of cacheSizePreShutdown'. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsaobcachb.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagflashrestart.tsc - restart cell to test flash persistence

This script is invoked by tsagflashio.tsc to shutdown DB, ASM,
     cell and restart them. It gets flashcachecontent before and afterwards.
     If restartMode == killcell, kill cellsrv with -9 then restart it.
     (This is done only if not running with RS. If running with RS then
     cellsrv is shutdown by RS.)
     If restartMode == allservices, shutdown all cell services then
     restart them. (This is done only if running with RS. If not running
     with RS then cellsrv is stopped via SIGUSR1 then restarted.)
     celldowntime can be specified to sleep the desired number of seconds
     before restarting.

Test tsagflashrm.tsc. setup=(none). flags: errbasename=^tst_tscname^tmp.log. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsaflashrmw.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagflashrm.tsc - Simulate various failure cases

tsagflashrm.tsc - Simulate various failure cases
     . flash griddisk data corruption
     . testcase=flashcachelst
       - loss of flashcache.lst
       - corruption of flashcache.lst
       - loss of flashcache.lst and cell_dsk_config.xml*
     . testcase=flashdisk
       - temporary loss of FLASH disk
       - hot replacement of FLASH disk
         (while cell is up - not possible on real hw)
       - cold replacement of FLASH disk
         (while cell is down)

     You can specify what type of failure to test. For example,
     "oratst oss_saflashrmw testcase=flashcachelst"
     or
     "oratst oss_saflashrmr testcase=flashdisk"

Test tsagflashwearorion.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgrhx11saipcdat.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagflashwearorion.tsc - Real HW test for verifying flash wear checks

Test steps:
       i.) - Get device name and Vendor id
      ii.) - Get cell ip
     iii.) - check resetting of timed_workload_media_wear is needed or not
                 if yes -- reset value of timed_workload_media_wear (it takes around an hour time)
                 else no need of reset
      iv.) - Before running Orion Workload, checking value of timed_workload_media_wear
       v.) - Copy orion to cell node
      vi.) - Setup cellip.ora and .luns to run orion
   In a loop ( count 30 ); do
        vii.) - Run orion workload for 2 min
       viii.) - Comparing new value with old value
                 if newvalue>oldvalue ----> test passes
                 loop break;
                 else test fails
   endloop
        xi.) - verifying flash wear ticks or not

test is added in lrgrhx7saipcdat

Test tsaghybridrebal_egsrestart.tsc. setup=xrdbmsini. flags: oss_auto_manage_disks=true, oss_exascale_asm_testing=true, sage_mirror_mode=high, disable_multims=true. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexchybrid4.
Suites: EXAC_REGRESS, EXAC_VES.
Description: tsaghybridrebal_egsrestart.tsc -<Double failure test for hybrid setup>

Fail/reenable 2 disks in a loop and restart egs to check rebalance.

=== Flow of Test Case for Rebal  ===
    1. In a loop count of 3
    2. Get ASM alert log size
    3. Fail 2 disk and then reboot EGS leader 3 times in interval of 10sec.
    4. Check EGS leader started successfully and wait for disks to be dropped.
    5. Make sure rebalance completed for Exascale and ASM.
    6. Again, get ASM alert log size and reenable the disk.
    7. Reboot EGS leader 3 times in interval of 10 sec and then check EGS leader
    started successfully.
    8. Wait for disk to be added
    9. Make sure rebalance completed for Exascale and ASM.


    === Flow of Test Case for Resilver ===
    1. In a loop count of 3
    2. Fail 2 Flash disk and then reboot EGS leader 2 times in interval of 10sec.
    3. Check EGS leader started successfully and wait for disks to be dropped.
    4. Restart cellsrv
    5. Make sure resilver completed for cellsrv
    6. Reenable the 2 failed flash disk.
    7. Reboot EGS leader 2 times in interval of 10 sec and then check EGS leader
    started successfully.
    8. Wait for disks to be added

Description: tsagimcheckdev.tsc - Exadata cell checkdev thread tests

This test can be run on any cell and can be used to run one of the following scenarios
   a) Failure tests on system disks [ failure_option -sysdisk ]
   b) Failure tests on usb [ failure_option -usb ]
   c) Failure tests on md devices [ failure_option -md ]
   d) A combination of failures on system disk,usb and md devices. [ failure_option -all ]
   e) Failure scenarios [ failure_option -fail ]

   Syntax:
   oratst -d tsagimcheckdev.tsc mach_name=<cell name> mach_passwd=<cell root password>
   failure_option=<-usb|-sysdisk|-md|-all|-fail> [install_rpm=true]

   Using install_rpm=true would install the rpm from the view on the cell before
   running any tests.

     11.2.1.2.3, 11.2.1.2.4, 11.2.1.2.6, 11.2.1.3.1, 11.2.2.1.0, 11.2.2.1.1,11.2.2.2.0

Test tsaginimcell.tsc. setup=(none). flags: dot='.', creatdev_file=tsagr2def, sep_var=',', sep_var1='=', vault_log=^vault_db^, vault_db=DB^ORA_SID_UPPER^, cid=1. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgcmaincmainrmainsamcdbfail2_excld.
Suites: EXAC_COMPAT, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsaginimcell.tsc - Setup Exadata&Exascale Multiple cell versions with one database

This script will setup Exadata&Exascale Multiple cell versions in multi-views

     For Exadata:
       1). Setup three views: two oss views with OSS_MAIN, OSS_XXX, one RDBMS VIEW
       2) In OSS views, just setup cell services and setup GI/ASM/DB instances in RDBMS VIEW
       3) In rdbms view, we should setup ASM DG with normal redu that using griddisks
          from different cell versions

     For Exascale:
       1). Setup three views: two oss views with OSS_MAIN latest label, OSS_MAIN old base label, one RDBMS VIEW
       2) In OSS views, just setup full Exascale cell services and setup GI/DB instances in RDBMS VIEW
       3) In rdbms view, we should use Exascale vault to setup databases

     Once set oss_exascale_testing, it will setup multiple exascale cell versions, by default
     we setup multiple exadata cell versions, below items are different with Exadata:
       1). setup one cell in high cell view and two cells in low cell view
       2). setup egs cluster with 3 instances, one comes from high cell view and two comes from low cell view
       3). setup two ers instances, each of them come from different cell view

How to use

     A. If you don't have any views, just run: oratst -d tsaginimcell to setup this env.
     B. If you have two views or one view, please run
        oratst -d tsaginimcell oss_view2=juwawang_phoenix92470_ossv2 rdbms_view=juwawang_phoenix92470_rdbmsv1
        oratst -d tsaginimcell rdbms_view=juwawang_phoenix92470_rdbmsv1

     if you want to set some cell setup parameters, please use flag - cell_setup_parameters
        let cell_setup_parameters 'cell_with_pmemcache=1,cell_with_xrmem_cache=0'

     if you want to set some cell parameters, please use flag - cell_parameters
        let cell_parameters '_cell_storage_index_diag_mode=1,_cell_fc_columnar_force_cc1=FALSE'

     if you want to set some db parameters, please use flag - db_parameters
        let db_parameters 'oss_auto_manage_disks=true,oss_auto_manage_disks1=true'


      A full demo to run your special test:

         # setup multiple cell views env.
         include tsaginimcell

         # run your test
         runtest your_tsc_file

         # clean up multiple cell views env.
         include tsagclnmcell

      All user guide can be found from page: https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=4907585070

Test tsaginimtc.tsc. setup=(none). flags: no_gd_with_prefix=true, adg_dbname=exadb, ora_sid=exadb, db_unq=^db_unq^, cdb_dd=pdbs_across_cdbs, sep_var=',', sep_var1='=', file_dest=@^vault_db^, db_count=^num_dbs^. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsamtc.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsaginimtc.tsc  - limited asm disk discovery using 2 asm clusters

Basic test case for limited asm disk discovery
     this tsc will setup an oss cell have 2 set of griddisk, diska*,datafile*
     when cluster 1 create a diskgroup using diska0, cluster2 should not see the used asm disk
     Two cells with normal redundancy.

This test will setup two more RDBMS views to run 2 asm clusters share the same storage
     from current view which setup an oss cell


     1. Setup n-CDBs with n-PDBs in each clusters:

  oratst -d tsaginimtc cdb=true num_dbs=n pdbs_per_cdb=n cdb_dd=pdbs_across_cdbs duplicate_dbnm=true oss_asm_sec=true

     pdbs_per_cdb : the default value is 1
     num_dbs      : the default value is 1, , it is the number of databases in each cluster
                    if cdb_dd is pdbs_across_cdbs, then it's the number of CDB, in this mode,
                    you can use pdbs_per_cdb to define the number of PDB in each CDB
                    or else, it's the number of PDBs when cdb_dd is pdbs_in_cdbs
     cdb_dd       : PDB mode, the default is pdbs_across_cdbs, another value is pdbs_in_cdbs
     duplicate_dbnm: when it is true, we'll create the same db unique name in different clusters without ASM scoped security
                     db1 name: exadb, db2 name: exadbb, db3 name: exadbc, db4 name: exadbd
     duplicate_dbnm_sec: when it is true, we'll create the same db unique name in different clusters with ASM scoped security
                     db1 name: exadb, db2 name: exadbb, db3 name: exadbc, db4 name: exadbd
     cluster2_db_nums: this is used to create the number of database in cluster2 if it is set
                      or else create num_dbs databases in it, but we always create num_dbs databases in cluster1
     oss_asm_sec: enable ASM-scroped security
     disable_cluster_sec: 1 or 2 is the cluster where ASM-scoped security should be disabled
     cluster1_db_sec: the name of the db in cluster 1, we setup the database-scoped security for it
     cluster2_db_sec: the name of the db in cluster 2, we setup the database-scoped security for it
     cluster2_cdb:   when it is true, will enable cdb mode in cluster 2, but still create normal databases in cluster 1

     2. Setup n-DBs(non-CDB) in each clusters:
      oratst -d tsaginimtc num_dbs=n

     num_dbs      : the default value is 1, it is the number of databases in each cluster
     duplicate_dbnm: when it is true, we'll create the same db unique name in different clusters
                     db1 name: exadb, db2 name: exadbb, db3 name: exadbc, db4 name: exadbd
     duplicate_dbnm_sec: when it is true, we'll create the same db unique name in different clusters with ASM scoped security
                     db1 name: exadb, db2 name: exadbb, db3 name: exadbc, db4 name: exadbd
     cluster2_db_nums: this is used to create the number of database in cluster2, we always create num_dbs databases in cluster1
     oss_asm_sec: enable ASM-scroped security
     disable_cluster_sec: 1 or 2 is the cluster where ASM-scoped security should be disabled
     cluster1_db_sec: the name of the db in cluster 1, we setup the database-scoped security for it
     cluster2_db_sec: the name of the db in cluster 2, we setup the database-scoped security for it
     cluster2_cdb:   when it is true, will enable cdb mode in cluster 2, but still create normal databases in cluster 1

     3. Setup Exascale ADG across clusters(Primary and standby are in different clusters):
       oratst -d tsaginimtc oss_mtc_adg=xx [adg_standby_file_mode=xx] [adg_standby_creation_mode=xx]

       oss_mtc_adg : Enable to setup Exascale ADG in MTC test fw

          1). oss_mtc_adg=adg_indifferent_vault : Primary/Standby DB are created in different vaults
              oratst -d tsaginimtc oss_mtc_adg=adg_indifferent_vault

          2). oss_mtc_adg=adg_insame_vault : Primary/Standby DB are created in same vault
              oratst -d tsaginimtc oss_mtc_adg=adg_insame_vault

          3). oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_asm_vault : Primary is on ASM in cluster 1 and Standby DB is created on vault in cluster 2
              ASM griddisks and vault pool disks come from same cells

              oratst -d tsaginimtc oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_asm_vault

          4). oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_cross_cell : Primary is on ASM in cluster 1 and Standby DB is created on vault in cluster 2
              ASM griddisks and vault pool disks come from separated cells, in this setup, it creates 2 cell views and 2 cluster views

                1). Cell    view 1(root view): setup Exascale full serivces, it servers for the standby db in cluster view 2
                2). Cluster view 1(cluster 1): setup GI/ASM/Primary Database, it uses the ASM diskgroups in cell view 2
                3). Cluster view 2(cluster 2): setup GI/Standby Database, it uses the vault in cell view 1
                4). Cell    view 2(cluster 3): setup Exadata full serivces, it servers for the primary db in cluster view 1

            In summary, we setup ADG on hbrid (ASM -> Exascale) like this:

            1). Setup Exadata ASM in cell view 2 and cluser view 1 and create primary database on it

            2). Setup Exadata Exascale in cell view 1 and cluser view 2 and use rman duplicate/restore database from primary services
                to create standby database on it

            3). Config ADG between cluster view 1 and cluster view 2 to ensure MRP works well

        How to setup locally:

              oratst -d tsaginimtc oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_cross_cell


       adg_standby_file_mode : config file creation mode for standby database in cluster 2

          1). adg_standby_file_mode=omf : just enable OMF in standby database, default value

          2). adg_standby_file_mode=omf_all_convert :  enable OMF and db/log file_name_convert in standby database

          3). adg_standby_file_mode=omf_db_convert :   enable OMF and db file_name_convert in standby database

          4). adg_standby_file_mode=omf_log_convert : enable OMF and log file_name_convert in standby database

          5). adg_standby_file_mode=off : just enable db/log file_name_convert in standby database

              oratst -d tsaginimtc oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_asm_vault adg_standby_file_mode=omf

       adg_standby_creation_mode : config standby database creation mode in cluster 2

          1). adg_standby_creation_mode=duplicate :  use rman duplicate command to create standby database, default value

          2). adg_standby_creation_mode=restore_service : use rman restore services command to create standby database

              oratst -d tsaginimtc oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_asm_vault adg_standby_creation_mode=restore_service

LRGs: lrgdbconsasindx.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsaginitoflworkload.tsc - Common code for offloadgroup workload cases

tsagcrttbs.sql: create table for workload
     crtpkgtsagoffload.sql: define workload procedure tsagoffload.work_till_time
     tsaginitchk.sql: init sql running(pkg create, etc)
     tsagoffloadchk.sql: call tsagmdbchk to check SmartScan state
     crashcellsrv.tsc: use simulation event to crash cellsrv
     crashcelloflsrv.tsc: use simulation event to crash celloflsrv
     crtstartoflgrp4hook.tsc: create/start offloadgroup
     shutdropoflgrp4hook.tsc: shutdown/drop offloadgroup
     chkdurationstate4hook.tsc: check SmartScan state between certain duration
     chk0/1/2state4hook.tsc: same above, but seperate into two sub script
     chkdbstate4hook.tsc: check smartscan state from db perspective
     resetdbcelloflgrp4hook.tsc: call tsagresetdbcelloflgrp.sql to reset v$cell_state
     tsagresetdbcelloflgrp.sql: reset cell_offloadgroup_name if the case set this param at system level
     restartdb4hook.tsc: call tsagrestartdb.sql to restart db
     tsagrestartdb.sql: restart db
     tsagmdbworkload.sql: run workload for (specify) offloadgroup at session/system level
     defaultHook.tsc: reset *hooks.tsc for workload
     tsagoflworkloadtemplate.tsc: MAIN ENTRANCE, basic template for workload tests
     			    call before/mid/after hooks for each test

Followings need to initialize in the parent tsc
     tkrmlog
     tsagofllog
     sysdba
     chkduration
     midhookstart
     workloadtime
     pfile_path(for create spfile,in n-view, it's at ^T_WORK^/worklv^db_num^/t_init1.ora
     and sesql tsaginitchk.sql to initialize the sql

Description: tsagiof2.tsc - SAGE RDBMS instance crash fencing test

Crashes RDBMS instance while doing direct path IO's

- set event to HOLD IO
     - Fork sql which does an IO
     - shutdown abort RDBMS instance
     - check if IO fencing happened

     ***Note***
        This is how the test is now:
        ----------------------------
        inst 1 -> hold IO -> shutdown abort -> make sure table didn't get updated
        inst 2 -> donot hold IO -> donot shutdown abort -> do not check for table updates

        This is how the test should be:
        -------------------------------
        inst 1 -> hold IO -> shutdown abort -> make sure table didn't get updated
        inst 2 -> hold IO -> -> make sure table didn't get updated

        Being addressed:
        ----------------
        **The shutdown abort of inst 2 hangs **
        **If anything (inserts with HOLD event set) is done in inst 2, **
        **the shutdown abort of inst 1 hangs**

Test tsagiormmapping.tsc. setup=(none). flags: check_mode=excld_vol, dbobj=DB^dbname^.^dbname^, pdbobj=DB^dbname^.^dbname^.CDB1_PDB1, log_name=^tst_tscname^_^check_mode^.log. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsaiorm.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagiormmapping.tsc - check the IORM mapping

This test has below steps:
     Step 1: Check plan entry
     Step 2: Issue workload to CDB1_PDB1
     Step 3: Check the metrics
     Step 4: Dump FCGroup and make sure type is non-zero
     Step 5: Check IORM State Dump

This is common test script that will run in below setup
    1- ASM Standalone DBs (CDB and non-CDB)  : lrgsarslv1_nvc_cmainr19500/lrgdbconsaiorm
    2- Exascale Standalone DBs & Exascale Standalone PDBs
       (cluster guid is generated for them) without GI - lrgdbcsaiormvault
    3- ASM DBs (CDB and non-CDB) under GI (ASM scoped security configured)
       - lrgdbconsaiorm_asmsc, lrgdbconsamtciorm
    4- Exascale DBs under vault & Exascale PDBs under vault
       (Cluster guid is set from GI) - lrgdbconsamtciorm_excld?lrgdbcsaiorm1_excld
    5- Volumes in Exascale - lrgdbcsaexciormvol

   Original Request from Zak:
    - Common IORM mapping check
     Confirm the plan entries. Run the following based on the case type
     above: List vault/List cluster/List database/list volume/List
     pluggabledatabase
    - Issue read and write workloads to the DBs/PDBS/Volumes. Use tsagworkload.sql
      to run some read/write IOs-
      Dump FC cache groups - make sure FC group is
      created for the PDBs/ Volumes / non-CDB You can check the entry name, DB
      ID/Volume ID, and CDB ID from FC group dump. If group is created for them in FC
      dump and the type is not equal to zero, then we can consider that as successful
      mapping. If it is possible, we would like to confirm that there is only one
      group for each PDBs, non-CDB and volume. Note: FC group is only created
      for PDBs / Volumes / non-CDBs. We cant confirm CDB mapping from FC group dump
      (PDB mapping should be enough).
     - Check IORM metric:
     For DBs, DB_FD_IO_RQ_SM_SEC, DB_IO_RQ_SM_SEC,DB_FD_IO_RQ_LG_SEC,

Test tsagiotimeout.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: creatdev_file=mydiskdef, asm_read_cancel=10000, asm_write_cancel=20000, asm_cancel_alert_time=10, log_file=tsagiotimeout.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagiotimeout.tsc - Testcase for Project#55885 Client-Side Exadata I/O timeout

Project#55885 Client-Side Exadata I/O timeout tests, it includes:

       a)Testcase 1 : test for _asm_read_cancel
         1). Hang all read IOs in cell to trigger read/write IO cancel on the client side
         2). Run regular (non-Smart) read/write which takes longer than this value is redirected to
              a different mirror.

       b)Testcase 2 : test for _asm_write_cancel
         1). Hang all read and write IOs in cell to trigger read/write IO cancel on the client side
         2). Run regular (non-Smart) read which takes longer than this value is redirected to a different
             mirror.
         3). Run regular (non-Smart) write which takes longer than this value is cancelled, and its disk
             is pending. Since write cancel still requires some code changes, so only reads will result
             in a time-out. Writes will simply be held, this is because ASM metadata writes will pause
             at this time, as well, until the reconnect succeeds, and that should be the expected behavior
             without the write cancel offline support.

Description: tsagipcdatstre.tsc - IPCDAT stress test

IPCDAT stress test

IPCDAT stress test:
      ipcdat_stress is designed to measure the performance of RoCE and
    Persistent Memory harware ? but also runs in an ordinary ADE view. This
    test will start two processes: a server and a client.
      server:       ipcdat_stress -A 127.0.0.1 -i 15
      client:       ipcdat_stress -A 127.0.0.1 127.0.0.1 -n 2
    When everything works, it will create 2 TCP connections with 2 ipcdat
    contexts at each end, perform PMemLog-style IO across all of them for 5
   seconds, and display a set of statistics at the end including a histogram.

This is an additional test script after bug fix 37946606 where we check the
     latency for lsvolume reduced after the previous latency is cached for the same.
     Here are the test steps:
       1. Create vault and 200 volumes in it.
       2. Restart bsm service
       3. Run escli lsvolume --attributes numSnapshots and measure the latency.
       4. Run the step 3 again.
       5. Check the latency for second time has been reduced as expected

Test tsaglw_importance_caching.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0, cell_with_xrmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgsafciovgroup4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsaglw_importance_caching.tsc - orion test case for LW cachig by importance

Test case for LW caching by importance

Test steps:
     1. Run the test with LW flush, LW imbalance check, LW hd busy check
        disabled, fc_free_space set to 0.
     (1) Run unimportant LW with 64MB region of griddisk, nearly all should be
         absorbed.
     (2) Run important LW with 64MB region of griddisk, nearly all should be
         absorbed.
     2. Run the test with LW flush, LW imbalance check, LW hd busy check
        disabled, fc_free_space set to 100.
     (1) Run unimportant LW with 64MB region of griddisk, all should be
         rejected.
     (2) Run important LW with 64MB region of griddisk, nearly all should be
         absorbed.
     3. Run the test with LW flush, LW imbalance check, LW hd busy check
        disabled, fc_free_space set to 50.
     (1) Run OLTP write workload with 128MB region of griddisk, all should be
         absorbed by flashcache and takes 40% of flash cache space.
     (1) Run unimportant LW with 64MB region of griddisk, part of it should be
         rejected.
     (2) Run important LW with 64MB region of griddisk, nearly all should be
         absorbed.

Description: tsagmdbrsdeallo.tsc - Resource deallocation test

Check memory consumption when offloadgroup is/not in use
     1.  Create one offload group in cell 1
     2.  Run two workloads in two databases
     3.  Set workload is run by created offload group
     4.  Check memory consumption for two cells
     5.  When offloadgroup are shutdown the value should be 0

There is no paticular parameter to indicate the memory consumption of an offloadgroup.
     So we caculate the memory stat of all groups in v$cell_stat.
      1. total_osmem_all_groups in cellsrv memory node;
      2. total_osmem_all_groups in sga memory type node;
      3. total_osmem_all_groups in oflgroup memory type node.
      4.  when all groups are shutdown, the node oflgroup would be removed in v$cell_stat.

Test tsagmdbsimevent.tsc. setup=(none). flags: file_name=alert_^oss_port^.log, log_file=tsagmdbsimuevent.log. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsamdb3.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagmdbsimevent.tsc - Simulation events for MDB

Test Case 1. Simulation Event OCL_IPC_GET_FAIL
      Test Case 2. Simulation Event OCL_IPC_SEND_FAIL
      Test Case 3. Simulation Event OFLSRV_OAL_FAIL
      Test Case 4. Simulation Event OCL_IPC_MSG_DIE_INQ
      Test Case 5. Simulation Event OCL_IPC_MSG_DIE_DQD
      Test Case 6. Simulation Event OCL_OFLGRP_OPEN_FAIL

     suite = mdb3 : run Test Case 1-2
     suite = mdb4 : run Test Case 3-4
     suite = mdb5 : run Test Case 5-6

   For Test Case 1-5, we run different kinds of workloads to exercise different tags under each simulation
   event, but there is not SYSRPC test for Test Case 3-5.

       section = SI :  Run smart scan workload to exercise tags sicheck,si_write_population,
                       fpblock_process,ofl_group_stats,ofldisk_close
           The output file is tsagmdbsimuevent[1-5]_1.log

       section = FAST_FILE_CREATION :  Run Smart File Creation workload to exercise tag fcre_kuty
           The output file is tsagmdbsimuevent[1-5]_2.log

       section = IORM :  Run the IORM workoad to exercise tags iorm_kuty, free_memory
           The output file is tsagmdbsimuevent[1-5]_3.log

Test tsagmdbsuite.tsc. setup=(none). flags: temp_nowarn=^tst_nowarn^, dot='.', tsagmdbsuite=^rtest^, mdb_init_script='tsagmdbiormqmini.tsc', mdb_post_script='tsagmdbqm.tsc', tsnum=0, mdbtesti=mdbtest^tsnum^, unit_test=^^mdbtesti^'.tsc'. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgc9sacmainr12201r11204_bscn5.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagmdbsuite.tsc - The simple test framework to run multiple database version tests

This script is used to run mdb unit tests, the usage is :

        echo > cell_script.tsc
             > ....
        endecho
        let mdb_init_script 't_work:cell_script.tsc'
        let tsagmdbsuite 'tsagmdbsi,tsagmdbqm'
        let mdbclean 1
        let rdbms_version2 RDBMS_MAIN_RELEASE
        runtest tsagmdbsuite

     Please note: tsagmdbsi.tsc and tsagmdbqm.tsc should be created in t_source area by you,
     and the framework will fork to run them on database instances with different version

     mdb_init_script - This script that you defined will be run before running test cases concurrently
                        in tsagmdbsuite
     mdb_post_script - This script that you defined will be run at the end of tsagmdbsuite
     tsagmdbsuite   - define the user testing file names, such as 'tsagmdbsi,tsagmdbqm,..'
     rdbms_version1 - the default value is : RDBMS_MAIN_RELEASE
     rdbms_version2 - the default value is :  RDBMS_11.2.0.4.0_RELEASE
     mdbclean       - if mdbclean=1, it will clean all test env

      4) Attempt to modify "Disallowed" metricdefiniton

Test tsagmpkqm.tsc. setup=(none). flags: OSS_HW_TESTING=1, cellconnstr=root@^cell^. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagmpkqm.tsc - New quarantine feature for memory protection keys

New quarantine feature for memory protection keys

Adding a new test about quarantine feature for memory protection keys (mpk) to
     prevent the cellsrv from being kept down. The feature works
     by keeping track of how many mpk crashes there have been and turning off mpk once there
     have been too many. A new simulation event will cause an mpk crash:

     alter cell events="cellsrv_simevent[PKEY_RANDOM_CRASH] err_type=internal,frequency=1,count=5¡±

     It includes:

     1. Set _cell_mpk_quarantine_threshold to default value 3, after cellsrv crashed for three times,
        the event can't crash cellsrv in the fourth time

     2. Set _cell_mpk_quarantine_threshold to default value 2, after cellsrv crashed for two times,
        the event can't crash cellsrv in the third time

     3. Add corruption test by corrupting $OSSCONF/cellsrv_mpk_quarantine.state, then MPK will be disabled on
        the next cellsrv startup. Then the simulation event should have no effect.

     Concurrently running the workload in each clusters, check FC/NRW/MRW/ROW
     1. NRW stands for No-Read Write. This type of large write only happens
     when there's archive log write or backup write
     2. MRW stands for Most-likely-Read Write, which happens for large write
     on datafile.
     3. ROW stands for Read-Once Write, which usually happens for temp sort
     spill on datafile or tempfile.

Suites: EXAC_DB, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagmtcomf.tsc - OMF tests on MTC

OMF tests on MTC

OMF tests on MTC
     Test Steps:

     1. Verify basic DB parameters
     2. Drop PDBs pdb_tpcds and pdb_tpch
     3. Create PDBs pdb_tpcdss and pdb_tpch and open them
     4. Create tablespace tbs_10
     5. Shutdown/Startup DB - then check OMF files
     6. Create a test table on a test tablespace
     7. Perform PDB snapshot operation - then check OMF files
     8. Clone a PDB - then check OMF files
     9. Perform DB Backup using RMAN
    10. Create a backup restore point - check OMF files
    11. Drop the test table which was created earlier
    12. Perform DB restore using RMAN
    13. Verify the presence of the dropped table
    14. List all OMF files in the DB, which are not following the
        expected naming convention using ClusterID and ClusterName
        (We donot expect this for SI DB without Clusterware)

Description: tsagmtcadg.tsc - Setup Standby database for Exascale in MTC test fw

Setup Exascale Standby database in cluster 2 and the primary is created
     in cluster 1 (tsagmtcprimary.tsc)
     It uses rman duplicate command to create physical standby db in cluster 2,
     we can config it to use same/different vault with primary, plese note: inst1
     is bind with standby instance and inst9 is pointed to primary db in cluster 1

Setup Exascale Standby database in MTC test fw
       1) oss_mtc_adg=adg_indifferent_vault : Primary/Standby DB are created in different vaults
       2) oss_mtc_adg=adg_insame_vault : Primary/Standby DB are created in same vault
       3) oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_asm_vault : Primary is on ASM in cluster 1 and Standby DB are created on vault in cluster 2
       4) oss_mtc_adg=adg_hybrid_cross_cell : Primary is on ASM in cluster 1 and Standby DB are created on vault in cluster 2
                Cell    view 1(root view): setup Exascale full serivces, it servers for the standby db in cluster view 2
                Cluster view 1(cluster 1): setup GI/ASM/Primary Database, it uses the ASM diskgroups in cell view 2
                Cluster view 2(cluster 2): setup GI/Standby Database, it uses the vault in cell view 1
                Cell    view 2(cluster 3): setup Exadata full serivces, it servers for the primary db in cluster view 1

     Also introduce the parameter adg_standby_file_mode and adg_standby_creation_mode
          adg_standby_file_mode=omf : just enable OMF in standby database, default value
          adg_standby_file_mode=omf_all_convert :  enable OMF and db/log file_name_convert in standby database
          adg_standby_file_mode=omf_db_convert :   enable OMF and db file_name_convert in standby database
          adg_standby_file_mode=omf_log_convert : enable OMF and log file_name_convert in standby database
          adg_standby_file_mode=off : just enable db/log file_name_convert in standby database

          adg_standby_creation_mode=duplicate :  use rman duplicate command to create standby database, default value
          adg_standby_creation_mode=restore_service : use rman restore services command to create standby database

Test tsagmtcvictim.tsc. setup=(none). flags: fc_lw_size=50, dbid=^dbid_rel^'-'^dbid_rel^, cdbid=^cdbid_rel^'-'^cdbid_rel^, oltp_gd=sddlun3, lw_gd=sddlun4, cur_ossinst=1, cur_oss_devdir=OSS_DEVDIR^cur_ossinst^, OSSCONF=^T_WORK^. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsamtcvicfc.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagmtcvictim.tsc - Victim cache test on DBUNIQNAME

Victim cache test on DBUNIQNAME

1. We have two cells, in each cell, create two separated griddisks: sddlun1 and sddlun2
  2. There are two clusters, in each cluster, create one database with the same dbUniqueName
  3. enable ASM scoped security, sddlun1 is availableTo C1 and sddlun1 is availableTo C2

   Create 2 standalone GDs (not part of any ASM diskgroup), and make one available_to C1
   and the other available to C2.  IOV C1 uses C1 GD and IOV C2 uses C2 GD. Use standby0
   for C1 and standby1 for C2.

   Then copy C1's cellkey.ora for IOV C1 and C2's cellkey.ora for IOV C2.  This way IOV C1
   can impersonate C1 DB by using the same dbid, and IOV C2 can impersonate C2 DB by using
   the same dbid as well.

 This way, we can continue using IOV to launch LW vs OLTP workloads. It includes 2 cases:

   1) If there is no inter-DB IORM plan to divvy up the FC space between C1 DB and C2 DB,
     we should see both LW are throttled when OLTP is thrashing as is done in Dheeraj's
     existing test case.  This functionally tests that the victim cache continues to work
     even with ASM scoped security.

   2) Configure an inter-DB IORM plan to divvy up the FC space between C1 DB and C2 DB.
     Trigger OLTP thrashing for C1 DB only.  Verify that only C1 LW is throttled, but not C2.

   For the test about generic cache thrashing mechanism (ie. not hardmax
   groups), we need to satisfy the following criteria:

    1. OLTP workload must be larger than FC size minus LW size. eg. if FC
       size is 200MB and LW total region size  is 50MB, then the OLTP region
       size must be 150MB or larger.

    2. OLTP workload cannot be much larger than total FC size, since
       otherwise even stopping LW would have minimal effect. eg. if total
       FC size is 200 MB, and OLTP workload region size is 1G, no amount
       of LW limitation can really help the hit ratio.

Description: tsagmultibsmbsw.tsc - testcase for Multiple bsm/bsw if one bsw is shutdown
     while a find is in progress, we wait till the snaps and backups are moved
     to other bsws before returning.

1. oratst -d xblockini.tsc multiple_bst=true  iscsi=true, this will setup 2 bsm + 3 bsw env
   2. Create many volumes and snapshots for all 3 bsw's to share snapshots and backups
   3. list snapshots and backups to verify that all are id's listed
   4. kill bsw1 -  $runasroot "kill <pidbsw1>"
   5. Wait for 90s and verify its status is offline
   6. list snapshots and backups to verify that all are id's listed
   7. Bring bsw1 back

flags.multiple_bst: true # Inorder to setup 2 BSM + 3 BSW instances

Description: tsagnini.tsc - set up database diskgroups with disks in n oss servers

Set up database diskgroups with disks in n oss servers,
     where 1 <= n <= number of db disks defined in creatdev_file
     and n = OSS_TESTING.

     If not running with failgroup
     . use stkdefosm to create database diskgroups as normal
     . stop asm
     . stop oss
     . split disks to multiple oss servers and start the servers
     . restart asm
     . check that the disks are all accessible

     If running with failgroup
     . create datafile disks for additional failgroups and start
       associate servers
     . use stkdefosm to create the database diskgroups as normal
       This will also start the associated server.

At the end of the script, oss and asm are up.
    To collect cellsrv stat periodically in farm runs
    Please use the following config parameters
      farm submit <lrgname> -config "EXADATA_STAT_COLLECTION=true;EXADATA_STAT_NAME=CELLSRVSTAT;INTERVAL=10"
      Explanation of parameters :
      EXADATA_STAT_COLLECTION=true : Turn on stats collection
      EXADATA_STAT_NAME=CELLSRVSTAT/ECSTAT
      INTERVAL=10 : specify the interval of stat collection in seconds, for example-
                    INTERVAL=10 will invoke and save cellsrv output every 10 seconds.

flags.nflint: 1  ## No flint disks for appliance mode, already too many disks

Test tsagnini_startcell.tsc. setup=(none). flags: cell_is_online=0. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgcmainr12201r11204.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagnini_startcell.tsc - Start cell in tsagnini to avoid stkdefosm timeouts

Starts up a single cell during tsagnini.tsc before running stkdefosm if
     no cells are running.

     This is a performance optimization. stkdefosm will start CRS which wastes
     2 minutes trying to connect to the cell before timing out. By starting a
     single cell, we avoid this and other timeouts, saving 2-4 minutes.

     Steps:
     1. Check if a cell is already running. If so, we're done.
     2. Does cell_disk_config.xml exist? If not, run "cellcli -e alter cell..."
        to regenerate it.
     3. If cell_disk_config.xml exists, start cell.
     4. Delete oss_iorm.txt dump to avoid difs in iorm tests.

     creatdev.pl will eventually create the celldisks and restart the cell in
     stkdefosm.

To prevent difs:
     - Don't perform this optimization for remote interop or exadoop tests.
     - Don't start a second cell if one is already running.
     - Don't start a cell without cell_disk_config.xml.

     To help with debugging, we write the output from all startup attempts to
     start_cell_for_crs_out.sav.

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagnodereimage.tsc - File with code for re-imaging the node

This script reimages based on some pre-checks.
     Checks are as follows:

     The script first determines (1) Image version on node
                                 (2) Cell version on node
                                 (3) Image version in view
                                 (4) Cell version in view
     Additionally, skip_reimage & force_reimage flags are imported.
     If force_reimage is issued, re-imaging is done in all cases.
     Else, if skip_reimage is issued, re-image is skipped.
     If both skip_reimage and force_reimage are not issued,
     re-imaging occurs if (1)!=3 or (2)!=(4). Else, it is skipped.

     If re-imaging fails mid-way, the node is commented out
     and added back to the pool.

Test tsagnvdimmdbworkload.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsaremotepmemgd.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagnvdimmdbworkload.tsc - NVDIMM remote read functional test with db workload

Runs db workload on DXD griddisks and make sure all IOs are performed
     using RDMA. Hence CellSrv statistics (Total read block IO to be issued,
     and Total read block IO issued) don't increase before and after running workload.

Traditionally in Exadata, the storage tier consists of Flash disk and hard disk.
     To read a block into Flash disk or hard disk, database process on the compute node
     sends a message to CellSrv process on the storage node to submit CacheGet jobs.
     CellSrv then  reads the device on behalf of the database process and send the result
     back to database.

     Now with the advent of Persistent memory(DXD) in the storage tier (exposed either
     as a GridDisk or as a Cache) the read/write latency of DXD based disks is very small
     (in the order of microseconds). So involving CellSrv (a heavy weight process) during
     read/write operations will increase the latency. DXDs are byte addressable, so instead
     of using message based communication, one could directly do RDMA operations on the device.
     In order to keep the read/write latency as close to the order of microseconds,
     database process directly read or write to the requisite region using RDMA
     without involving CellSrv (for the most part).

Test tsagoclrh.tsc. setup=(none). flags: tstname=tsagoclrh. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgcmainr12201sacc2rholtp.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagoclrh.tsc - Test Cases of OCL RH

It is a new feature called OCL Region Heuristics (RH) for OLTP and
     Uncompressed tabled. The main idea with this feature is to improve
     CC performance in write intensive queries. Consider a scenario where
     we have a 1MB CC populated region and the following occurs read-write
     sequence occurs to a region (write, read, write, read)

     Currently our code works as follows
   1. When 1st write to a region occurs. We invalidate CC for that region
   2. When 1st read to the region occurs, CC is built again for the region
   3. When 2nd write to the region occurs. We invalidate CC for that region
      again
   4. When 2nd read the region occurs, CC is built again for the region.
   This constant invalidation and rebuilding is costly in terms of performance
   The OCL RH feature is meant to stop constantly re building CC for a region
   if writes to the region keeps occurring. The feature monitors each region
   and builds CC only when say 10 consecutive reads to the region occurs.
   That way we know it is read-intensive and CC wont be invalidated.
   When the first write occurs, RH begins to monitor the region and say after
   10 consecutive we unmonitor the region. During the time the region is
   monitored we dont build CC.

Test tsagoclrh_corrupt.tsc. setup=(none). flags: tstname=tsagoclrh_corrupt. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgcmainr12201sacc2rholtp.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagoclrh_corrupt.tsc - Test for Population Failure Tracking

Currently when we perform CC2 population in the background, there could
     be CC2 population failures due to data dependencies (Max numbero of CUs,
     CU too big, Output size too big etc). FPLIB indicates to the celloflsrv
     if such a failure has occured and informs the cellsrv to skip CC2
     population retries.

     For EHCC, this information is stored as a bit in the FC cache header which
     prevents subsequent CC2 population retries.

     for non-EHCC we dont have foreground CC population and hence the FC cache
     header at this stage is not valid and hence there is no way to hold this bit
     of preventing CC2 population retries

     With OCL RH we introduce the concept of CC2 Population Tracking. The bit
     sent by Fplib is cached in OCL RH for each 1 MB region and the region is
     tracked by RH till a write to the region occurs. While the region is being
     tracked, CC2 wont be populated for the given CC2 rewrite region. When a write
     to the region occurs, we assume the data dependency is fixed and we
     automatically untrack the region

     Thus OCL RH will now perform two functions
     1. Population Failure Tracking-Tracking those regions which previously failed
     CC2 population
     2. CC2 monitoring - Monitoring those regions that had a CC2 invalidation due
     to a write

          shutdown completes, restart the group, sleep 60 seconds, repeat

Test tsagorphanfilecleanup.tsc. setup=xrdbmsini. flags: media_type=XT, vault_db=DATA, tst_name=tsagorphanfilecleanup. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexcorphanfile.
Suites: EXAC_DB, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagorphanfilecleanup.tsc - EXASCALE: TEST CASES FOR
                                 ORPHANED FILES' CLEANUP

Test to verify that orphaned files are cleaned up
      after failed DB operations

Files can be orphaned after database creates files but
     cannot commit them due to various failure scenarios :
     Case 1 : A process creates file but cannot proceed to commit
              resulting in invoking abort which inturn deletes the
              file.
     Case 2 : Process death after create but before commit =>
              resulting in file delete from PMON/CLMN process
     Case 3 : Instance death - On instance fence due to death, EDS
              should delete the orphaned files

Test tsagparfait.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgsastaticscan.
Suites: EXAC_MEDIUM.
Description: tsagparfait.tsc - Automate Parfiat run and produce error report for user txns

Automate pd-parfait wrapper run against OSS source codes. It produces
     error report for any detected coding error or warning for possible
     memory issue at the end of the run, which generates a new diff file
     each time it detects the error/warning.

This test is meant to catch parfait errors in the user txns. Parfait is
     also run during nightly label build w/ report uploaded to parfait server.
     The goal of this test is to catch parfait errors before they are introduced
     in the label. Ideally nightly parfait report should not report any new errors.

     Please note that any changes to thirdparty - fastcgi should not be in the same
     txn as other code files. As parfait can only run against fastcgi or other non-cgi
     code files. It can not do both since parfait itself does not know how to build for
     fastcgi.

Test tsagpdb_fcsize.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: cell_with_pmem_cache=true      ## create pmem cache, creatdev_file=tsagrddef4, file_dest='+datafile'. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbcsapdbmaxsize.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagpdb_fcsize.tsc - Test for Bug# 34146527 - PDB FCMAXSIZE SET
                          TO 0 WHEN THE NORMALIZED MAX IS ZERO EVEN FOR ADB

This is about flashcachesize of PDBs in ADBS.
    In ADBS, PDBs flashcachesize is calculated as CDB_flashcache_size X
   PDB_max_size / Diskgroup_size in:
   https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/pages/viewpage.action
   ?spaceKey=~cecilia.gervasio@oracle.com&title=FC+Space+on+ADB-S
   But it became zero which is impossible in ADBS, when there are some PDBs
   whose sizes very small. When this happens, a normalization logic in IORM
   kicks in and flashcachesize for some PDBs becomes zero.

to be added in lrgdbcsapdbmaxsize

Description: tsagpdbcc2.tsc - Check CC2=65 in CDB mode

Check CC2=65 in CDB mode
     Create the CC2(imcfclv=65) table in PDB1 and PDB2 with same table name
     1. Connect to PDB1
     Turn on CC2=65 and create table tbl_65 cellmemory memcompress for query
     2. Connect to PDB2
     Turn on CC2=65 and create table tbl_65 cellmemory memcompress for query
     3. Connect to PDB1
     Query tbl_65, CC2 check expects SUCCESS
     4. Connect to PDB2
     Query tbl_65, CC2 check expects SUCCESS
     5. Connect to PDB2
     Turn off CC2 and query tbl_65, CC2 check expects FAILURE
     6. Connect to PDB1
     Query tbl_65, CC2 check expects SUCCESS

      pdb_section=2: Setup n cdb and 'n' pdb in each cdb with normal redundancy. Each PDB gets its own set of GD.

Description: tsagpdpf_subheap.tsc - test script for predicate disk/ predicate filter heap allocation limits

This script has 3 test cases
     test case 1: simulate event to allcate a 100MB chunk on subheap. Run a SI query. Then check
                  for ORA-700 soft assert and cellsrvstat have >0 stat
     test case 2.1: simulate event to allocate 10 chunks of 10MB on subheap. Run SI query. Then check
                  for ORA-700 soft assert and cellsrvstat have >0 stat
     test case 2.2: same with test case 2, only that we are testing a fplib bug by using "subheap_alf"
                  in the simevent
     test case 3:
       Step 1: set parameters _cell_pred_metadata_subheap_size_mb=1 and
               _cell_pred_filt_max_subheap_size_mb=100

Test tsagpmemlogoff.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: runfakeibsrv=true. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbcsapmemlogoff.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagpmemlogoff.tsc - PMEM Log on/off capability test within IORMPLAN.

PMEM Log on/off capability test within IORMPLAN.

PMEM Log on/off capability test within IORMPLAN.

     1) Start up all cell services, ASM, and db
     2) Fork/run a db workload that will take about 5 minutes; this should
        be some sort of PL/SQL loop that repeatedly updates a database table,
        the loop needs periodic COMMIT statements to force log writes
     3) Query PMEM Log writes from v$cell_state: value should be non-zero;
     4) Run the following loop 10 times:
        1. Disable PMEM Log:
           alter iormplan dbplan = ((name = <db_name>, pmemlog=off));
        2. Clear PMEM Log stats:
           alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_resetstats('pmemlog')"
        - Sleep 5 seconds
        - Query PMEM Log writes from v$cell_state: value should be zero
          Enable PMEM Log:
            alter iormplan dbplan = ((name = <db_name>, pmemlog=on));
        - Sleep 5 seconds
        - Query PMEM Log writes from v$cell_state: value should be non-zero

     5) Wait for db workload to finish

     SQL PMEM Log writes:

     select to_number(extractvalue(xmltype(statistics_value),
                                   '//stat[@name="num_writes"]'))
     "num_writes"
     from v$cell_state
     where statistics_type='PMEMLOG' and object_name like '%PMEMLOG';

Description: tsagpmemoff.tsc - test case for bug 33854422

Test case for bug 33854422 to ensure IO request bypass pmemcache
     if DB has pmemcache=off.

Test steps:
     (1) Create 2 test DBS (TEST5 & TEST6) and set default IORM plan.
     (2) Run orion small read workload on 150MB disk area with dbid=6.
         The entire 150MB region should get cached in pmemcache.
         DB_PC_BY_ALLOCATED for TEST6 should be 150MB.
     (3) Run orion small read workload on a separate 150MB disk area
         with dbid=5. The entire 150MB region should get cached in
         pmemcache. DB_PC_BY_ALLOCATED for TEST5 should be 150MB.
     (4) Change IORM plan. Set pmemcache=off for TEST6.
         This will trigger IORM policy enforcement. The TEST6 data
         cached in pmemcache will get invalidated.
     (5) Run orion small read workload on 300MB disk area again
         with dbid=6. All reads should be NOCACHE reads that bypass
         pmemcache. DB_PC_BY_ALLOCATED for TEST6 should be 0.
         DB_PC_BY_ALLOCATED for TEST5 remains unchanged.

Test tsagpq1mbalign.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: log_file=tsagpq1mbalign.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsage9.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagpq1mbalign.tsc - PQ 1MB alignment test case

When the DB server sends data to the cell in Parallel Query mode, it send them as granules. A big table will have multiple granules.
     CC2 handles data in 1MB chunks. Sometimes there is misalignment since the granules will not align to these 1MB chunks.
     In these cases, there will be a flashcache miss since data is not stored in the cache. We can see this as misses in flashcache.
     The number of granules has a dependency on the number of slaves (degree of parallelism-dop). So the test case Yali has mentioned will
     have the following steps:

       1) drop flashcache
       2) create flashcache to a particular celldisk/girddisk (to isolate the test)
       3) create a big table like lineitem table
       4) select max(val) from table with dop 2 (which gets this to cache)
       5) clear v$cellstate
       6) Do select again.
       7) Check the stats.

Description: tsagpredpxyrd_bug38087492.tsc - Test timeout cancellation for Smart IO Partner Read

Validates Smart IO Partner Read behavior when the partner cell hangs
     before responding to INIT or DATA requests. Uses simulation events to
     delay partner cell responses and verifies that timeout cancellation
     logic works as expected.

     Simulation events used:
       alter cell events = "cellsrv_simevent[PRED_PXYRD_INITREQ_DELAY_RESP] ..."
       alter cell events = "cellsrv_simevent[PRED_PXYRD_DATAREQ_DELAY_RESP] ..."

Test steps:
       1. Connect to cellsrv1 and shut it down.
       2. Execute a full table scan repeatedly. IOs will be directed to cellsrv2,
          which will begin building the CC2.
       3. Bring up cellsrv1, wait 60 seconds for synchronization to complete.
       4. Enable the desired simulation event on cellsrv2.
       5. Execute a full table scan again and check num_bytes_ptnr_hit and query execution time:
            - For freq = 1: num_bytes_ptnr_hit should be 0
            - For freq = 2: num_bytes_ptnr_hit should be > 0
            - Execution time should be < 1s
       6. Wait 60 seconds for the simulation event to finish and for stats to
          update on both cells. Collect state dump on cellsrv1 and cellsrv2
          to verify the statistics.

     Four test cases:
       PRED_PXYRD_INITREQ_DELAY_RESP freq = 1
       PRED_PXYRD_INITREQ_DELAY_RESP freq = 2
       PRED_PXYRD_INITREQ_DELAY_RESP freq = 1
       PRED_PXYRD_INITREQ_DELAY_RESP freq = 2

     Expected state dump statistics:
       Primary cell (cellsrv1):
         pred_pxyrd_read_jobs_succ                 = 0 (freq = 1); >0 (freq = 2)
         pred_pxyrd_read_jobs_bytes_returned_toPD  > 0
         pred_pxyrd_read_jobs_fail_initreq_timeout > 0 (for INIT simulation event); = 0 (for DATA simulation event)
         pred_pxyrd_read_jobs_fail_datareq_timeout > 0 (for DATA simulation event); = 0 (for INIT simulation event)
       Partner cell (cellsrv2):
         pred_pxyrd_data_req_received              > 0
         pred_pxyrd_data_req_success               = 0 (freq = 1); >0 (freq = 2)
         pred_pxyrd_bufs_purged_timedout           > 0
         pred_pxyrd_bufs_purged_timedout_bytes     > 0
         pred_pxyrd_get_jobs_ptnr                  > 0
         pred_pxyrd_get_jobs_bytes_ptnr            > 0
         pred_pxyrd_get_jobs_succ_ptnr             > 0

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagpredpxyrd_bug38178155.tsc - kcfis partner read failure tests

Testcases to check if kcfis handles proxy read translation failures
     gracefully.

     1.) Test that kcfis can handle the initial proxy read translation
         failure correctly:

         alter session set events=''27606 trace name context forever, level 0x10000000'';

     2.) Test that kcfis can handle the proxy read translation failure
         after IO completion gracefully:

         alter session set events=''27606 trace name context forever, level 0x20000000'';

     2.) Test kcfis session interrupt during proxy read:

         alter session set events=''27606 trace name context forever, level 0x40000000'';

At the time of writing this test, the size of kcfis request batch is
     fixed (128). To reproduce the original issue, one has to manually reduce
     the size to a much smaller value in addition to the above simulation
     events. If the size becomes configurable in the future, this test should
     be updated to better exercise the code path.

       since startup of inst 11 (ASM inst 11) after the shutdown abort hangs.
       This is to be investigated later on .

Description: tsagprodd15.tsc - Exadata Predictive Disk Drop Test with Flash Disks

Cell 1: Through cellcli mark two disks as inactive (alter griddisk
    FLASH0 inactive) and mark 1 cell as slow performing.
    The slow performing disk is taken offline

    3) The slow performing disk is replaced.
    4) At the end of the test, all disks are online

    Note: Originally the test was marking disks in the second cell as slow
    performing. But that brought the diskgroup down. So presently test
    doesn't do anything with the second cell disks.

Test tsagpushback_offloadqueries.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: (none). platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbcsascbug28.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagpushback_offloadqueries.tsc - Pushback predicate filtering

Pushback (Reverse offload) predicate filtering is now
     fair for serial and parallel queries running together. Before txn
     sidchoud_mpp_serialquery when a serial or low DOP query was run in
     parallel with high DOP queries, there use to be no pushback for the
     serial query. This was unfair for the high DOP queries since they
     disproportionately would get impacted by pushback (reverse offload)
     causing query time impact. This test validates pushback for a mixture of
     queries to ensure the feature is working as intended

Test tsagpwrcycle.tsc. setup=tsagnini. flags: oss_auto_manage_disks=true. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsadebugcli11.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagpwrcycle.tsc - Debugcli test

The test checks for the following-
     - Test -1 : Failed disk comes back normal after power-Cycle
     - Test -2 : Failed disk don't comes back normal (it will remain failed) even after power-Cycle
     - Test -3 : Simulate timeout for powercycle of a failed disk - disk will go to failed status
     - Test -4 : Powercycle a normal physicaldisk - cli should throw an error
     - Test -5 : Powercycle a normal physicaldisk with force- disk should be powercycled
     - Test -6 : Power-off command fails - Physicaldisk should go to failed state
     - Test -7 : Power-on command fails - Physicaldisk should go to failed state
     - Test -8 : Test backdoor feature

Test tsagrecreatexrmem_x11.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgrhx11sadaxorion.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagxrmemcachex11.tsc - Test for cache drop and restore when
                             FlashCache flush/cancel on x11

Test steps :
     1. We need to ensure that FlashCache, PmemCache, and XRMemCache
        do not exist. If they do exist, drop all of them.
        cellcli -e list <FlashCache/PmemCache/XRMemCache> detail
        cellcli -e drop <FlashCache/PmemCache/XRMemCache> all
     2. We need to change the cache mode to writeback to allow FlashCache
        to be flushed.
        cellcli -e alter cell FlashCachemode=writeback
     3. The first test step is to create the FlashCache.
        We can use the following command:
        cellcli -e create FlashCache all
     4. Run cellcli -e list <FlashCache/PmemCache/XRMemCache> detail.
        We should see that all three caches are present.
        PmemCache and XRMemCache both will show XRMemCache in the output.
     5. Run cellcli -e alter FlashCache all flush
     6. Repeat step 4. We should see FlashCache is flushed
        and only FlashCache is present.
     7. Run cellcli -e alter FlashCache all cancel flush
     8. Repeat step 4. We should see FlashCache is normal
        and all three caches are present.
     9. Run cellcli -e drop FlashCache all
    10. Repeat step 4. We should see all three caches are dropped.

Test tsagrecreatexrmem_x9.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgrhx9sams1.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrecreatexrmem_x9.tsc - Test for re-create the XRMemCache when
			is flushed the Flash Cache on x9

Test steps :
     1. We need to ensure that FlashCache, PmemCache, and XRMemCache
        do not exist. If they do exist, drop all of them.
        cellcli -e list <FlashCache/PmemCache/XRMemCache> detail
        cellcli -e drop <FlashCache/PmemCache/XRMemCache> all
     2. We need to change the cache mode to writeback to allow FlashCache
        to be flushed.
        cellcli -e alter cell FlashCachemode=writeback
     3. The first test step is to create the FlashCache.
        We can use the following command:
        cellcli -e create FlashCache all
     4. Run cellcli -e list <FlashCache/PmemCache/XRMemCache> detail.
     	  We should see that only the FlashCache is present.
     5. Run cellcli -e alter FlashCache all flush?
     6. Repeat step 4. We should see FlashCache is flushed
  	  and only FlashCache is present.
     7. Run cellcli -e alter FlashCache all cancel flush
     8. Repeat step 4. We should see FlashCache is normal
        and only FlashCache is present.
     9. Run cellcli -e create PmemCache all
    10. Repeat step 4. We should see FlashCache is present and
        PmemCache will be shown for both list PmemCache detail and
        list XRMemCache detail.
    11. Run cellcli -e alter FlashCache all flush
    12. Repeat step 4. We should see FlashCache is flushed, and
        all three caches are present.
    13. Run cellcli -e drop FlashCache all
    14. Repeat step 4. We should see FlashCache is dropped but PmemCache
        and XRMemCache will still output the PmemCache.
    15. Run cellcli -e drop PmemCache all
    16. Repeat step 4. We should see all three caches are not present.

Test tsagredocache.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagredocache.tsc - Caching online redo log in FlashCache

Test online redo log caching in FlashCache

Below is basic test steps:
     (1) Create WriteBack FlashCache in the test.
     (2) Have the table contain more rows, such as 128K rows, then the redo
         log generation is much higher.
     (3) Add "alter system switch logfile" to trigger archivelog write.
     (4) Check cell side metrics. The following metrics shall be non-0.
             "Number of redo log read cache hit",
             "Total size of redo log read cache hit (KB)",
             "Number of redo log read population",
             "Total size of redo log read population (KB)",
             "Number of redo log write to cache",
             "Total size of redo log write to cache (KB)",
     (5) Also check "list flashcachecontent" to check whether redolog is
         cached in FC. There shall be 2 lines, one is cachedRedoContent for
         primary database, the other is for physical standby database.
   list flashcachecontent attributes dbUniqueName,dbID,tableSpaceNumber,
         objectNumber,cachedSize where objectNumber = 4294967293;
     For example, the result might look like:
  CellCLI> list flashcachecontent attributes dbUniqueName,dbID,
    tableSpaceNumber,objectNumber,cachedSize where objectNumber = 4294967293;
           DGREDOLOGB      3009953870      0       4294967293      142036992
           DGREDOLOG       2294494054      0       4294967293      140795904
     (6) We also perform a FC stat dump for debugging reference purpose.
 alter cell events="immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_flashcache(dumpstats, 0, 0, 1)"

Test tsagreimage.tsc. setup=(none). flags: SKIP_REIMAGE=true, FORCE_REIMAGE=false, cell_imagv="", cell_cellv="", dbnode_imagv="", view_imagv="", view_cellv=^label^, image_needed=true, reimage_fail=true, cell_reimage_fail=true, dbnode_reimage_fail=true. platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagreimage.tsc - File with code for re-imaging the cell ad dbnode

This script reimages based on some pre-checks.
     Checks are as follows:

     The script first determines (1) Image version on node
                                 (2) Cell version on node
                                 (3) Image version on dbnode
                                 (4) Image version in view
                                 (5) Cell version in view
     Additionally, skip_reimage & force_reimage flags are imported.
     If force_reimage is issued, re-imaging is done in all cases.
     Else, if skip_reimage is issued, re-image is skipped.
     If both skip_reimage and force_reimage are not issued,
     re-imaging occurs if (1)!=(4) or (2)!=(5) or (3)!=(4). Else, it is skipped.

     If re-imaging fails mid-way, the node is commented out
     and added back to the pool.

Test tsagrestartexc_bg.tsc. setup=(none). flags: loop_count=1, interval=300, excserver=^command^, file_to_stop=^stopfile^, dbg_msg='RESTART EXC:DEBUG:', valid_excserver='egs,syseds,usreds,eds,ers,bsw,bsm,cellsrv,esnp,random,', sep=,, option=restart_esnp, restartlog=^logfile^.lst. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexcfail1.
Suites: EXAC_CORE, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagrestartexc_bg.tsc - Restarts an EXC service in the background

defmacro restartessrv tsagrestartexc_bg
     Following parameters can be passed:
      loop_count=<n> -> Number of times ES server need to be restarted
      interval=<n> -> Restart every n secs
      excserver=<ES server name>, like egs, syseds, ers, etc
      stopfile=<file> -> file marker in $T_WORK to stop the loop [optional]

Example invocations:
    (1) restartessrv loop_count=10 interval=500 excserver=egs
         => Will restart EGS Leader 10 times in interval of 500 secs
    (2) restartessrv loop_count=20 interval=90 excserver=egs stopfile=stop.log
         => Restarts EGS Leader 20 times in interval of 90 secs, but will
            stop if it finds $T_WORK/stop.log before/end of a loop.
