Description: tsagrh_dimm_poison_test.tsc - Real Hardware fault injection test for DIMM in compute node
                                   (bug-34538907 / 34548884 / 34572057)

This test injects failure into compute/guest node's DIMM and cause guest node to crash.
     After the crash caused by the DIMM failure, we verify the guest node status and check
     alerts and diagpack generation.  After that, we restart the guest node for recovery

     Without above bug fixes (bug-34538907 / 34548884 / 34572057) the guest node continue
     to run even if there is a DIMM failure and it will cause many different random errors
     to the process/application running on the guest VM

Test tsagrh_dstate_faultinj.tsc. setup=(none). flags: vmuser=oracle, vmpasswd=We1come$. platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhx9amdimonec.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrh_dstate_faultinj.tsc - D-state fault injection test

This script is replication sequence for MAA Bug-35784008, using Cgroup Freezer
     Aims to find any corruption caused due to D-state processes on guest nodes.

     Fatal bg processes in D-state causes the sick DB instance terminate, due to which after
     the instance reconfiguration some stale write from this bg process leads to Corruption.

Refer to wiki for details:
     https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/display/~rajeev.k.jain@oracle.com/Bug+35784008+Reproduction+using+D+state+injection

Test tsagrh_dstate_faultinj_cell.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhexaprovcluster.
Suites: EXAC_REALHW.
Description: tsagrh_dstate_faultinj_cell.tsc - D-state fault injection on Cell node

Testing out the D-state fault injection with CELLSRV, MS and RS process.
     Def: State "D" indicates Uninterruptible sleep generally related to IO.
     This state usually occurs when a process is waiting for data from
     a device. Once in D state processes don't respond to any I/O?s, even
     termination signal (KILL/SIGKILL). D-state processes exit their state
     when the I/O they were waiting for completes, allowing them to resume.

https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/x/JWzEGwI

Description: tsagrh_logon_storm_test.tsc - test for logon storm on half rack rh

This transaction simulates a logon storm using Last Transaction Emulator
     (LTE) utility in Exascale half rack envirnment

This test simulates logon storm and monitors CPU usage in the background
     A diff file is generated if the IDLE CPU usage dips below 50%
     The test collects the following data:
       - CPU usage
       - cumulative logon stat
       - cell disk open
       - cell single block physical read: xrmem cache
       - cell single block physical read: flash cache

Test tsagrhrunscript.tsc. setup=(none). flags: callername=^tst_current_name^, tscname=u^callername^_^rndm^^tsagrhrunscriptsuffix^, append_prefix='>', output_list='> '^log^, ALL_ARG_LIST=^ALL_ARG_LIST^' '^ARGVALUE^'='^^ARGVALUE^, NXTARG=0, ARGNAME=ARG^NXTARG^, ARGVALUE=^^ARGNAME^, value=^^ARGVALUE^, aws_cell=^value^, aws_cluster=1, aws_compute=^value^, aws_compute_asm=true, aws_compute_db=1, cellcli_prefix='@', aws_node=^compuser^@^cur_compute^, aws_node_twork=^aws_compute_twork^, fileprefix='.sql', script_file=^cmdfile^, outfilenm=^tscname^.log, macro_debug_file=^tscname^_debug.log. platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhexaprovcluster_livemig.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrhrunscript.tsc - The wrapper of invoking sqlplus/perl/sh/cellcli
         to run on AWS cell and compute nodes

The wrapper of invoking sqlplus/perl/sh/cellcli to run on AWS cell and compute nodes
   it requires cell or compute parameter
     cell=[1-3], mean run on cell[1-3] node
     cluster=[1-3], mean run on cluster x
     compute=[1-3], mean run on compute[1-3] node
     db=[1-3], mean run on cluster[1-3], compute[1-3] node , db[1-3]


   usage: how to run sql/perl/shell/cellcli

     echo > cell.dat
          > set echo on
          > list cell detail
     endecho
     tcellcli cell.dat cell=1 > ^outbasename^
     log append

     echo > checkimage.sh
          > imageinfo
          > echo "test value $1"
     endecho
     tsh checkimage.sh test1 cell=2 > ^outbasename^
     log append

     echo > checkimage.pl
          > system("imageinfo");
     endecho
     tperl checkimage.pl cell=2 > ^outbasename^
     log append

     echo > tsagcrttb.sql
          > set verify off
          > connect sys/knl_test7 as sysdba
          > set echo on
          > set trimspool on
          > set linesize 160
          > drop table t1;
          > 'create table &1 (c0 number, c1 date, c2 varchar2(2000), c3 nvarchar2(2000), c4 timestamp,'
          >       c5 timestamp with time zone, c6 timestamp with local time zone, c7 float(20), c8 number,  c9 number);
          > declare
          >  i     NUMBER := 0;
          >  k     timestamp:= systimestamp;
          >  l     nvarchar2(30):= ''stage22299'';
          > begin
          >  for i in 1..80000 loop
          > '  insert into &1 values (i,sysdate,''storage'',l,k+i,k+i,systimestamp,9999.99999,2,i); '
          >  end loop;
          >  commit;
          > end ;
          > /
          > 'select count(*) from &1 ;'
     endecho
     sesql tsagcrttb t1 compute=1 > ^outbasename^
     log append

The wrapper of invoking sqlplus/perl/sh/cellcli

LRGs: lrgdbconsars.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrs3.tsc - test RS behavior when zombie Cellsrv exists

Check whether RS waits for zombie Cellsrv to go away before starting
     a new Cellsrv

This test first creates a zombie cellsrv process: start a cellsrv
     from a script, kill -STOP the script and force kill the cellsrv.
     We check that in the presence of a zombie cellsrv, we cannot restart
     cellsrv in cellcli successfully - RS will keep trying to remove the
     zombie before starting a new cellsrv. We check the alert log to see
     if after 60 seconds, RS will print a message to the alert log and
     generate an RS-7445 incident. We then kill -CONT the script pid (the
     parent process of the zombie cellsrv), and observe if the cellcli
     command to restart cellsrv finally succeeds

Test tsagruniormpmem.tsc. setup=(none). flags: iormreflog=tsagiormpmem_off_bug^xrmem_mode^.log. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbcsaiormpmem2_xrmem.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagruniormpmem.tsc - Run unit test of IORM PMEM Cache

IORM PMEM Cache includes below Basic TestCase 1 and TestCases 2 : flash cache and pmem cache
     section - define which case will be tested
       section = pmem_wr_fc_wr : WT PMEMCache + WT FC
       section = pmem_wr_fc_wb : WT PMEMCache + WB FC
       section = pmem_wb_fc_wr : WB PMEMCache + WT FC
       section = pmem_wb_fc_wb : WB PMEMCache + WB FC
       section = pmem_wr_fc_no : PMEMCache without FC

A: Basic TestCase 1:

     1. Use multiple cluster test framework to setup two clusters:
          Cluster 1 is normal database, and Cluster 2 is 2 CDBs with 2 PDBs in each one

     2. Configure inter-dbplan on cell side, focus on three attributes: pmemcachemin/pmemcachelimit/pmemcachesize
        pmemcachelimit - soft limit , pmemcachesize - hard limit

     3. Configure intra-dbplan on db server side:
       a). Create two resource consumer groups on normal database in cluster 1
       b). Map user sessions to consumer groups
       c). Use CREATE_SIMPLE_PLAN to create and enable a resource plan for normal database
       d). Use CREATE_CDB_PLAN_DIRECTIVE and CREATE_CDB_PLAN to create user directives and cdb plan in Cluster 2 CDB1,
           config new_memory_min, new_memory_limit, memory_min, memory_limit
       e). Use CREATE_CDB_PROFILE_DIRECTIVE and CREATE_CDB_PLAN to create user profiles and cdb plan in Cluster 2 CDB2,
           config new_memory_min, new_memory_limit, memory_min, memory_limit
       f). Enable intra-dbplan

     4. Enable IORM on cell side
        CellCLI> ALTER IORMPLAN objective=auto;

     5. Fork to run different workloads via tsagworkload.sql on different consumer groups across normal database and CDBs
        Also includes CC1/CC2 workloads
         Consumer group 1 -> workload1
         Consumer group 2 -> workload2

     6. Verify result
       1). All workloads should be successful
       2). Check the stats in nvcache dump trace files, this need your help to clarify which stats should be verified.
           CellCLI> alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_nvcache(dumpstats, 0, 0, 1)"
           CellCLI> alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_nvcache(dumpgroups, 0, 0, 0)"
       3). Check the pmem cache limits about the intra-dbplans and inter-dbplans in oss_iorm.txt
       4). Display the pmem cache limits in list database and pluggabledatabase
       5). Check pmemcache/flashcache and flashcachecontent

     B: TestCases 2 : flash cache and pmem cache
       1. Setup exadata with flash cache and pmem cache, there are five conbinations
         1) WT PMEMCache + WT FC  : section = pmem_wr_fc_wr
         2) WT PMEMCache + WB FC  : section = pmem_wr_fc_wb
         3) WB PMEMCache + WT FC  : section = pmem_wb_fc_wr
         4) WB PMEMCache + WB FC  : section = pmem_wb_fc_wb
         5) PMEMCache without FC  : section = pmem_wr_fc_no

       2. Rerun testcase1

Description: tsagruniormqm.tsc - Run unit test of IORM Quarantine

qm_crash_freq - use it to define the cellsrv crash frequent
     skip_qm_check - use it to define when to skip check for QM message
     my_plan - This is the plan name of IROM on db side
     enable_iormplan - enable or disable iormplan on cellsrv side
     section - define which case will be tested
       section = INTRA_DBPLAN_SOFTLIMIT : use intradbplan quarantine to isolate soft intradbplan
       section = INTRA_DBPLAN_HARDLIMIT : use intradbplan quarantine to isolate hard intradbplan
       section = INTER_DBPLAN_HARDLIMIT : use iormplan quarantine to isolate soft interdbplan
       section = INTER_DBPLAN_SOFTLIMIT : use iormplan quarantine to isolate hard interdbplan
       section = CATEGORY_DBPLAN_SOFTLIMIT : use iormplan quarantine to isolate category plan
       section = MIXED_INTRA_INTER_DBPLAN : use intradbplan and iormplan quarantine to mixed plans
       section = MIXED_ALL_DBPLAN :  use intradbplan and iormplan quarantine to all mixed plans

Test tsagrunmtciormqm.tsc. setup=(none). flags: default_catdbplan='(name=other, level=2, allocation=50)', iorm_user='iormuser2/iormuser2@inst1', qm_crash_freq=1, iormdb_inst=1, excld_mode='_excld'. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsamtciormqm1.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrunmtciormqm.tsc - Run unit test of IORM Quarantine

qm_crash_freq - use it to define the cellsrv crash frequent
     skip_qm_check - use it to define when to skip check for QM message
     my_plan - This is the plan name of IROM on db side
     enable_iormplan - enable or disable iormplan on cellsrv side
     section - define which case will be tested
       section = INTRA_DBPLAN_SOFTLIMIT : use intradbplan quarantine to isolate soft intradbplan
       section = INTRA_DBPLAN_HARDLIMIT : use intradbplan quarantine to isolate hard intradbplan
       section = INTER_DBPLAN_HARDLIMIT : use iormplan quarantine to isolate soft interdbplan
       section = INTER_DBPLAN_SOFTLIMIT : use iormplan quarantine to isolate hard interdbplan
       section = CATEGORY_DBPLAN_SOFTLIMIT : use iormplan quarantine to isolate category plan
       section = MIXED_INTRA_INTER_DBPLAN : use intradbplan and iormplan quarantine to mixed plans
       section = MIXED_ALL_DBPLAN :  use intradbplan and iormplan quarantine to all mixed plans

We run a set of unit tests about IORM QM in tsagrunmtciormqm.tsc from
       cell view like :
         runtest tsagrunmtciormqm

       in cell view, there is no asm/db instances in it, so we use mtcruninrdbms.tsc
       to rewrite the macro to support sesql/sesqlfp to run in cell view, this can
       allow us to run the sql files from cell view. below is the examples:
         sesql tsagset_cdbplan 0 iorm_plan log=tsag_setdbplan_clu1.log clusterid=cid1
       It means we have tsagset_cdbplan.sql in cell view, then it will be copied to
       cluster 1 view, and use pcw_remote_exec to run sesql in cluster 1 view,
       when it is finished, copy the output file ^log^ to t_work under cell view

       There are two parameters in mtcruninrdbms.tsc:
         - clusterid, the default is cid1, it can be set to cid1 or cid2, it means
           that the sql file will be run in cluster 1 or cluster 2
         - log, the name of output file, if don't set, it is the same as the name of sql file

      For "sesqlfp", we should pass the connect string to sql file, eg.
        fork sesqlfp tsagwkld iormuser1/iormuser1@inst1 log=tsagwkld_sub_cid1.log clusterid=cid1
        fork sesqlfp tsagwkld iormuser1/iormuser1@cdb1_pdb1 log=tsagwkld_sub_cid1.log clusterid=cid2
        wait

      We have another wrapper - pcw_remote_exec_wrapper which can help us to run tsc file
      in cluster views asynchronously
       examples:
    	  for cid 1 ^max_cluster_num^
    	    CPFILE T_WORK:tsagstartasmdb.tsc HAS_MCL_HASW_^cid^:
    	    fork T_WORK:pcw_remote_exec_wrapper.tsc pcw_exec_tsc=tsagstartasmdb.tsc clusterid=^cid^
    	  endloop
    	  wait

      If you want to run tsc file in cluster views in sequence, please do:
    	  for cid 1 ^max_cluster_num^
    	    CPFILE T_WORK:tsagstartasmdb.tsc HAS_MCL_HASW_^cid^:
    	    pcw_remote_exec T_HAS_WORK:tsagstartasmdb.tsc node_nums=0 clusterid=^cid^ wait_for_complete
    	  endloop

Description: tsagsacellsigmask.tsc - test for cellsrv sigmask

Test for cellsrv to check the output of grep SigBlk
     before and after running cellsrvstat command (Bug: 36888230)

Test performs following Operations
   1. It checks for sigmask of all threads
   2. Add OSS_EL_SEGV_KGETRY with 1 occurrence
   3. After the simulation event is triggered, check if all threads' sigmasks are
      normal after the signal is dealt with by comparing it with the values taken in step 1.

   It checks for SigBlk by providing cellsrv pid.

    === Flow of test for Bug:36888230 ===
    1. Grep for SigBlk by providing cellsrv pid
    2. Run cellsrvstat -stat=exec_threadstate
    3. Again, grep for SigBlk by providing cellsrc pid
    4. Comapare values before and after running cellsrvstat are same

Test tsagsddsimu.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: creatdev_file=tsagr2def, log_file=tsagsddsimua.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgsasdd5.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagsddsimu.tsc - Drop erase tests with simulation event

Drop erase tests with simulation event, it includes below test cases:

     Test Suite A : Erase for Griddisk - the output is tsagsddsimua.log
        TestCase 1 - GridDisk is in HEALTH_GOOD state
        TestCase 2 - GridDisk is in HEALTH_GOOD state ¨C erase with force option
        TestCase 3 - GridDisk is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE
        TestCase 4 - GridDisk is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE ¨C erase with force option

     Test Suite B : Celldisk with one or more griddisks - the output is tsagsddsimub.log
        TestCase 5 - CellDisk is in HEALTH_GOOD state ¨C erase with force option
        TestCase 6 - CellDisk is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE
        TestCase 7 - CellDisk is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE ¨C erase with force option

     Test Suite C : Celldisk with no griddisks - the output is tsagsddsimuc.log
        TestCase 8 - CellDisk is in HEALTH_GOOD state ¨C erase with force option
        TestCase 9 - CellDisk is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE
        TestCase 10 - CellDisk is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE ¨C erase with force option

     Test Suite D : Erase disks with nowait option - the output is tsagsddsimud.log
        TestCase 11 - GridDisk is in HEALTH_GOOD state ¨C erase with nowait option
        TestCase 12 - CellDisk with no griddisks is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE
                      and erase with nowait
        TestCase 13 - CellDisk with no griddisks is in worse state than BAD_ONLINE
                      and erase with force and nowait

We don't start asm and db instance in these tests.

LRGs: lrgsaexcscldcpers.
Suites: EXAC_CORE, EXAC_MEDIUM, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagsendmail.tsc - Test utility to run a given test in a loop.

The utility accepts few parameters, checks for dif(s) and sends email

Usage: tsagsendmail [testname=<testname>]
                        [sleep=<sleep> | wait | diffcheck]
                        [ifarm]
                        [[email=<email_id] |
                         [[from_email=<email id>]
                          [to_email=<email id>]]]

     testname    -  The test for which the dif will be checked. If not provided
                    will use ^tst_tscname^
     diffcheck   -  Will wait or sleep only if there is a failure
     sleep       -  wait for 'sleep' seconds before exiting
     wait        -  Keep waiting till user enters and creates a file called
                    ^tst_tscname^.exit
     ifarm       -  will mail only for ifarm


    EXTRA options if required
    ----------------------------
     email       -  Both from and to email will be set to this email address
     from_email  -  To filter using the email id, if nothing is provided,
                    default will be username@oracle.com
     to_email    -  A comma separated list of email id to send the summary
                    mail to. Pass this within single quotes

   Example
       When running as part of user farm job, comment it in case you
       want to get notification after some step or just before a step is to
       executed use

          mailexa wait

       When running as part of user farm job, comment it in case you
       want to get notification about failure of the test and wait use the
       following option

          mailexa diffcheck wait

       If you want the test to sleep for sometime after some steps and
       recieve a notification

          mailexa sleep=x

            note: x in seconds

Test tsagsipersfailure.tsc. setup=(none). flags: table_name=tsagrectab, sysdba='sys/knl_test7@cdb1_pdb1 as sysdba', pre_checksum='_checksum'. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbconsasipersist1.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagsipersfailure.tsc - Failure tests for SI Persistence Project

Failure tests for SI Persistence Project

     When kill -9 cellsrv, we will not save/load imgs. So there will be no imgs.
     Upon graceful shutdowns, we save and load imgs.
     When imgs are created, SHMEM is destroyed. When imgs are loaded, imgs are destroyed.

Failure tests for SI Persistence Project

       run_srdbmsini: 1. setup exadata by running srdbmsini, 0. skip it when it is up
       restart_type : we have below kinds of cellsrv/cellolfsrv restart
         cellsrv_restart - cellcli restart for cellsrv
         celloflsrv_restart - cellcli restart for celloflsrv
         cellsrv_startup - cellcli shutdown/startup for cellsrv
         celloflsrv_startup - cellcli shutdown/startup for celloflsrv
         cellsrv_kill - use "kill -9" to kill cellsrv, RS will restart it
         celloflsrv_kill - use "kill -9" to kill celloflsrv, RS will restart it
         cellsrv_simulate - use use simulation event to crash cellsrv, RS will restart it
         celloflsrv_simulate - use use simulation event to crash celloflsrv, RS will restart it
         all - run all above testcases

       mode : run this file with different mode
          testcase  - run basic cases
            sitab_creation: whehter recreate testing table

          restart   - restart cellsrv/celloflsrv, then rerun SI workload
            workload - user defined SI workload
            workload_ref : the workload ref log

          loopstart - Run testcase mode in a N loop
            loop_num: the count of restart times

           randomloop - Random loop tests for cellsrv/celloflsrv kill/restart

       area : areas about SI persistent failure tests
          si_store_crash : SI restore Recovery crash quarantine
          si_rec_crash : SI recovery after oflsrv crash
          si_checksum : SI checksumming
          si_identity : SI store identity verification
          si_loader_crash : osssistoreloader crash simulation
          si_loader_save : osssistoreloader "save" function
          si_loader_load : osssistoreloader "load" function
          si_write : pending write consistency check
          si_ridx_chain : RIDX chain
          si_miss_state : missing/corrupted loader state file

      if you want to test SI Persistence with a speical SI workload, and use event to crash celloflsrv
         runtest  tsagsipersfailure mode=restart restart_type=celloflsrv_simulate \
              workload=tsagsichk workload_ref=tsagsiwkld

      if you want to test SI Persistence in a loop
         a). run all restart types in a loop
           runtest  tsagsipersfailure mode=loopstart run_srdbmsini=0
         b). run cellsrv_kill in a loop
           runtest  tsagsipersfailure mode=loopstart run_srdbmsini=0 restart_type=cellsrv_kill

      if you want to test SI Persistence
         a). run all restart types testcases
           runtest  tsagsipersfailure mode=testcase run_srdbmsini=0
         b). run cellsrv_restart testcase
           runtest  tsagsipersfailure mode=testcase run_srdbmsini=0 restart_type=cellsrv_restart

Test tsagsipurge.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: sys_group_name_11233='TEST_GROUP', log_file=tsagsipurge.log. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsage6a.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagsipurge.tsc - Basic tests for SI purge

Include below basic tests for SI purge:
     (1) single purge with wrong name
     (2) single group purge for an offload group with correct name
     (3) single purge for "ALL"
     (4) purge and queries running together:

We would like to merge the SI purge transaction along with some tests.
     In all cases, we should see the message "StorageIdx action params: PURGE group_name 0 0 0" in the alert log.

     We could add the following test cases for an environment where we have
     finished some queries and have non-zero number of pages (but without active queries running):
     (1) single purge with wrong name
       e.g. alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_storidx(purge, wrong_group_name, 0, 0, 0)"
       We should observe the message in the trace file:
         "OCL SI PURGE: invalid offload group name wrong_group_name. Error:10 (Offload group name not found)"

     (2) single group purge for an offload group with correct name
       e.g. alter cell events = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_storidx(purge, SYS_121210_140217, 0, 0, 0)"
            alter cell offloadgroupEvents = "immediate cellsrv.cellsrv_storidx(dumpridx, ALL, 0, 0, 0)"
       We should observe 0 num_pages in the dump file and message:
          "OCL SI GROUP PURGE: purged * (total *) pages for group * number of iterations *"
       The first two numbers should be equal.

     (3) single purge for "ALL"
       The general case of Test (2) in a 3-view setup. The messages should be observed in trace files of all offload groups.

     We could also add the following concurrency tests:
     (4) purge and queries running together:
       continuous purge and heavy-load queries running side-by-side

     Here, to be a bit more specific, please do the followings:
     1) create a table with 100MB
     2) make 10 copies of the table
     3) have one query run against each table with each query having at least a predicate, in addition to having continuous purge.
     4) Enable SI diag mode and run scans on tables
       - alter session set "_kcfis_storageidx_diag_mode" =1
       - scan the table again (if problems happen, celloflsrv will assert)

     1) create a table with 100MB
     2) make 10 copies of the table
     3) have DML modifying each the table (e.g. update t1 set col1 = col+1),
     in addition to having continuous purge.
     4) Enable SI diag mode and run scans on tables
       - alter session set "_kcfis_storageidx_diag_mode" =1
       - scan the table again (if problems happen, celloflsrv will assert)

     (5) purge and recovery running together
       continuous purge and "kill celloflsrv" running side-by-side
     Please do this on top of 4 (i.e. kill celloflsrv peridically while doing 4).

     (6) purge and griddisk drop running side-by-side
       continuous purge and "drop griddisk" running side-by-side

LRGs: lrgdbconsage6si1_excld.
Suites: EXAC_REGRESS, EXAC_STORAGE_INDEX.
Description: tsagsirec.tsc - SI recovery test

This test will exercise the SI recovery code: RIDXes become free when oflsrv dies and new incarnation
      of celloflsrv can use them again since free() put freed pages in the beginning of the free list.

    The below is the details in this test:
      1) Create the testing table
      2) wait for 5 minutes for SI summary
      3) issue the following query twice.
        sql> select count(*) from tb_name where col1 < 0;
      4) In the same session, please run
         select name,value from v$sesstat a, v$statname b where
            (a.STATISTIC# = b.STATISTIC#) and
             (a.sid) = userenv('sid') and
             (name in ( 'cell physical IO bytes saved by storage index')) order by name;
         We should see non-zero value with: 'cell physical IO bytes saved by storage index'
      5) issue a query in a loop for 10 minutes such as :
         sql> select count(*) from tb_name where col1 < 0;
         Meanwhile, bounce celloflsrv.
      6) In the same session, run the sql in step4, should see the value of
         "cell physical IO bytes saved by storage index" that is greater than the one that see in step4.

Description: tsagsmrebal3.tsc - Loop test that fills upa and frees up DG space

The test for bugs :
        35271102 -  STARTUP OF DATABASE FAILS IN CTWR BACKGROUND PROCESS, ORA-00600: MEMORY LEAK
        35271083 -  ALERT "INSUFFICIENT FREE SPACE TO REBALANCE THE ASM DISK GROUP: RECOC1" NOT CLEARED ON ANY NODE

     Test steps:
        Loop 5 times :
          1) Fill up the DG space
          2) Restart DB + ASM
          3) Trigger smart rebalance by drop disk for replacement from the DG
          4) Check asm disk status + warning alerts for insufficient free space
          5) Reenables the disk back in DG
          6) Frees up space in DG
          7) Look for clear alert

Test tsagsnaprman.tsc. setup=(none). flags: cdb=true. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbcsaexcsnap3.
Suites: EXAC_DB, EXAC_REGRESS.
Description: tsagsnaprman.tsc - RMAN tests for exascale snapshots

The test checks  backup and restore command on 4 (sparse, densily sparse,sparse
    child, chunk) tables on multilevel exascale snapshots.
    tab_sparse    - nearly entirely SPARSE (save perhaps the first block or two)
    tab_s_and_p_d - "Salt AND Pepper Dense"  - every  10th block updated in snap.
    tab_s_and_p_s - "Salt AND Pepper Sparse" - every 100th block updated in snap.
    tab_chunk     - one contiguous CHUNK of updated data representing a %10 section.
    For each of these four types of data we are going to test

     backup as sparse    copy       ....
     backup as nonsparse copy       ....
     backup as sparse    backupset  ....
     backup as nonsparse backupset  ....

      finally we will also test the restore
     portion of the puzzle with commands resembling

     restore (datafile ) from datafilecopy;
     restore (datafile ) from backupset;

      The outline goes aomething like below :

      1- create the snapshot test environment.
      2- populate the tables with 25000 rows, one 8K block each for approximately
         195M of test data
      3- build some indexes and clean out the base table blocks.
      4- create multilevel snapshots
      5 - testing a backup
        The cross product of all these tests looks like

        [backup to  , restore from ]                            X
        [sparse     , nonsparse    ]                            X
        [copy       , backupset    ]                            X
        [tab_sparse , tab_s_and_p_d, tab_s_and_p_s, tab_chunk ]

       6- delete backed up file
       7- testing a restore.
            restore the deleted file and run query to verify everything is correct

Test tsagsparse_si_cross_cdb.tsc. setup=srdbmsini. flags: logon='sys/knl_test7 as sysdba'. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbcsaspsi.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagsparse_si_cross_cdb.tsc - SI test on SPARSE DB across CDBs

Verify the Storage Index entries for the parent are shared among the
     snapshots within the same CDB and across different CDBs.

     Test overview:
      1) Create 2 CDBs
      2) Add sparse disks and disk-group
      3) Bring the CDBs up with  _kcfis_cell_passthru_enabled=true.
         This is to prevent SI from being populated by other DB activities.
      4) Create a table in the CDB1_PDB1, which will be the parent for
         snapshots
      5) Create 4 snapshots off the CDB1_PDB1
      6) Unplug TEST_SNAP3 and TEST_SNAP4 from CDB1 and plug it into CDB2
      7) Modify half of the table in TEST_SNAP2 and TEST_SNAP4, so that they
         get some RIDXes of their own.
      8) Run the scan on all snaphosts and verify the results.
         TEST_SNAP1 and TEST_SNAP3 should should have zero valid RIDXes (all
         should be coming from the parent). TEST_SNAP2 and TEST_SNAP4 should
         have non-zero number of valid RIDXes.

Description: tsagsparsedropgd.tsc - sparsedb test

drop a disk and let rebalance to finish with

   - no IO
   - a workload of reads
   - a workload of writes

     inserting rows and query them back out.

  6) delete the newly created file.
  7) Restore an RMAN backup of one of these new files... recover it...
     confirm the recently inserted rows, i.e. the rows inserted since
     the backup, are still there.

LRGs: lrgdbcsasparse27.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagsparseparent.tsc - Sparsedb test.

Test for renaming of a child's parent file.

- Create normal sparse environment with test_snap1, test_snap2, etc..
   - locate/remember all the parent file names in cdb_pdb1.
   - locate/remember all the child file names in test_snap2.
   - close test_snap1, test_snap2, and cdb_pdb1 (if opened)
   - ASMCMD cp all the files associated with cdb_pdb1 to a new directory (say) "+DATAFILE/PARENT_COPY/".
   - ASMCMD rm all the orig parent files from wherever they were.
   - now the part we want to test - RENAME all the kid's parents to their respective new name in +DATAFILE/PARENT_COPY
      via oradebug command , also rename's parent file location in controlfile
   - open test_snap1, and execute some queries on tables in test_snap1.  Be sure he can find new parent,
     opens parent db in read only
   - Also, confirm parent is in new location with a query from x$ksfdss_cloneinfo.

Test tsagsparserman.tsc. setup=(none). flags: exa_cdb=true, creatdev_file=tsagr2def, redund=external. platform: (none).
LRGs: lrgdbcsasparse26.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagsparserman.tsc - Test for sparsedb - rman test

The test checks  backup and restore command on 4 (sparse, densily sparse,sparse
    child, chunk) tables .
    tab_sparse    - nearly entirely SPARSE (save perhaps the first block or two)
    tab_s_and_p_d - "Salt AND Pepper Dense"  - every  10th block updated in snap.
    tab_s_and_p_s - "Salt AND Pepper Sparse" - every 100th block updated in snap.
    tab_chunk     - one contiguous CHUNK of updated data representing a %10 section.
    For each of these four types of data we are going to test

     backup as sparse    copy       ....
     backup as nonsparse copy       ....
     backup as sparse    backupset  ....
     backup as nonsparse backupset  ....

     to either sparse media or non-sparse media (e.g. "+DATAFILE" or "+SPARSEGD") and
      finally we will also test the restore
     portion of the puzzle with commands resembling

     restore (datafile ) from datafilecopy;
     restore (datafile ) from backupset;

      The outline goes aomething like below :

      1- create the test sparsedb environment.
      2- populate the tables with 25000 rows, one 8K block each for approximately
         195M of test data
      3- build some indexes and clean out the base table blocks.
      4- close and re-open the base pluggable and create test_snap1
      5- Rename asm files - because of the ASMCMD mkalias issue.
         One cannot simply (re)move a fully qualified ASM name so
         we need to mkalias for them so that we CAN (re)move the names.
      6 - testing a backup
        The cross product of all these tests looks like

        [backup to  , restore from ]                            X
        [sparse     , nonsparse    ]                            X
        [copy       , backupset    ]                            X
        [tab_sparse , tab_s_and_p_d, tab_s_and_p_s, tab_chunk ] X
        [+DATAFILE  , +SPARSEDG    ]

       7- testing a restore.

       backup file as describe in foreach loop
       rm the alias describing the file
       restore file as describe in foreach loop
       open the snapshot and run a query on restored table - close snaphot ......
       rm restored file
       reestablish asm alias back the original good child.

Description: tsagstatcollection.tsc - driver script to periodically collect stats

This is the driver script to periodically collect stats in
     Exadata/Exascale environment on farm runs. The stat results are saved
     in <farm result location>/exadata_stats.tar.gz.sav file

To use this utility in farm jobs, use the following config parameters:
      farm submit <lrgname> -config "EXADATA_STAT_COLLECTION=true;EXADATA_STAT_NAME=CELLSRVSTAT;INTERVAL=10"
      Explanation of parameters :
      EXADATA_STAT_COLLECTION=true : Turn on stats collection
      EXADATA_STAT_NAME=CELLSRVSTAT/ECSTAT
      INTERVAL=10 : specify the interval of stat collection in seconds, for example-
                    INTERVAL=10 will invoke and save cellsrv output every 10 seconds.

     OR to enable it in integration runs please add the following entry in
     tsagstatcollection_lrglist.dat
      LRG:<lrgname>:<EXADATA_STAT_NAME>:<INTERVAL> - to enable stat collection in single lrg
      SUITE:<SUITE_NAME>:<EXADATA_STAT_NAME>:<INTERVAL> - to enable stat collection in all lrgs in a suite

Test tsagstclusd.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: disable_newhome=false, OSS_AUTO_MANAGE_DISKS=true, stclust=true. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsage7.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagstclusd.tsc - Exadata Stretch Cluster with OCR/VD on ASM

The stretch cluster test case with OCR and Voting Disks on the Exadata Diskgroup(lrgsage7).
   The setup does the following:

   a) Set oss_testing to 4.
   b) Replicate Oracle Home(the setup uses the 2 home setup for ASM and DB).
   c) Configure OCR and Voting Disks on ASM(tclsaocrasm_init.tsc)
   d) Connect to ASM instance and create a diskgroup which has 2  regular failgroups
      and 3 quorum failgroups.The regular failgroups have 4 disks each with cellsrv 1
      and 2 serving one FG and cellsrv 3 and 4 the other.The quorum failgroups have
      one asm disk(not Exadata) each.
   e) Replace OCR from the default dg created by tclsaocrasm_init.tsc to the new diskgroup.
   f) Replace Voting Disks from the default dg to the new dg.
   g) Configure DB on ASM(tclsaocrasm_dbinit.tsc).
   h) Create tablespace,table on the new dg and run a predicate query.
   i) Run failure scenarios.
      1) Fork a workload and kill cellsrv 3 and 4 while it is doing inserts.
         See if it completes successfully.The FG served by cellsrv 3 and 4 goes offline.
      2) Restart cellsrv 3 and 4,the disks come online automatically.
      3) Switch back to cellsrv 1 and drop a regular and a quorum disk.
      4) Add back the dropped disks.
      5) Run read/write queries on the tablespace.
   j) Do cleanup.

Description: tsagstrindx3.tsc - Multi cell Test case for storage index

1) Load a table on a normal redundancy diskgroup
    2) run a query on the table that would use storage index
    3) Offline the primary disk
    4) update table (which makes the mirror dirty and hence require a rebalance)
    5) run a query on the updated table
    6) online the primary disk (this should trigger ASM rebalance)
    7) run a query on the table (the scan should go to the primary. ASM rebalance should make the SI on the primary disk consistent with the secondary disk)

LRGs: lrgrhx9sams1.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagsysloginput.tsc - Functional test for sysloginput

This test addes the functional test for txn xiaohshe_bug-32054460 (log relay support for auditd and other log files..)
     Documentation : https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/display/EXD/SysLogInput+for+Cells+and+Computes
       * Its a cellcli and dbmcli feature similar to syslogconf and syslogformat.
       * SyslogInput is a cell/dbserver attribute which can be set to configure system logging.
       * It makes persistent change to /etc/rsyslog.conf, so that upgrades will not overwrite the logging configuration change.
       * It is independent of syslogconf and syslogformat in that it can be specified with or without these settings.
       * The purpose is to extend log forwarding beyond just system messages (/var/log/messages).
       * This can be used to also forward audit, aide, and yum messages

     2. with EDV LW. EDV IO is considered as important but non high priority LW(important

Suites: (none).
Description: tsagtorniodxd.tsc - test for tornio cellsrv crash recovery

Find the offset of the DXD griddisk
   Do orion to write to the griddisk with small disk_end_offset
   Dump the full hexdump of the 40K to some file for reference
   Set simulation event to crash cellsrv (also corrupt the data) at next DXD IO:
   Use arbiter to issue 10 write 4K I/O to disk:
   cellsrv will crash, and arbiter will exit with error after some wait.
   Dump the full hexdump of the 40K to some file for reference again:
   Now bring up rs, cellsrv, and it should auto recover the torned blocks:
   Now we need to verify the 40K (4K x 10 blocks) region to verify if the recovery is successful or not.

test added to lrgsapmem3

Test tsaguwcache1.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgsafciovgroup4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsaguwcache1.tsc - test case for unaligned write caching

Test case for caching unaligned write into clean page for WBFC.

Test steps:

     (1) Run orion 100% small read workload on 100MB disk region.
         The small read is 1KB, i.e. not 4KB aligned. The small read would
         trigger FC prefetch and populatiion. At the end of workload.
         The data would get 100% cached.

     (2) Run orion 100% small write workload on 100MB disk region.
         The small write is 1KB, not 4KB aligned. All the unaligned writes
         should go to cache. There should be zero nocache write.

     (3) Repeat small read in (1). All reads should get cache hit.
         There should be no cache miss, and no delta change in population.

Test tsaguwcache2.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0, cell_with_write_cache=1, write_cache_size=256. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgsafciovgroup4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsaguwcache2.tsc - test case for unaligned write caching

Test case for WriteCache (aka FlashCache for unaligned write caching).

Test steps:

     (1) Run orion 100% small write workload on 10MB disk region.
         The small write is 1KB, not 4KB aligned. All the unaligned writes
         should go to writecache. There should be zero nocache write.

     (2) Repeat small write in (2). All writes should be redirty.

     (3) Run orion 100% small read workload on 10MB disk region.
         The small read is 1KB. All reads should get cache hit.
         There should be no cache miss, and no delta change in population.

Test steps:

         The small write is 1KB, not 4KB aligned. All the unaligned writes

Test tsaguwcache4.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: asm_disk_def=tsagrdmadef, cell_with_ram_cache=0, cell_with_pmem_cache=0, cell_with_xrmem_cache=0. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgsafciovgroup4.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsaguwcache4.tsc - test case for unaligned write caching

Test case for unaligned write into recovered clean page

Test steps:

     (1) Run orion 100% small read workload on 10MB disk region.
         The entire 10MB disk region should get cached.
     (2) Restart cellsrv.
         All the clean cache pages are marked as recovered after restart.
     (3) Run orion 100% small write workload on 10MB disk region.
         The small write is 1KB, not 4KB aligned. All the unaligned writes
         should go to flashcache. There should be zero nocache write.

Description: tsagvolclonestress.tsc - Using CURL, concurrently create clones for around 30 minutes

Using CURL, concurrently create clones for around 30 minutes. (Stress Testing)

     Test steps:
       1. Create vault, volume and volume snapshot using curl commands
       2. Assign execution time to be 1800 as we need to create volume clones parallely for 30 minutes.
       3. Take the batch value as 10. (this creates 10 clones parallely)
       4. Keep creating volume clones using curl command.
       5. After 30 minutes when we exit from the loop, wait for 5 minutes.
       6. Now check how many actual volumes have been created.
       7. Delete all the volume clones that has been created.
       8. Delete volume snapshot, volume and finally delete vault.

Test tsagvolgrplooptest.tsc. setup=xblockini. flags: oss_memleak_skip_restart=1. platform: EXASCALE.

Description: tsagvolgrplooptest.tsc - This test script runs a loop test case with 100 iterations where we create and delete volume group and other storage entites in every iteration.

This test script runs a loop test case with 100 iterations wehere we create and delete volume group and other storage entities in every iteration.
     In a loop of 100, run the same script - one after the other :
       1. Create vault and volume
       2. Create a volume group
       3. Add volume to volume group
       4. Delete volume group which would fail as volume group is not empty
       5. Remove volume from volume group
       6. Delete volume group which will succeed now
       7. Increase size of volume
       8. Create another volume group
       9. Add old volume to newer volumegroup, add vol group snapshot as well
      10. Repeat 4-6
      11. Decrease size of volume
      12. Repeat 8-10
      13. Delete volume snapshots
      14. Delete volume
      15. Delete vault
      16. Delete volume group

Test tsagvsn_tst_asm_setup.tsc. setup=tsaginit. flags: sparsegds=', virtualSize=10G', hd_size=1040, fd_size=256, gd_data=800, gd_fd=48, gd_reco=160, gd_dbfs=80, sage_mirror_mode=high, oss_auto_manage_disks=true, oss_failgroup=failalldbdg, asmdisks_created=2, creatdev_file=tsagvsndef, raw_path=^sage_diskstring_dir^. platform: EXADATA.
LRGs: lrgdbconsarslv1_nvc.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagvsn_tst_asm_setup.tsc - set up script for Enabling appliance mode in LRGs

This script sets up the test environment for Virtual Slot Number -
    ASM Fixed  Partnership test cases.

    USAGE:
    tsagvsn_tst_asm_setup hd_size=<size> fd_size=<size> gd_data=<size>
    gd_fd=<size> gd_reco=<size> gd_dbfs=<size>

    where hd_size is the size of hard disks (DISK0 to DISK11)
          fd_size is size for FLASH disks
          gd_data is size of datafile GD's
          gd_fd is size for flash GD's
          gd_reco is size for reco GD's
          gd_dbfs is size for dbfs GD's

    The gd_<..> parameters are reused to determine whether the respective disk#     groups are to be created or not. Note that if gd_data parameter is passed,#     CONTROLFILE, LOGFILE and STANDBY diskgroups will also be created along
    with DATAFILE diskgroup.

   If none of the above parameters is passed, it uses default sizes and does
   not create RECO and DBFS diskgroups.

This feature will only work in appliance mode. i.e
    1. There are 12 disks and 16 Flash disks
    2. Uses High Redundancy - 3 cells
    3. DATA and RECO disk groups are created on all 12 HD's (slots 0 -11)
    4. DBFS diskgroup is created on all of the 10 non-system HD's (slots 2-11)
    5. a diskgroup spanning all of the Flash Disks
    6. FlashLog and Writeback Flashcache on all the FD's
    7. ASM/Grid disks in each disk group are of same size

    Following are various constraints to enable appliance mode:

    1. Appliance mode is not explicitly disabled. (_disable_appliance_check,
       _disable_appliance_partnering)
    2. Diskgroup compatibility is 11.2.0.4 or higher. Note 12.1.0.1 is not
       compatible with appliance mode.
    3. cell.smart_scan_capable (sageonly) is enabled.
    4. All disks in the diskgroup are of the same type - hard/flash disks.
    5. All disks have the same size.
    6. All failure groups in the diskgroup have equal number of disks.
    7. No. of disks in each failgroup should be either numslots or (numslots -
       numdisks_system) where numslots is the maximum number of disk slots in #        the cell (info provided during oss discovery) and numdisks_system is
       number of system disks carved out of the cell. Today, default for
       numdisks_system is 2.
    8. There are atleast 3 failure groups and 4 disks per failure group.
    9. There are no offline disks.
    10. All disks in the failure group have sequential and non-overlapping
        slot numbers. Also, the first slot number is same across failure
        groups. (guaranteed by OSS)

Description: tsagx10efconfig.tsc - Create X10 EF config

Using this file, a test can configure X10EF like system
    with 4 TLC PERFORMANCE optimized FLASH devices (used for flashcache,etc)
    and 4 QLC CAPACITY FLASH devices that can host 2 celldisks each
    This script can be used in following ways
    (1) include tsagx10efconfig
        - Set sage_mirror_mode appropriately prior to calling this script
        - set only_disks, if you do not want to setup ASM
        - This script does not setup DB - It is responsibility of the caller
          (This script is kind of replacement of tsagnini, if called directly)
    (2) Second way to set up X10 EF is to set CELL_WITH_QLC_DISK=1
        In that case, tsagnini will invoke tsagx10efconfig by itself
    Example - To setup DB on QLC disks in X10EF mode, using normal redundancy:
       let CELL_WITH_QLC_DISK 1
       let sage_mirror_mode normal
       include srdbmsini

7) Unmount /opt/cellconf and remount it in Read-Write Mode

Description: tsagbug38366131.tsc - Bug 38366131 - OCI:: PHX::MULTIPLE HARDDISKS
                     CONFINED DURING SCRUB DUE TO SOME IO HANG OVER 90S

Bug 38366131: remove undrained cancelled IOs confinement trigger.
     As long as there are IO completions, do not confine the disk for hang.

     The test starts read worklaod and simulates BLOCKIO_READ_HANG to trigger
     disk temporary hang which would generate undrained cancelled read IO.
     Then the test starts write workload which would clear the disk's hang
     but the disk still has the undrained cancelled read IO. As long as
     the write workload is active, Cellsrv will not confine the disk for hang.

Description: tsagbug38375591.tsc - Functional test for bug 38375591

Verify correct handling of SEL events in MS: skip empty alerts for
     non-matching GUIDs and trigger IO hang alert for matching GUIDs on
     celldisks.

1) Change cell trace level to finer.
     2) Shut down MS.
     3) Store output of get_SEL.sh in /tmp/file1.
     4) Add a line to file1 with non-matching GUID, incrementing ID and time.
     5) Modify get_SEL.sh to output content of file1.
     6) Start up MS.
     7) Wait for 'Alert message is empty, skipping...' in ms-odl.trc.
     8) Change cell trace level back to fine.
     9) Shut down MS.
     10) Modify file1 by adding another line with matching GUID.
     11) Start up MS.
     12) Wait for IO hang alert on expected celldisk in ms-odl.trc.
     13) Restore get_SEL.sh.
     14) Remove /tmp/file1.

Test tsagbug38397771.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: (none). platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug38397771.tsc - testcase for bug 38397771

Test Overview: This test validates the behavior and recovery of SYSEDS
     fence metadata files when they are deleted after an ERS restart

Steps to Reproduce:
      - Identify the Exascale node ID of ERS (for example, node ID 81).
      - Locate and open any ERS trace file under trace dir to confirm the
        assigned node ID.
      - Restart the ERS service to trigger EGS to broadcast a fence to SYSEDS
      - In the SYSEDS fence directory, find the fence metadata file
        corresponding to the target node ID (e.g., fence_metadata_197).
      - Manually remove the .copy file and empty the .header file for the
        identified metadata.
      - Restart the ERS service again to trigger another fence event.
      - Verify that SYSEDS remains active and that the previously removed
        metadata files (.copy and .header) have been recreated and repopulated
      - Check system logs for an ORA-00700 error indicating recovery of the
        fence metadata file.
      - Confirm that the copy1 or copy2 file and the header file for the
        concerned metadata are present and populated in the fence directory.

Test tsagbug38414502.tsc. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: (none).
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagbug38414502.tsc - Test for bug 38414502

Due to bug 38414502, if MS restarts during a disk failure on a multi-FDOM
     flash card, only one FDOM may get the failure flag. This leaves FDOM states
     inconsistent, causing the flash card to be stuck in "powering off" and preventing
     a failure alert. The fix ensures all FDOMs correctly track pending failures or
     degradations, even after an MS restart.

      8. Cleanup : Remove both the vaults, and startup the USREDS on cell2 and cell 3

Test tsagexcegsdiskrebuild.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: sage_mirror_mode=high, max_rpm=20000, delta_sync=true, exc_normal=disable, exc_in_performance_testing=true, oss_multims_testing=true. platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagexcegsdiskrebuild.tsc - TEST For EGS_DISK_REBUILD Feature

The txn tests the EGS_DISK_REBUILD Feature
     The EGS_DISK_REBUILD feature restricts each disk to be used for the
      rebuild COPY operations of the earliest disk failure. This way, there
      should be less disk resource contention because a smaller number of
      disk IOs will be issued to each disk at a given time.

     Testing deals with simulation of failures on multiple disks and ensure
      the disk rebuild operations are based on the timestamp of failure one
      by one with the help of script - tsagexcrebuildtest.sh

     In summary, the rebuildtest.sh checks to ensure that any REBUILD COPY
     operations that belong to a later disk failure event must be
     processed after all REBUILD COPY operations that belong to an earlier
     disk failure event have been processed, for a given disk that is being
     used as either the source disk or the target disk of the REBUILD COPY
     operations. Specifically, there are some operations that are force
     started due to some dependency logic. These force started operations
     are ignored.

Test tsagexcerssecurity_zap1.tsc. setup=tsagexastackup. flags: (none). platform: EXASCALE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagexcerssecurity_zap1.tsc - security test on ERS endpoint using ZAP

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
ZAP Automated Security Test:
This script automatically runs a full security scan on API endpoints.
It installs Java + ZAP if needed, sets up SSL trust, and runs:
  1. Spider   - explores and maps all hidden URLs.
  2. Active Scan - sends crafted attacks (SQLi, XSS, etc.) to find issues.
  3. Fuzzer   - injects malicious payloads to test input validation.
It authenticates via admin:welcome1, fetches Bearer tokens dynamically,
runs all endpoints from a YAML file, and generates HTML + JSON reports.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Description: tsagrh_bug35824385.sh

This is a testcase to check net.ipv4.ip_forward consistency on KVM hosts pre/post upgrade (Bug #35824385).
     But net.ipv4.ip_forward should be set to 1 only on NAT'd system (Bug #35852020).
     For non NAT deployment vm_maker will correct this if it was set wrong, post upgrade when vm_maker kicks
     in it sees that the setting is wrong for this machine and corrects it

     Testcase brief:
       Before the compute upgrade, we set parameters as described in Bug testcase.
        Set in-memory net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1
        Set in-disk net.ipv4.ip_forward = 0

       Upgrade KVM Hosts

       After Upgrade check for in-memory net.ipv4.ip_forward, should be 0 for non Nat'd system
        Check in-memory net.ipv4.ip_forward = 0

Test tsagrh_bug36263733.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhexaprovcluster.
Suites: EXAC_REALHW.
Description: tsagrh_bug36263733.sh - test script for bug 36263733 (aka 35496061)

This test verifies the proper functioning of the vm_maker utility's bridge management feature
     on KVM guest nodes. Specifically, it validates the creation and removal of a network bridge with
     a VLAN, ensuring that bridge removal works correctly even if the bridge definition file has been
     renamed. The test is applicable to all SE branches and both fresh and upgraded environments.

Steps to Reproduce:
      - Use vm_maker to create a guest VM with a bridge on a guest node [EXPECT PASS].
      - Use vm_maker to add a single bridge with 'vm_maker --add-single-bridge [BRIDGE_NAME] --vlan [VLAN_ID]'
          on the guest node [EXPECT PASS].
      - Locate a bridge definition file under /EXAVMIMAGES/GuestImages/[GUEST_NAME];
          rename 'vmbondeth0.xml' to 'vmbondeth0.[NEW_VLAN_ID].xml' on the guest node [EXPECT PASS].
      - Use vm_maker to remove the bridge with 'vm_maker --remove-bridge [BRIDGE_NAME] --vlan [VLAN_ID]'
          on the guest node [EXPECT PASS].

   MODIFIED   (MM/DD/YY)
   kuashen     09/08/25 - Creation

Description: tsagrh_bug_38081703.sh - Check rocelinkinfo after switch SSH setup after `sudo su` on a non-root user

This script is related to bug 38081703. It ensures that running
     rocelinkinfo works correctly after setting up switch SSH equivalency
     from a root shell. The issue occurred when setup was done as a non-root
     user and then rocelinkinfo failed even after switching to root.

   REPRO STEPS (prior to fix):
     1. ssh <non-root user>@scaqai13adm07.us.oracle.com
     2. sudo su -    # switch to root
     3. /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/setup_switch_ssh_equiv.sh <switch_list>
     4. /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/rocelinkinfo

     The issue was that rocelinkinfo would still fail even when run as root if
     setup_switch_ssh_equiv.sh was run after switching to root from a non-root user.

Test tsagrh_clone_basedb_vm.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrh_clone_basedb_vm.sh - RH test script for clone basedb vm

This script pefroms following steps to create a basedb vm clone:
     Prereq:
     Create a single guest XML, with network IPs for the cloned guest, and convert the XML to a basedb config.
     This is a edv volume level clone of a basedb virtual machine
     Steps:
     1. List the volume details that will be used by the cloned guest
     2. List the volumes used by the parent guest that will be used for snapshot and clone
     3. Shut down the parent and guest for a consistent Snapshot
     4. Create snapshots of volumes used by the parent guest listed in Step 3, for both system and basedb volumes
     5. Use the snapshot created above to create volume clones and name them the same as listed in Step 2
     6. Attach Cloned volumes using the same deviceName as listed in Step 2 with KVM host initiator of the parent KVM host
     7. List the devices to verify if those are reflected on the target KVM host
     8. For install.sh to reuse the EDV volume without recreate it, set up the property REUSEEDVVOLUMEIFEXIT=true for non-cloud
     9. Finally, run the Create Basedb step using install.sh to create cloned guest

     We also perform database clone validation here, we write some sql data to parent VM before the cloning
     and we validate the DB on the cloned VM by looking for same data is accessible from cloned VM.

     Addtional Bug tests added as part of the automatiom:
     37916820, 38225309 (38199281)

Wiki: https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/x/ofYixgM

   MODIFIED   (MM/DD/YY)
   sadwe       09/13/25 - Creation

Test tsagrh_dimm_ue_egssrv.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhexaprovcluster.
Suites: EXAC_REALHW.
Description: tsagrh_dimm_ue_egssrv.sh - RH DMM_UE fault test on EGSSRV

This test injects DIMM_UW fault on the EGSSRV using hwpoison utility
     Follows below steps:
     1. Disable secureboot and reboot Cell1 to apply changes
     2. Make the EGS Leader to switch to Cell1
         2.1- Shutdown EGS servers on two cells (do not shutdown EGS on node X).
         2.2- Wait 5 seconds.
         2.3- Shutdown EGS servers on two remaining nodes (do not shutdown EGS on node X).
         2.4- Startup EGS on the two cells from step (1).
         2.5- Wait 5 seconds -> Node X should become the leader.
         2.6- Startup the remaining EGS servers.
     3. Inject fault to physical address of EGS
         3.1- Get EGSSRV PID
         3.2- Fetch virtual adddresser mapped to PID
         3.3- Convert virtual address to physical addresses
         3.4- Echo addresses to /sys/kernel/debug/hwpoison/corrupt-pfn
     5. Restart CELLSRV to trigger I/O's on EGS
     6. Verify if EGS is stared with new PID
     7. Enable secureboot and reboot Cell1 to apply changes

If there are any crashes seen in the stimulation then watson should catch them.

                          sometimes take more time and cellcli drop alerthistory fail

   sadwe       01/10/25 - Creation

Description: tsagrh_list_ers_ip.sh - Verifies that the result of command `escli lswallet --attributes restEndPoint` matches the expected ERS IP.

This script connects to the first compute node in the cluster, retrieves the restEndPoint value
     from the EGS wallet using escli, and compares it against the expected ERS_IP. It is intended to
     validate proper EGS registration in Exascale environments.

     Steps:
       1. Parse input arguments: log suffix and compute node list.
       2. Skip execution if not running in an Exascale environment.
       3. Connect to the first compute node.
       4. Retrieve the restEndPoint value from escli lswallet.
       5. Compare it with the expected global ERS_IP.
       6. Log the result and return appropriate status.

Test tsagrh_live_migration.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhexaprovcluster_livemig.
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrh_live_migration.sh - Script to setup and prepare node with UDP for live migration

This script assumes that input cells compute_node
     and guest/gi/db cluster info from $T_WORK/clusterinfo.sav
     This script is based on the wiki https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/x/9_Set
     In section VIRTIO Live Migration Steps (From PT_LM Branch - No Secure Fabric)

   Steps :

    1. Provision the env with PTLM label series, with database is up and operational
       Reimaging the environment is done by doimageoeda.sh -xml  <xml file path>
       In the current configuration file, the oeda deploy xml
       2 compute nodes, 3 cell nodes, and 1 cluster.

    ***   tsagrh_live_migration.sh starts from step 2 ***

    2. Update RAC communication to use UDP instead of RDS
       stop database and shutdown clusterware on each guests

    3. Shutdown all guests

    4. Configure Virtio network interfaces

       a)Create bridge interfaces vmre0 and vmre1 on the KVM host using re0/re1 as
         the physical interfaces and plumb IPs to the vmre0/vmre1 interfaces
         Modify re0/re1 interface to use bridge vmre0/vmre1 interface

       b)Using virsh domiflist <guest_domain_name> and note the hostdev and mac address
         Replace hostdev interfaces from the guest with type bridge,virtio interface
         vmre0/vmre1 while keeping same mac addresses as before

   5) Update Cells node for UDP

      a) Disable cellwall

      b) Append _skgxp_dynamic_protocol=2 and _skgxp_ant_options=1
          to  $OSSCONF/cellinit.ora

      c) Restart rs and cellsrv


   6) Update guest to recognize new network inteface from step 4b.

       a)Check on guest and grab new internet mac to set in 70-persistent-net.rules

       b)Update 70-persistent-net.rules with new mac from re0 / re1

   7) Configure guest with UDP mode

      a) Append _skgxp_dynamic_protocol=2 ,_skgxp_ant_options=1" >> /etc/oracle/cell/network-config/cellinit.ora

      b) Execute make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_g ioracle at Database Home

      c) Unlock crs and Execute make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_g ioracle at GI Home

      d) Update $GI_HOME/bin/oradism file permission and lock crs again

   8) Stop Guests

   9) Define Shared Storage

       9.1) Use targetcli to create backstores/fileio for all guest images

         a) create backstores/fileio

         b) create iscsi client (note target name to be used in later step)

         c) create luns to connect with backstores/fileio to iscsi client

         d) create ACLS for each of the client accessing this client(from step b)

            The ACLS are for iscsi clients from KVM hosts
            INITIATOR_NAME cat be found in /etc/iscsi/initiatorname.iscsi

            ex: InitiatorName=iqn.1988-12.com.oracle:1fe0e187abf3

       9.2) Expose ISCSI to local drive and for target VM

            a) Using internal/private IP from re0 or re1 to create storage pool (
               with device path from ISCSI client target name in Step 5.1b
               using virsh pool-define
            b) start the storage pool using virsh pool-start
               iscsi storage should be mount at /dev/disk/by-path/ip*

       9.3) Modify VM's disks to use new ISCSI luns from storage pool above
            Guest is using local physical disks on compute host,
            removing current mount points, and attaching to ISCSI storage luns

            a) Detach each of the current storage mount from the guest
               virsh domblklist scaqap10adm01vm01.us.oracle.com
		 Target   Source
         	-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
              sda      /EXAVMIMAGES/GuestImages/scaqap10adm01vm01.us.oracle.com/System.img
              sdb      /EXAVMIMAGES/GuestImages/scaqap10adm01vm01.us.oracle.com/grid19.19.0.0.230418.img
              sdc      /EXAVMIMAGES/GuestImages/scaqap10adm01vm01.us.oracle.com/db19.19.0.0.230418_3.img
              sdd      /EXAVMIMAGES/GuestImages/scaqap10adm01vm01.us.oracle.com/u01.img

            b) Attach each of the storage mount with luns mount from ISCSI storage
	 Align them with the proper target (sda, sdb, sdc...) on the guest from virsh domblklist cmd

	 virsh domblklist scaqap10adm01vm01.us.oracle.com

	 Target   Source
         --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
		sda      /dev/disk/by-path/ip-192.170.216.32:3260-iscsi-iqn.2003-01.org.linux-iscsi.scaqap10adm01.x8664:sn.501a966a6afc-lun-0
		sdb      /dev/disk/by-path/ip-192.170.216.32:3260-iscsi-iqn.2003-01.org.linux-iscsi.scaqap10adm01.x8664:sn.501a966a6afc-lun-1
		sdc      /dev/disk/by-path/ip-192.170.216.32:3260-iscsi-iqn.2003-01.org.linux-iscsi.scaqap10adm01.x8664:sn.501a966a6afc-lun-2
		sdd      /dev/disk/by-path/ip-192.170.216.32:3260-iscsi-iqn.2003-01.org.linux-iscsi.scaqap10adm01.x8664:sn.501a966a6afc-lun-3


  10) Startup Guests, and Verify CRS status
      Verify that guest is reachable and ready for migration

      Completing Step 1 to Step 10, the environment is ready for Live Migration

  11) Perform live migration guest1 from clustersList on compute1 to compute2 and back
      Repeating the migration back and forth for 10 times.


  12) Check CRS cluster status after migration completed

Test tsagrh_oedacli_guest_edv_ops.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhexaprovcluster_onprem_multi_vm.
Suites: EXAC_REALHW.
Description: tsagrh_oedacli_guest_edv_ops.sh - RH script for oedacli API for edv

This script perfrom follwoing steps:
      1. Change the default password of the guest (using $ passwd, set it to welcome5)
      2. ALTER MACHINE ACTION=CREATEVOLUME VOLNAME=vol_sadwe WHERE HOSTNAME=scaqaw03adm01vm01
      3. ALTER MACHINE ACTION=ATTACHVOLUME VOLNAME=vol_sadwe WHERE HOSTNAME=scaqaw03adm01vm01 STEPNAME= ATTACH_VOLUME
      4. Login to guest and verify the volume attached using lsblk
      5. ALTER MACHINE ACTION=DETACHVOLUME VOLNAME=vol_sadwe WHERE HOSTNAME=scaqaw03adm01vm01 STEPNAME= DETACH_VOLUME
      6. Login to guest and verify the volume attached using lsblk are removed
      7. ALTER MACHINE ACTION=REMOVEVOLUME VOLNAME=vol_sadwe WHERE HOSTNAME=scaqaw03adm01vm01
      8. Revert the guest password to oeda default (welcome1)

Jira: Exadata Exascale Testing Team / EXESL-425: Cloud Use Case: OEDACLI volume attachment with 19c ASM on EDV
     Wiki: https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/x/ZrRWhgM

   Usage: sh tsagrh_oedacli_guest_edv_ops.sh <log_suffix> <is_basedb_guest> <is_vhostscsi_disk_hotplug> <attach_disk_count>
      [log_suffix]:                 Optional. Append to log name for readablity
      [is_basedb_guest]:            Optional. True for BaseDB or False for Non-BaseDB guest flag (Default: false)
      [is_vhostscsi_disk_hotplug]:  Optional. True for vhost-scsi hotplug or False for normal disk hotplug flag (Default: false)
      [attach_disk_count]:          Optional. Number disk hot attachment to specified guest VM (Default: 5)
      [lrg_name]:                   Optional. Give LRG_NAME if you want to run on specific guest VM from LRG

Test tsagrh_online_u01disk_expansion.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: lrgrhexaprovcluster.
Suites: EXAC_REALHW.
Description: tsagrh_online_u01disk_expansion.sh - RH online guest u01 disk expansion

Guest storage expansion in /u01 partition by resizing up the volume
     Below steps that show how to increase the space in /u01 partition dynamically
     Note:  VM is using elastic Exascale volumes
     1. escli chvolume <u01 volId> --attributes size=<new size>
     2. virsh blockresize <guest> --path <u01 mount> --size <new size>
     3. On guest: parted <block dev> resizepart <partition no> <partition End>
     4. On guest: pvresize <phyical vol>
     5. On guest: lvresize -l +100%FREE <lvpath>
     6. On guest: xfs_growfs /u01
     7.Verify new size using 'df -h /u01' on guest

Detailed steps here: https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/x/rterrQI

   MODIFIED   (MM/DD/YY)
   sadwe       12/16/24 - Creation

Description: This scripts is a test for vtambi_clear_ms_esnode_attr_on_ers_disable.

    Steps follwed in order:

    Step 1: Disable AEP
     Step 1.1: List cluster to check servicePlacement before Disabling AEP
     Step 1.2: Change AEP servicePlacement from auto to manual
     Step 1.3: Validate AEP is turned from auto to manual

    Step 2: Run chservice --disable ers for cell2 and verify esnode attr
     Step 2.1: List esnode on cell2 before disabling ERS
     Step 2.2: List ERS status before disabling ERS
     Step 2.3: Disable ERS on cell2
     Step 2.3: Confirm ERS is disable on cell2
     Step 2.4: Make sure below ESNODE attributes read as empty on cell2
           frontEndPriority, restBackend, restBackendServerList, ersip

    Step 3: Disable any non-ERS service (USREDS) on cell3 and verify esnode attr
     Step 3.1: List USEREDS status before disabling
     Step 3.2: List esnode on cell3 before disabling USREDS
     Step 3.3: Disable USEREDS on cell3
     Step 3.4: ensure that the disable for that service works
     Step 3.5: verify no ESNODE attribute are cleared on cell3

    Step 4: Re-enable the services back in order
     Step 4.1: Enable USREDS on cell3
     Step 4.2: Enable USREDS on cell2
     Step 4.3: Enable AEP

Connect to ESCLI instance of cell1 using port 8080 (ERS backend)

Test tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh - VM_MAKER utility for Live-Migration

Usage:
     $ sh tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh <cells> <src_host> <dest_host> <guest> <option>

     Options:

     1. Perform precheck validations before migration event
        cmd    : vm_maker --precheck-live-migrate-domain
        oprion : precheck
        example: $ sh tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh <cells> <src_host> <dest_host> <guest> precheck

     2. Perform EDV resource setup before migration event
        oprion : setup_resources
        example: $ sh tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh <cells> <src_host> <dest_host> <guest> setup_resources

     3. Perform Livemigration of domain from src host to destination host
        cmd    : vm_maker --migrate-domain
        oprion : live_migrate
        example: $ sh tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh <cells> <src_host> <dest_host> <guest> live_migrate

     4. List ongoing/completed migration event of domain on src host
        cmd    : vm_maker --list-migration
        oprion : list_migration
        example: $ sh tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh <cells> <src_host> <dest_host> <guest> list_migration

     5. Abort ongoing migration event of  domain on src host
        cmd    : vm_maker --migrate-domain --domain <domain> --abort
        oprion : abort_migrate
        example: $ sh tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh <cells> <src_host> <dest_host> <guest> abort_migrate

This utility only supports single migration event at a one time
     For concurrent migration append '&' to run the command in background

   MODIFIED   (MM/DD/YY)
   sadwe       01/06/25 - Add prereq to create bridges interface on the dest host
   sadwe       10/09/24 - Creation

Description: tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig_scenarios.sh - RH Live Migration Scenarios using VM_MAKER

This File contins multiple test scenarios for the Live Migrations using
     VM_MAKER commands, call tsagrh_vmmaker_livemig.sh utility to perform migrations.

     Following scenarios are covered:
     1. Migrate guest1 from kvmhost1 to kvmhost2 and Migrate it back - 5 times
     2. Migrate guest1,guest2 from kvmhost1 to kvmhost2 concurrently and Migrate them back concurrently - 5 times (Parallel Migration)
     3. Migrate guest1 from kvmhost1 and guest2 of same cluster(Cluster-1) from kvmhost2 in parallel and Migrate them back to their original computes concurrently - 5 times (Cross parallel migration of same cluster nodes)

Test tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh - Driver for tsagrh_vmmaker_options.sh

This txn adds vm_maker coverage as a part of dedicated testsuite to RH.
     Aimed certain abilities in the test framework:
     1. Improved Coverage of vm_maker commands end-to-end covering all options/flags.
     2. Ability to run particular set of vm_maker commands from cmd line.
     3. Flexibility in the framework to be plugged in lrgs or integration(so no oratst).
     4. Standalone framework that can be run manually/locally outside lrgs/integration.

https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/x/VO40gAI

     How to run the utility?
     1. Run all vm_maker options:
     sh tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh run_all <comma seperated list of hosts>
     Example: sh tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh run_all "scacad02adm01.us.oracle.com,scacad03adm01.us.oracle.com"

     2. Run list of user specified options:
     sh tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh run_list <comma seperated list of options> <comma seperated list of hosts>
     Example: sh tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh run_list "--set --memory,--list --vcpu,--reboot" "scacad02adm01.us.oracle.com"

     3. Run Bug tests: (run_all also calls run_bugtest)
     sh tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh run_bugtest <comma seperated list of hosts>
     Example: sh tsagrh_vmmaker_testsuite.sh run_bugtest "scacad02adm01.us.oracle.com,"scacad03adm01.us.oracle.com""

   MODIFIED   (MM/DD/YY)
   sadwe       07/25/24 - Creation

Test tsagrhvolgrpresource.sh. setup=(none). flags: (none). platform: REAL HARDWARE.
LRGs: (none).
Suites: (none).
Description: tsagrhvolgrpresource.sh - This script contains test for RHW vol group types

test for new volume group types, with resourceSharing attribute set to aggregate, none, specified.
    more test details can be found here :
    https://confluence.oraclecorp.com/confluence/display/EXC/Multiple+Volume+Groups+and+Volume+Group+Type

      test 1
      create a volume group with resourceSharing=aggregate, iops=0
      create a volume with iops =200. add this volume to volume group.
      lsvol and lsvolgrp should show the volume's iops value.
      change the volume grp type to specified. should alter successfully

      test 2
      Create a volumegroup with resourceSharing=none.
      create a volume with 300 iops. add it to volume group.
      lsvolume should show iops 300 and lsvolumegroup should show iops should be 0

      test 3
      Create a volume group with resourceSharing=specified, iops=1000
      Create volume with 500 iops. add this volume to volumegroup
      lsvolume should show that volume iops is now 1000

      test 4
      one volume can be added to different vol groups (max 5 groups and only one of them can be sharing.)

      test 5
      # create a volume group. add few volumes to , check iops of volume group.
      # create a clone of volumes
      # then remove some volume groups , check iops of volume group.

      test 6
      create clones and restored bkps to all 3 different types of volume groups
      and check the iopsProvisioned attribute of vol grp for expected output

      test 7
      add volume with invalid id to volumegroups
      add volume to volumegroup with invalide id

     test 8
     add a volume to volumeGroups of all type,
     chvolume alter the volume iops value,
     check lsvolume and lsvolumegroup
